@article{87DuFeHa_2,
abstract = {The four A1-species fundamentals of ketene have been analyzed at a resolution of 0.05 cm-1. Assignments are made for J ² 36 and Ka ² 7, and asymmetry splittings observed for Ka ² 2. Although individual subband analyses can be made, yielding upper state B, C, and B constants, all four bands exhibit irregular subband origins such that in no case can an accurate vibrational origin be determined. The rather close-lying perturbing levels can almost certainly be identified but no strictly quantitative interpretation of the perturbations can be made. Studies of the spectra of H213C12CO and H212C13CO confirm the origin of these perturbations. They are particularly acute in the cases of $\nu$3 (_ 1387 cm-1), in Fermi resonance with $\nu$8 + $\nu$9, and of $\nu$4 (_ 1116 cm-1), in Fermi resonance with $\nu$5 + $\nu$6, and also 2$\nu$5 and 2$\nu$6. Indeed, in the latter case, it is debatable whether the observed band should be called $\nu$4 at all. On the other hand, analyses of the 2$\nu$8 overtones of the CH2 rocking fundamentals in the isotopic ketenes show little evidence of the effects of vibrational perturbations. The four fundamentals of dideuteroketene have also been studied; only $\nu$1 would appear to be essentially unperturbed. {\textcopyright} 1987.},
author = {Duncan, J. L. and Ferguson, A. M. and Harper, J. and Tonge, K. H. and Hegelund, F.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(87)90219-0},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {1},
pages = {72--93},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution infrared rovibrational studies of the A1 species fundamentals of isotopic ketenes}},
volume = {122},
year = {1987}
}

@article{87DuFeHa,
abstract = {The general harmonic force field (GHFF) of ketene has been determined through a joint empirical-ab initio investigation. Perturbations in the infrared spectra of all isotopic species render experimental frequency data of limited discriminatory value in the empirical determination. Microwave/infrared determined quartic distortion constants are found to be mutually incompatible, both within and between isotopic species. The sensitivity of the distortion constants to truncation and constraints made in their determination is established in order to make a realistic estimate of their reliability in the force constant calculations. Ab initio calculations performed at various different levels of sophistication predict consistent values for interaction constants, some of which are markedly different from previously reported empirical values. The joint empirical-ab initio GHFF reproduces all observed and perturbation-corrected data well over five isotopic species. Coriolis interaction constants are calculated for ketene-H2, -HD, and -D2, which will be of assistance to future analyses, particularly of the strongly interacting four-level systems below 1000 cm-1. Scaled ab initio force constants, calculated around the experimental ground state geometry as reference, are in excellent agreement with the empirical values, with one exception, which arises due to neglect of configuration interaction. {\textcopyright} 1987.},
author = {Duncan, J. L. and Ferguson, A. M. and Harper, J. and Tonge, K. H.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(87)90207-4},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {1},
pages = {196--213},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{A combined empirical-ab initio determination of the general harmonic force field of ketene}},
volume = {125},
year = {1987}
}

abstract = {The four A1-species fundamentals of ketene have been analyzed at a resolution of 0.05 cm-1. Assignments are made for J ² 36 and Ka ² 7, and asymmetry splittings observed for Ka ² 2. Although individual subband analyses can be made, yielding upper state B, C, and B constants, all four bands exhibit irregular subband origins such that in no case can an accurate vibrational origin be determined. The rather close-lying perturbing levels can almost certainly be identified but no strictly quantitative interpretation of the perturbations can be made. Studies of the spectra of H213C12CO and H212C13CO confirm the origin of these perturbations. They are particularly acute in the cases of $\nu$3 (_ 1387 cm-1), in Fermi resonance with $\nu$8 + $\nu$9, and of $\nu$4 (_ 1116 cm-1), in Fermi resonance with $\nu$5 + $\nu$6, and also 2$\nu$5 and 2$\nu$6. Indeed, in the latter case, it is debatable whether the observed band should be called $\nu$4 at all. On the other hand, analyses of the 2$\nu$8 overtones of the CH2 rocking fundamentals in the isotopic ketenes show little evidence of the effects of vibrational perturbations. The four fundamentals of dideuteroketene have also been studied; only $\nu$1 would appear to be essentially unperturbed. {\textcopyright} 1987.},

@article{94EsDoCa,
abstract = {Infrared and Raman spectra of the v1 band of ketene, H 2CCO, have been recorded at Doppler resolution. The infrared spectrum has been obtained with a difference frequency infrared spectrometer, and the Raman spectrum of the Q branches of this band has been recorded using a stimulated Raman spectrometer. The vib-rotational analysis of the data is very complicated because of many crossings with other vibrational states, which can interact with v1=1 through Fermi or Coriolis mechanisms. We present a discussion on global and local resonances, and we are able to extract information on the perturbing levels and on the perturbation parameters, even though the perturbing bands are not always detected in the spectrum. {\textcopyright} 1994 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Escribano, Rafael and Dom{\'{e}}nech, Jos{\'{e}} L. and Cancio, Pablo and Ortigoso, Juan and Santos, Julio and Bermejo, Dionisio},
doi = {10.1063/1.467748},
file = {::},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {CORIOLIS FORCE,DOPPLER EFFECT,FERMI RESONANCE,INFRARED SPECTRA,KETENES,PERTURBATION THEORY,RAMAN SPECTRA,RESOLUTION,ROTATIONAL STATES,STIMULATED EMISSION,VIBRATIONAL STATES},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {2},
pages = {937--949},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{The v1 band of ketene}},
url = {http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.467748},
volume = {101},
year = {1994}
}

@article{72JoStWi,
abstract = {We have reexamined the infrared spectrum of ketene in the 3$\mu$m region, and analysed two B-type perpendicular bands; the stronger is associated with the fundamental $\nu$7 and the weaker with the combination band ($\nu$2 + $\nu$8). Furthermore we have examined the millimeterwave spectrum up to 200 GHz and measured several pure rotational transitions. The ground state combination differences obtained from the infrared spectrum together with the microwave and the new millimeterwave transitions have been used to determine a complete set of ground state rotational and centrifugal distortion constants. The derived rotational constants are A = 282081 ± 12 MHzB = 10293.9722 ± 0.0059 MHzC = 9915.2396 ± 0.0062 MHz. {\textcopyright} 1972.},
author = {Johns, J. W.C. and Stone, J. M.R. and Winnewisser, G.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(72)90227-5},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {3},
pages = {523--535},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The ground state of ketene}},
volume = {42},
year = {1972}
}

@article{11PrSaJo,
abstract = {Glyoxal, methylglyoxal, and 2,3-butanedione (diacetyl) are all known biomass burning effluents and suspected aerosol precursors. Pressure-broadened quantitative infrared spectra of glyoxal, methylglyoxal, and diacetyl vapors covering the 520-6500 cm -1 range are reported at 0.112 cm -1 resolution, each with a composite spectrum derived from a minimum of 10 different sample pressures for the compound, representing some of the first quantitative intensity data for these analytes. Many vibrational assignments for methylglyoxal are reported for the first time, as are some near-IR and far-IR bands of glyoxal and diacetyl. To complete the vibrational assignments, the far-infrared spectra (25-600 cm -1) of all three vapors are also reported, those of methylglyoxal for the first time. Density functional theory and ab initio MP2 theory are used to help assign vibrational modes. Potential bands for atmospheric monitoring are discussed. {\textcopyright} 2011 American Chemical Society.},
author = {Profeta, Luisa T.M. and Sams, Robert L. and Johnson, Timothy J. and Williams, Stephen D.},
doi = {10.1021/jp204532x},
issn = {10895639},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {35},
pages = {9886--9900},
pmid = {21755958},
title = {{Quantitative infrared intensity studies of vapor-phase glyoxal, methylglyoxal, and 2,3-butanedione (diacetyl) with vibrational assignments}},
volume = {115},
year = {2011}
}

@article{71CoOs,
abstract = {All i.r.-active vibrations of C2H2O2, C2HDO2 and C2D2O have been studied under resolution sufficient to allow the determination of accurate band centres from the rotational structure. The low frequency torsion v7, which is responsible for the appearance of hot bands, has been investigated in detail and accurate vibrational spacings measured up to the fifth level. The nearly-harmonic character of these spacings is proof that the glyoxal molecule is planar. A Coriolis interaction occurs between the torsion and v12, the antisymmetric skeletal bending vibration. {\textcopyright} 1971.},
author = {Cole, A. R.H. and Osborne, G. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(71)80144-7},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {12},
pages = {2461--2490},
title = {{Vibrational spectra of glyoxal, monodeuteroglyoxal and dideuteroglyoxal}},
volume = {27},
year = {1971}
}

@article{02LaHeCe,
abstract = {The high-resolution Fourier transform infrared spectrum of trans-glyoxal in the gas phase has been recorded in the spectral regions 700-900 cm_1, 1200-1400 cm_1, and 1600-1800 cm_1 with a resolution ranging from 0.0020 to 0.0025 cm_1. The spectrum displays extensive rotational structures which are assigned to the three fundamental bands v6 (Au, 801.5 cm_1), and v10 (Bu, 1732.1 cm_1). A total of ca. 5000 absorption lines have been assigned to these three bands. A simultaneous ground state combination difference analysis of all three bands yields improved ground state spectroscopic constants for trans-glyoxal. Furthermore, a number of spectroscopic constants for the v6 and v11 levels have been determined for the first time. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science.},
author = {{Wugt Larsen}, R. and Hegelund, F. and Ceponkus, J. and Nelander, B.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2001.8489},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {127--134},
title = {{A high-resolution ft-ir study of the fundamental bands v6, v10, and v11 of trans-glyoxal}},
volume = {211},
year = {2002}
}

@article{70CoOs,
abstract = {The type B infrared band, $\nu$9, of glyoxal has been studied under high resolution and although there is extensive overlap of hot bands due to molecules in excited states of the low frequency torsion, 636 individual lines have been assigned in the subbands with Ka$\Delta$Ka = 11 to -11. In particular, many lines have been assigned in the central, low Ka, region where the subbands are split by asymmetry. The rotational constants have been determined by means of a line-fitting computer program and the ground state constants are in good agreement with those determined by Paldus and Ramsay from the visible electronic spectrum. The constants are A_ = 1.8445 ± 0.0002 cm-1 A_ = 1.8379 ± 0.0002 cm-1B_ = 0.15993 ± 0.00007 B_ = 0.15982 ± 0.00007C_ = 0.14723 ± 0.00007 C_ = 0.14707 ± 0.00007Dk_ = (0.199 ± 0.014) _ 10 -4 Dk_ = (0.209 ± 0.012) _ 10 -4. {\textcopyright} 1970.},
author = {Cole, A. R.H. and Osborne, G. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(70)90214-6},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {3},
pages = {376--385},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Rotational fine structure of the antisymmetric CH stretching band $\nu$9, of glyoxal}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022285270902146},
volume = {36},
year = {1970}
}

@article{66EnAs,
abstract = {The previous study of infrared spectra of VC(vinyl chloride) and VC-d3 was developed with those of VC-$\alpha$d1, VC-$\beta$,$\beta$d2, VC-$\beta$d1, and VC-$\alpha$,$\beta$d2. A normal coordinate analysis was made for their infrared spectra by the customary GF matrix method with a force field of the Urey-Bradley type for the planar vibrations and a modified valence-type potential function for the nonplanar ones. The force constants which were determined by a least squares process with the spectra of VC, VC-$\alpha$d1, and VC-d3 could well explain other spectra.},
author = {Enomoto, S and Asahiva, M},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {1-4},
pages = {117--130},
title = {{Infrared spectra of vinyl chloride and its deuterated derivatives}},
volume = {19},
year = {1966}
}

@article{05De,
abstract = {The quadratic, cubic, and semi-diagonal quartic force field of vinyl chloride has been calculated at the MP2 level of theory employing a basis set of triple-$\zeta$ quality. The spectroscopic constants derived from this force field are compared with the experimental values. To make this comparison more complete, the rotational constants of the lowest excited state, v9 = 1 at 395 cm-1 have been determined by microwave spectroscopy and the $\nu$12 band (around 618 cm-1) has been investigated by high-resolution infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy. The equilibrium structure has been derived from experimental ground state rotational constants and ab initio rovibrational interaction parameters. This semi-experimental structure is in excellent agreement with the ab initio structure calculated at the CCSD(T) level of theory using a basis set of quintuple-$\zeta$ quality and a core correlation correction. The experimental mass-dependent rm structures are also determined and their accuracy is discussed. The recommended equilibrium geometry is: r (CC) = 1.3262(10), r (CCl) = 1.7263(10), r (CH g) = 1.0784(10), r (CHc) = 1.0795(10), r (CHt) = 1.0797(10), _(CCCl) = 122.77(10)¡, _(CCHg) = 123.86(10)¡, _(CCHc) = 121.80(10)¡, _(CCH t) = 119.29(10)¡. {\textcopyright} 2005 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Demaison, J. and M{\o}llendal, H. and Perrin, A. and Orphal, J. and Tchana, F. Kwabia and Rudolph, H. D. and Willaert, F.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2005.04.006},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Ab initio,Anharmonic force field,Equilibrium structure,Infrared,Microwave,Vinyl chloride},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {174--185},
title = {{Microwave and high resolution infrared spectra of vinyl chloride, ab initio anharmonic force field and equilibrium structure}},
volume = {232},
year = {2005}
}

@article{05De,
abstract = {The quadratic, cubic, and semi-diagonal quartic force field of vinyl chloride has been calculated at the MP2 level of theory employing a basis set of triple-$\zeta$ quality. The equilibrium structure has been derived from experimental ground state rotational constants and ab initio rovibrational interaction parameters. @article{00LoGiBi,
abstract = {The Fourier transform gas-phase infrared spectra of the v 10 and v 11 bands of natural CH2=CHCl have been measured with a resolution of 0.005 cm_1 in the frequency range 820Ð1010 cm_1. These vibrations of symmetry species A_ give rise to c-type bands and the transitions observed are characterized by $\delta$K a = ±1 and $\delta$K c = 0, ±2. Both J and K structures have been resolved in different subbranches and about 1800 (J ² 64, K a ² 13) and 2800 (J ² 72, K a ² 14) transitions for the v 10 and v 11 fundamentals, respectively, have been identified for the 35Cl isotopomer. Combined analysis of the assigned data with the available ground state constants allowed the determination of the band origins, rotational and centrifugal distortion parameters for the v 10 = 1 and v 11 = 1 excited states of CH2=CH35Cl isotopic species. The molecular constants obtained account for slight perturbations in the v 10 vibrational level. {\textcopyright} 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {{De Lorenzi}, A. and Giorgianni, S. and Bini, R.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970009483300},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {6},
pages = {355--362},
title = {{High-resolution FTIR spectrum of vinyl chloride: Rovibrational analysis of the v10 and v11 fundamental bands}},
volume = {98},
year = {2000}
}

@article{00LoGiBi,
abstract = {The Fourier transform gas-phase infrared spectra of the v 10 and v 11 bands of natural CH2=CHCl have been measured with a resolution of 0.005 cm_1 in the frequency range 820Ð1010 cm_1. These vibrations of symmetry species A_ give rise to c-type bands and the transitions observed are characterized by $\delta$K a = ±1 and $\delta$K c = 0, ±2. Both J and K structures have been resolved in different subbranches and about 1800 (J ² 64, K a ² 13) and 2800 (J ² 72, K a ² 14) transitions for the v 10 and v 11 fundamentals, respectively, have been identified for the 35Cl isotopomer. Combined analysis of the assigned data with the available ground state constants allowed the determination of the band origins, rotational and centrifugal distortion parameters for the v 10 = 1 and v 11 = 1 excited states of CH2=CH35Cl isotopic species. The molecular constants obtained account for slight perturbations in the v 10 vibrational level. {\textcopyright} 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},

@article{97StGiGh,
abstract = {The gas-phase infrared spectra of natural CH2 = CHCl and monoisotopic CH2 = CH37Cl(isotopic purity, 95%) have been investigated in the $\upsilon$7 band region near 1030 cm -1, at Doppler-limited resolution, employing a tunable diode laser spectrometer. This vibration of symmetry species A 'is expected to give rise to an a/b hybrid band, with a predominant contribution of the a-type component. A rovibrational analysis led to the identification of more than 1100 (J ² 51, K a ² 12) and 1000 (J ² 47, K a 12) transitions belonging to the 35Cl and 37Cl isotopomers, respectively. The band was found to be affected by different perturbations, and avoided crossings due to the second-order a-Coriolis resonance with the $\upsilon$9 + $\upsilon$12 combination also were observed. After using Watson's A-reduction Hamiltonian in the I r representation, the assigned transitions provided a set of effective upper state constants for both the isotopic species. {\textcopyright} 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Stoppa, P. and Giorgianni, S. and Ghersetti, S.},
doi = {10.1080/002689797171526},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {215--222},
title = {{Infrared measurements and rovibrational study of the v7 band of vinyl chloride by diode laser spectroscopy}},
volume = {91},
year = {1997}
}

@article{92GiLoPe,
abstract = {The gas-phase infrared spectrum of natural CH2_CHCl has been measured in the $\nu$6 band region near 1281 cm_1 at a resolution of about 0.002 cm_1 using a tunable diode laser spectrometer. This vibration of symmetry species A_ is expected to give rise to an hybrid band, which resulted mainly composed by a-type transitions. The spectrum investigated exhibits patterns characteristic of molecules approaching to the prolate symmetric-top limit; the rovibrational analysis in the P, Q, and R branches led to the assignment of more than 1000 lines with J ² 40 and Ka ² 14. The band was found to be affected by Coriolis-type resonance and the $\nu$9 + $\nu$11 state seems to be involved in the perturbation. From a simultaneous fit of the obtained ground state combination differences, together with microwave data available in the literature, a set of ground state constants up to the quartic coefficients has been determined using the Watson's A-reduction Hamiltonian in the I_ representation. A least-squares fit of the assigned transitions yielded a set of effective constants for the first excited vibrational state of the $\nu$6 of CH2_CH 35Cl.},
author = {Giorgianni, S. and {De Lorenzi}, A. and Stoppa, Paolo and Ghersetti, S.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(92)90207-5},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {373--382},
title = {{Infrared spectrum and rovibrational analysis of the $\nu$6 band of vinyl chloride by diode laser spectroscopy}},
volume = {156},
year = {1992}
}

@article{97GiStLo,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of CH2=CH37Cl has been investigated in the $\upsilon$5 band region around 1370 cm-1, at Doppler-limited resolution, using a tunable diode laser spectrometer. This vibration of symmetry species A_ yields an a/b hybrid band exhibiting patterns characteristic of molecules approaching the prolate symmetric top limit. The J fine structure was resolved in most of the (P,)QK clusters and the rovibrational analysis in the P, Q and R branches led to the assignment of about 800 transitions with J _ 49 and Ka _ 11. The band is affected by different Coriolis-type resonances with the nearby states $\upsilon$8 + $\upsilon$12 and $\upsilon$9 + $\upsilon$10. Using the Watson's A-reduction Hamiltonian in the Ir representation, a least-squares fit of about 650 transitions free of major resonance contribution provided a set of effective molecular constants for the v 5 = 1 state of CH2=CH37Cl. From spectral simulation the |$\Delta$µa /$\Delta$µb| dipole moment ratio was estimated to be 0{\textperiodcentered}74 ± 0{\textperiodcentered}08. {\textcopyright} 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Giorgianni, S. and Stoppa, P. and {De Lorenzi}, A.},
doi = {10.1080/002689797170491},
isbn = {0026897971704},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {301--306},
title = {{Infrared laser spectroscopy of the nu band of CH2--CH37Cl}},
volume = {92},
year = {1997}
}

abstract = {The previous study of infrared spectra of VC(vinyl chloride) and VC-d3 was developed with those of VC-$\alpha$d1, VC-$\beta$,$\beta$d2, VC-$\beta$d1, and VC-$\alpha$,$\beta$d2. A normal coordinate analysis was made for their infrared spectra by the customary GF matrix method with a force field of the Urey-Bradley type for the planar vibrations and a modified valence-type potential function for the nonplanar ones. The force constants which were determined by a least squares process with the spectra of VC, VC-$\alpha$d1, and VC-d3 could well explain other spectra.},

journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},

@article{66EnAs,
abstract = {The previous study of infrared spectra of VC(vinyl chloride) and VC-d3 was developed with those of VC-$\alpha$d1, VC-$\beta$,$\beta$d2, VC-$\beta$d1, and VC-$\alpha$,$\beta$d2. A normal coordinate analysis was made for their infrared spectra by the customary GF matrix method with a force field of the Urey-Bradley type for the planar vibrations and a modified valence-type potential function for the nonplanar ones. The force constants which were determined by a least squares process with the spectra of VC, VC-$\alpha$d1, and VC-d3 could well explain other spectra.},
author = {Enomoto, S and Asahiva, M},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {1-4},
pages = {117--130},
title = {{Infrared spectra of vinyl chloride and its deuterated derivatives}},
volume = {19},
year = {1966}
}

_@article{79PaPeAr,
abstract = {Acetonitrile-15N has been synthesized from ammonium chloride with a 99.4% 15N isotopic content. The IR spectrum of the liquid has been recorded in the range 10,000-20 cm-1 and some new assignments have been proposed particularly in the range 10,000-4,000 cm-1. The spectrum of the gas has been recorded in the range 4,000-200 cm-1 and $\nu$5 and $\nu$7 have been analyzed as well as the $\nu$6, $\nu$7 + $\nu$8 Fermi resonant band system. Molecular parameters suitable for force constant refinements have been calculated. {\textcopyright} 1979.},
author = {Parellada, R. and Perez-Pe{\~{n}}a, J. and Arenas, J. F.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2860(79)80263-X},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {C},
pages = {1--7},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of acetonitrile-15N}},
volume = {51},
year = {1979}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{20GuWaHa,
abstract = {Ultrahigh-resolution and -precision air-broadened acetonitrile (CH3CN) spectra of the v5-band in the region of 3039.0Ð3041.5 cm_1 were recorded and analyzed using tunable laser absorption spectroscopy (TLAS) technology with a distributed feedback interband cascade laser. The spectral line profile of methane (CH4) was used as the standard to correct the nonlinearity and baseline drift in the CH3CN spectra. The recorded spectra are very close to that in the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) database, however it has a much lower absorbance uncertainty of 1.02%. The air-broadened CH3CN absorption at the v5-band with a spectral resolution of 2.15 _ 10_5 cm_1 ($\sim$23 fm/637 kHz) and an estimated uncertainty of 1.1% was derived at a temperature of 296.75 K and a pressure of 1 atm. The ultrahigh-resolution and -precision spectra of CH3CN provide reference data for absolute spectral measurements, laser remote sensing, and atmospheric inversion.},
author = {Guan, Hongfei and Wang, Xiaoyu and Han, Ruiyan and Yuan, Liming and Meng, Shuo and Wang, Shuanke and Du, Zhenhui},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2020.107254},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Acetonitrile,High-resolution and -precision spectra,Tunable laser absorption spectroscopy (TLAS)},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {nov},
pages = {107254},
publisher = {Elsevier Ltd},
title = {{High-resolution and -precision spectra of acetonitrile at the $\nu$5-band for laser remote sensing}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2020.107254 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022407320304271},
volume = {255},
year = {2020}
}

@article{96KhPaBr,
abstract = {In the frame of a program of systematic studies to determine or reassess the absolute intensities of gas phase organics of interest to Titan, we have experimentally studied the IR spectra in the gas phase of diazomethane, methyl azide, and methyl isocyanide, at room temperature, in the 250-4300 cm-1 region. The absolute intensities, Sv, of the most intense vibrational bands of these compounds were determined experimentally together with the associated uncertainties. In order to estimate the detectability of the selected compounds by infrared spectroscopy in Titan's atmosphere, our data were compared with Voyager IRIS spectra of Titan. Upper limits of, respectively, 5, 5.4, and 1.3 ppb on the mean stratospheric abundances are inferred. These values are consistent with photochemical modeling of Titan's atmosphere. They appear auspicious for possible detection in Titan using upcoming space missions. {\textcopyright} 1996 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Khlifi, Mohammed and Paillous, Pierre and Bruston, Paul and Raulin, Fran{\c{c}}ois and Guillemin, Jean Claude},
doi = {10.1006/icar.1996.0207},
issn = {00191035},
journal = {Icarus},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {1},
pages = {318--328},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Absolute IR band intensities of CH2N2, CH3N3, and CH3NC in the 250-4300 cm-1 region and upper limits of abundance in Titan's stratosphere}},
volume = {124},
year = {1996}
}

The absolute intensities, Sv, of the most intense vibrational bands of these compounds were determined experimentally together with the associated uncertainties. In order to estimate the detectability of the selected compounds by infrared spectroscopy in Titan's atmosphere, our data were compared with Voyager IRIS spectra of Titan. @article{He1992,
abstract = {The first completely resolved high-resolution infrared vibration-rotation spectrum of methyl isocyanide (CH3NC) has been obtained. The $\nu$4 band was measured between 900 and 990 cm-1 with a resolution of 0.006 cm-1; 971 transitions were assigned to the P and R branches of the $\nu$4 fundamental band spanning K = 0 to K = 9 and J = 0 to J = 65. Reliable and highly accurate sets of spectroscopic constants for both of the $\nu$4 and ground states were generated. Small anomalies were found in a group of lines in the low-J region of the K = 4 subband and near J = 61 of the K = 3 subband. A perturbation analysis was performed based on symmetry considerations. A rotational resonance ($\Delta$l = _ 1, $\Delta$k = ±2) between the $\nu$4 and 3$\nu$8±1 (kl < 0) was found to be the most probable origin of the anomalies, and the interaction matrix element has been derived. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {He, Chun and Bernheim, R.A},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(92)90526-T},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {2},
pages = {365--383},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution spectroscopy of methyl isocyanide: The $\nu$4 fundamental and ground state constants}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/002228529290526T},
volume = {155},
year = {1992}
}

@article{95LePlGo,
abstract = {The vibration-rotation spectrum of methyl isocyanide (CH3NC) has been recorded with the aid of a high-resolution Fourier transform spectrometer in the region 1370 to 1560 cm_1 containing the perpendicular band of the fundamental vibration $
u$6 (species E), the weaker parallel band of the $
u$3 (A1) fundamental, and the perpendicular combination band $
u$_7 + $
u$_8 (E) enhanced by Fermi resonance with $
u$6. Sixteen hundred seventy well-resolved lines were assigned to 15 subbands of $
u$6, 6 subbands of $
u$3, and 3 subbands of $
u$_7 + $
u$_8. A strong x, y-Coriolis resonance between $
u$3 and $
u$6 and Fermi resonance between $
u$±6 and the E component $
u$_7 + $
u$_8, as well as between $
u$3 and the A1,2 components $
u$±7 + $
u$_8, greatly affects the spectrum. Additional weaker anharmonic interaction of $
u$6 with the $
u$4 + 2$
u$28 combination and higher-order rotational interactions connecting the various states were also detected in the spectrum. All of these interactions have been incorporated into a 9 _ 9 Hamiltonian matrix used for modeling the upper states of the observed transitions. A set of spectroscopic constants is reported for the upper states of the bands $
u$3, $
u$6, and $
u$7 + $
u$8 and for $
u$4 + 2$
u$28 which reproduces the observed lines with an overall standard deviation of 0.0012 cm_1.},
author = {Le, L. and Pliva, J. and Gold, L. P. and Bernheim, R. A.},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {506--515},
title = {{High-Resolution Infrared Spectroscopy of Methyl Isocyanide: The $
u$3, $
u$6, and $
u$7 + $
u$8 Bands}},
volume = {170},
year = {1995}
}

@article{95LePlGo,
abstract = {The vibration-rotation spectrum of methyl isocyanide (CH3NC) has been recorded with the aid of a high-resolution Fourier transform spectrometer in the region 1370 to 1560 cm_1 containing the perpendicular band of the fundamental vibration $
u$6 (species E), the weaker parallel band of the $
u$3 (A1) fundamental, and the perpendicular combination band $
u$_7 + $
u$_8 (E) enhanced by Fermi resonance with $
u$6. Sixteen hundred seventy well-resolved lines were assigned to 15 subbands of $
u$6, 6 subbands of $
u$3, and 3 subbands of $
u$_7 + $
u$_8. A strong x, y-Coriolis resonance between $
u$3 and $
u$6 and Fermi resonance between $
u$±6 and the E component $
u$_7 + $
u$_8, as well as between $
u$3 and the A1,2 components $
u$±7 + $
u$_8, greatly affects the spectrum. Additional weaker anharmonic interaction of $
u$6 with the $
u$4 + 2$
u$28 combination and higher-order rotational interactions connecting the various states were also detected in the spectrum. All of these interactions have been incorporated into a 9 _ 9 Hamiltonian matrix used for modeling the upper states of the observed transitions. A set of spectroscopic constants is reported for the upper states of the bands $
u$3, $
u$6, and $
u$7 + $
u$8 and for $
u$4 + 2$
u$28 which reproduces the observed lines with an overall standard deviation of 0.0012 cm_1.},
author = {Le, L. and Pliva, J. and Gold, L. P. and Bernheim, R. A.},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {506--515},
title = {{High-Resolution Infrared Spectroscopy of Methyl Isocyanide: The $
u$3, $
u$6, and $
u$7 + $
u$8 Bands}},
volume = {170},
year = {1995}
}

@article{96KhPaBr,
abstract = {In the frame of a program of systematic studies to determine or reassess the absolute intensities of gas phase organics of interest to Titan, we have experimentally studied the IR spectra in the gas phase of diazomethane, methyl azide, and methyl isocyanide, at room temperature, in the 250-4300 cm-1 region. The absolute intensities, Sv, of the most intense vibrational bands of these compounds were determined experimentally together with the associated uncertainties. In order to estimate the detectability of the selected compounds by infrared spectroscopy in Titan's atmosphere, our data were compared with Voyager IRIS spectra of Titan. Upper limits of, respectively, 5, 5.4, and 1.3 ppb on the mean stratospheric abundances are inferred. These values are consistent with photochemical modeling of Titan's atmosphere. They appear auspicious for possible detection in Titan using upcoming space missions. {\textcopyright} 1996 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Khlifi, Mohammed and Paillous, Pierre and Bruston, Paul and Raulin, Fran{\c{c}}ois and Guillemin, Jean Claude},
doi = {10.1006/icar.1996.0207},
issn = {00191035},
journal = {Icarus},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {1},
pages = {318--328},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Absolute IR band intensities of CH2N2, CH3N3, and CH3NC in the 250-4300 cm-1 region and upper limits of abundance in Titan's stratosphere}},
volume = {124},
year = {1996}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{72BeCo,
abstract = {Infrared spectra of acetyl fluoride and acetyl fluoride-d3 are reported for the gas and the solid, as are the Raman spectra of the liquids. Changes in a previous assignment for CH3CFO [J. Chem. Phys. 53, 1713 (1970)] are indicated. Observed intensities and analogy with COF2 suggest that fundamentals at 826 and 1188 cm-1 are best described as in-phase and out-of-phase C-C-F stretches. The methyl rock and the in-phase C-C-F stretch are strongly mixed in CD3CFO (839 and 778 cm-1). A product-rule calculation indicates that the fundamental frequencies of CD3CFO are about 2 per cent higher than expected on the basis of a strictly harmonic potential function for CH3CPO. A similar calculation is used to compare CH3CFO with CF3CFO. {\textcopyright} 1972.},
author = {Berney, C. V. and Cormier, A. D.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(72)80153-3},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {10},
pages = {1813--1822},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Vibrational spectra of acetyl fluoride and acetyl fluoride-d3}},
volume = {28},
year = {1972}
}

A product-rule calculation indicates that the fundamental frequencies of CD3CFO are about 2 per cent higher than expected on the basis of a strictly harmonic potential function for CH3CPO. A similar calculation is used to compare CH3CFO with CF3CFO. {\textcopyright} 1972.},

title = {{Vibrational spectra of acetyl fluoride and acetyl fluoride-d3}},

@article{99HeHeGe,
abstract = {We describe experiments on acetaldehyde (12CH312CH16O) resulting in new or improved spectroscopic data on the n$\nu$3 (n=1-5) aldehyde CH stretching vibrational bands. The n=1 component is rotationally resolved using room temperature and supersonic jet Fourier transform spectroscopy, and vibration-rotation assignments are reported. The next two components (n=2, 3) are recorded at room temperature using Fourier transform spectroscopy, and the K-structure is resolved and assigned. The last two series of bands (n=4, 5) are observed but not resolved, using laser opto-acoustic spectroscopy. Effective vibrational constants ($\omega__eff3=2938.53 cm-1, xeff33=55.75 cm-1) are obtained. Information is also provided on additional bands in the spectrum from 1300 to 14 000 cm-1, involving, in particular, the assignment of the K-structure in $\nu$11 and 2$\nu$1, from the jet-cooled and the room-temperature Fourier transform spectral data, respectively. A table updating the origin of most vibration-rotation bands in acetaldehyde previously assigned in the literature is provided.},
author = {Herman, Michel and Herregodts, Fr{\'{e}}d{\'{e}}ric and Georges, Robert and Hepp, Martin and {Hadj Bachir}, Ikhlef and Lecoutre, Micha{\"{e}}l and Kleiner, Isabelle},
doi = {10.1016/S0301-0104(99)00167-6},
issn = {03010104},
journal = {Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {1-3},
pages = {433--443},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Spectroscopic investigation of vibration-rotation bands in acetaldehyde:: Focus on the n$\nu$3 (n=1-5) aldehyde CH stretch bands}},
volume = {246},
year = {1999}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{71HoGu,
abstract = {Infrared spectra from 4000 to 400 cm-1 of crystalline films and gases of CH3CHO, CH3CDO, CD3CHO, CD3CDO and CH2DCHO have been measured with spectral slit width ³ 0.4 cm-1. For the crystal spectra, factor group splittings were observed and identified by studying isotopically mixed crystals. In the gas spectra, the Q-branch structure of many bands were resolved. A nearly complete assignment, differing considerably from former work, of the fundamentals of CH3CHO, CH3CDO, CD3CHO and CD3CDO is based on a comparison of computed and observed rotational contours. The rotational structure of several bands reveal a Coriolis type coupling between nearly degenerate a' and a_ fundamentals, which is qualitatively discussed. Furthermore, some strong Fermi resonances of combination tones involving the torsional mode with fundamentals are found for the gas spectra. In the crystal spectra these resonances are lifted, the reason being a shift of the methyl torsion by 50-60 cm-1, caused by the crystal field. From a normal coordinate analysis, a fairly general harmonic valence force field and additional information about the assignments have been obtained. The RMS deviation of calculated and observed fundamental frequencies was about 7 cm-1. This is considered as a lower limit attainable by harmonic approximation. The normal coordinate analysis is also used to get a nearly complete assignment of the highly complex spectra of both the symmetric and gauche isomers of CH2DCHO. {\textcopyright} 1971.},
author = {Hollenstein, H. and G{\"{u}}nthard, Hs H.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(71)80102-2},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {10},
pages = {2027--2060},
title = {{Solid state and gas infrared spectra and normal coordinate analysis of 5 isotopic species of acetaldehyde}},
volume = {27},
year = {1971}
}

@article{94KlHe,
abstract = {The room temperature absorption spectrum of the $\nu$14 CCH bending fundamental band of acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) has been recorded with a Fourier transform interferometer at a resolution of 0.00186 cm-1. The spectrum exhibits c-type transitions which have been assigned up to values of J_ ² 20 and K_a ² 9 for the A-type transitions and of J_ ² 15 and K_a < 7 for the E-type transitions. All data could not be fitted simultaneously to measurement precision. A partial fit, gathering some 277 lines of A-type and 75 of E-type, could be achieved with a RMS deviation of 0.000594 cm-1, i.e., about twice the measurement precision. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Kleiner, I. and Herman, M.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1994.1237},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {300--313},
title = {{The fundamental $\nu$14 band of acetaldehyde}},
volume = {167},
year = {1994}
}

@article{95AnTrPa,
abstract = {The spectrum of the v9 A_ C-C stretching fundamental band of acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) at 867 cm-1 has been recorded in a slit-jet nozzle expansion using a diode-laser spectrometer and in a room-temperature gas cell using a Fourier- transform infrared spectrometer. The spectrum exhibits a-type transitions which have been assigned for J_ _ d 19 and X_ _ 5 for the A state and J_ _ 19 and K_a _ 4 for the E state. The transitions show a large tunnelling splitting of Å0 5 cm1 for Ka = 0, attributed primarily to an anharmonic interaction of the v9 vibration with the $\upsilon$14. + $\upsilon$15 torsional combination vibration at 920 cm-1. Evidence is also presented for an additional interacting vibration(s) affecting the $\upsilon$9 tunnelling splitting. {\textcopyright} 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Andrews, A. M. and Tretyakov, M. Yu and Pate, B. H. and Fraser, G. T. and Kleiner, I.},
doi = {10.1080/00268979500100151},issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {95AnTrPa},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
mendeley-tags = {95AnTrPa},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {201--210},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{Fourier-transform infrared and jet-cooled diode-iaser spectra of the 867 cm-1 v9 band of acetaldehyde}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?journalCode=tmph20},
volume = {84},
year = {1995}
}

@article{80Ho,
abstract = {The bands centred near 1430 and 1110 cm"1 in the infrared spectrum of acetaldehyde exhibit strongly distorted A-structures, indicating Coriolis resonance between $\upsilon$5(a') and $\upsilon$12(a) in the first, and $\upsilon$(a') and $\upsilon$13(a) in the second case. The K-structures of these bands have been analysed. The theory, which is very generally applicable to study Coriolis resonance phenomena in Cs-asymmetric tops, is formulated in terms of effective hamiltonians. Approximate solutions of the reduced problems involved are obtained by using perturbation theory. A least-squares analysis of sub-band frequencies yielded estimates for a number of molecular parameters. Among these, the vibrational frequencies are obtained as $\upsilon$5¡ = 1429-91, $\upsilon$12¡= 1435-83, $\upsilon$8¡ = 1114-04 and $\upsilon$u¡ = 1107-30 cm-1. A computer program has been written allowing the simulation of the Q-branch of a Coriolis resonance band involving an a'- and an a-fundamental of a Cs- asymmetric top molecule. This program was used to verify hypothetical assignments of sub-bands and of characteristic central features, and to estimate, roughly, relevant intensity parameters. An extraordinary K- structure anomaly observed with the rt, v12 band is traced to a term similar to the retype interaction in symmetric top molecules. {\textcopyright} 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Hollenstein, H.},
doi = {10.1080/00268978000100861},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {4},
pages = {1013--1033},
title = {{Coriolis resonance in cs-asymmetric tops analysis of the5, v12- and v8, v13-coriolis resonance bands in the infrared spectrum of acetaldehyde}},
volume = {39},
year = {1980}
}

_@article{65HaNo,
abstract = {Les spectres infrarouges des mol{\'{e}}cules CH3COOH, CH3COOD, CD3COOH et CD3COOD {\`{a}} l'{\'{e}}tat gazeux {\`{a}} 150¡C ont {\'{e}}t{\'{e}} enregistr{\'{e}}s entre 4 000 et 400 cm-1. Les vibrations fondamentales des monom{\`{e}}res correspondants ont {\'{e}}t{\'{e}} attribu{\'{e}}es en utilisant l'effet isotopique et l'enveloppe des bandes d'absorption comme crit{\`{e}}res principaux.},
author = {Haurie, Michel and Novak, Alexander},
doi = {10.1051/jcp/1965620137},
issn = {0021-7689},
journal = {Journal de Chimie Physique},
keywords = {EDP Sciences,Journal de Chimie Physique et de Physico-Chimie Bi,chimie physique,journal,physico-chimie biologique,revue},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
pages = {137--145},
publisher = {EDP Sciences},
title = {{Spectres de vibration des mol{\'{e}}cules CH 3 COOH, CH 3 COOD, CD 3 COOH et CD 3 COOD}},
url = {https://jcp.edpsciences.org/articles/jcp/abs/1965/01/jcp196562p137/jcp196562p137.html},
volume = {62},
year = {1965}
}

@article{05HaFeBl,
abstract = {The mid-IR and near-IR vapor phase spectrum of CH 3COOH was examined with a focus on the regions of the $\nu$ 17 O-H torsion and the $\nu$ 1 O-H stretch. Each region showed a number of peaks that were assigned using previous ab initio work, their temperature dependence, and analysis of the deuterated species of acetic acid (CD 3COOH, CH 3COOD, and CD 3COOD). These assignments correct and improve upon the values currently used in the literature. Many of the peaks were assigned as hot bands associated with either the $\nu$ 17 O-H torsion or the $\nu$ 1 O-H stretch. In addition, the first definitive assignment of the Q-branch of the $\nu$ 1 O-H stretch was made. The hot bands were shown to contribute a significant amount of absorption intensity to the $\nu$ 1 region at 298 K. An empirical temperature-dependent correction to the total absorption of the $\nu$ 1 O-H stretching region as well as an adjusted absolute cross-section for $\nu$ 1 are given and suggested for future use. {\textcopyright} 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Havey, Daniel K. and Feierabend, Karl J. and Black, Joshua C. and Vaida, Veronica},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2004.09.009},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Acetic acid,Hot bands,Spectroscopy,Torsions,Vibrational},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {2},
pages = {151--157},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Temperature-dependent infrared spectra of torsional vibrations in acetic acid}},
volume = {229},
year = {2005}
}

@article{20DiZiPo,
abstract = {We present the first matrix-isolation infrared (MI-IR) spectra of CH3CH2F and its isotopologue CD3CD2F in Neon and Argon matrix, together with new gas-phase IR spectra. Extensive vibrational self-consistent field and configuration interaction (VSCF/VCI) calculations are performed, based on an ab initio potential energy surface at ae-CCSD(T)-F12a/cc-pCVTZ-F12 level of electronic structure theory. We encounter an excellent agreement between VCI calculated transitions and the experimental MI-IR and gas-phase IR spectra. Mean absolute deviations are scattering between 1 and 4 cm_1. The interplay of accurate vibrational structure calculations and high-resolution infrared experiments enables unprecedented insights in the CH respectively CD stretch region, providing the first rigorous assignment of the energetically very close $\nu$1,$\nu$12 and $\nu$13 fundamental transitions.},
author = {Dinu, Dennis F. and Ziegler, Benjamin and Podewitz, Maren and Liedl, Klaus R. and Loerting, Thomas and Grothe, Hinrich and Rauhut, Guntram},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2019.111224},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
pages = {111224},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The interplay of VSCF/VCI calculations and matrix-isolation IR spectroscopy Ð Mid infrared spectrum of CH3CH2F and CD3CD2F}},
volume = {367},
year = {2020}
}

@article{20DiZiPo,
abstract = {We present the first matrix-isolation infrared (MI-IR) spectra of CH3CH2F and its isotopologue CD3CD2F in Neon and Argon matrix, together with new gas-phase IR spectra. Extensive vibrational self-consistent field and configuration interaction (VSCF/VCI) calculations are performed, based on an ab initio potential energy surface at ae-CCSD(T)-F12a/cc-pCVTZ-F12 level of electronic structure theory. We encounter an excellent agreement between VCI calculated transitions and the experimental MI-IR and gas-phase IR spectra. Mean absolute deviations are scattering between 1 and 4 cm_1. The interplay of accurate vibrational structure calculations and high-resolution infrared experiments enables unprecedented insights in the CH respectively CD stretch region, providing the first rigorous assignment of the energetically very close $\nu$1,$\nu$12 and $\nu$13 fundamental transitions.},
author = {Dinu, Dennis F. and Ziegler, Benjamin and Podewitz, Maren and Liedl, Klaus R. and Loerting, Thomas and Grothe, Hinrich and Rauhut, Guntram},

@article{11LaLaHo,
abstract = {A high resolution Fourier transform infrared spectrum of C 2H 6, measured at a pressure of 173.3Pa and an optical path of 153.2m, was analysed between 1050 and 1295cm -1. Extensive absorption due to the difference bands v 11-v 4, and several rotation-torsion lines of the difference band v 2-v 4, in the region of the x, y-Coriolis resonance of v 2 and v 11, were observed. This allowed a detailed rotation-torsion analysis of the upper states v 11 and v 2. The anomalous torsional structure, found in the non-degenerate vibrational state v 2, can be explained as the effect of an Hamiltonian term accounting for a strong dependence of the torsional barrier height on the normal vibrational coordinate q 2. The value of the barrier height derivative @V 3/@q 2 is estimated to be 127 ± 10cm -1. Also detected and assigned were 'hot' difference transitions belonging to the (v 4+ v 11)-2v 4 band, yielding information on the upper state v 4 + v 11. It is believed that transitions from 3v 4 to 2v 4 + v 11 are also detectable in the investigated region. {\textcopyright} 2011 Copyright Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Lattanzi, Franca and {Di Lauro}, Carlo and Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2011.614283},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {barrier to internal rotation,high resolution infrared spectra,infrared difference bands,torsional Coriolis coupling,torsional splitting,vibration-rotation Coriolis coupling},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {19},
pages = {2375--2383},
title = {{High resolution difference bands of ethane C 2H 6 from torsionally excited lower states: Rotation-torsion structure of the v 2, v 11 and v 4 + v 11 vibrational states}},
volume = {109},
year = {2011}
}

@article{08BoMoHo,
abstract = {The $
u$12 - $
u$9 difference band of ethane in the region around 385 cm-1 has been recorded with a Bruker IFS-120 HR Fourier transform spectrometer at a resolution of 0.003 cm-1 to characterize interactions between the torsional stacks of symmetric rocking mode $
u$12 with its analog motion the anti-symmetric rocking mode $
u$9. This spectrum is analyzed with data from the $
u$3 and $
u$9 fundamentals, the $
u$9 +$
u$4 - $
u$4 hot band and torsional transitions from the $
u$4, 2 $
u$4 - $
u$4, and 3 $
u$4 bands. The combined data set includes more than 4800 frequencies, and was fitted to within experimental accuracy using a 67-parameter model Hamiltonian. The first determination of molecular parameters for the $
u$12 state from a high resolution spectrum has been made. The selection rules for the $
u$12 - $
u$9 band, the development of the coupling terms between $
u$9 and $
u$12 states and the possible extension of the model to treat the bands of ethane in the 1300 to 1600 cm-1 region are discussed. {	extcopyright} 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Borvayeh, L. and Moazzen-Ahmadi, N. and Horneman, V. M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2008.04.009},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Astronomical species,Infrared spectra,Internal rotation,Vibration-torsion-rotation,Vibrational bands of ethane},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {51--56},
title = {{The $
u$12 - $
u$9 band of ethane: A global frequency analysis of data from the four lowest vibrational states}},
volume = {250},
year = {2008}
}

Journal: _Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{16MoOl,
abstract = {High quality line parameters of the band systems of ethane are required for accurate characterization of spectral features observed in the atmospheres of Jovian planets and their satellites. To date, experimental characterization of the excited vibrational states lying below 1300 cm-1 has been made. This includes the torsional bands around 35 $\mu$m, $
u$9 (820 cm-1), $
u$3 (990 cm-1), $
u$12-$
u$9 (380 cm-1) and $
u$9+$
u$4-$
u$4 (830 cm-1) bands. These earlier high resolution ro-vibrational analyses were made to experimental accuracy. Here, we report a detailed analysis of the weak $
u$6 band in the 1340-1410 cm-1 region using a spectrum recorded at a resolution of 0.003 cm-1 and temperature of 200 K. The Hamiltonian model included couplings between $
u$6 and $
u$9 (in particular with $
u$9+2$
u$4 with which it is resonantly coupled) as well as couplings between $
u$6 and $
u$8. An excellent fit to within experimental accuracy was obtained. Taking the results of this 5-state fit, together with earlier results on lower lying vibrations, we now have experimental characterization for torsion-vibration states of ethane lying below 1400 cm-1.},
author = {Moazzen-Ahmadi, N. and Oliaee, J. Norooz},

@article{16MoOl,
abstract = {High quality line parameters of the band systems of ethane are required for accurate characterization of spectral features observed in the atmospheres of Jovian planets and their satellites. To date, experimental characterization of the excited vibrational states lying below 1300 cm-1 has been made. This includes the torsional bands around 35 $\mu$m, $
u$9 (820 cm-1), $
u$3 (990 cm-1), $
u$12-$
u$9 (380 cm-1) and $
u$9+$
u$4-$
u$4 (830 cm-1) bands. These earlier high resolution ro-vibrational analyses were made to experimental accuracy. Here, we report a detailed analysis of the weak $
u$6 band in the 1340-1410 cm-1 region using a spectrum recorded at a resolution of 0.003 cm-1 and temperature of 200 K. The Hamiltonian model included couplings between $
u$6 and $
u$9 (in particular with $
u$9+2$
u$4 with which it is resonantly coupled) as well as couplings between $
u$6 and $
u$8. An excellent fit to within experimental accuracy was obtained. Taking the results of this 5-state fit, together with earlier results on lower lying vibrations, we now have experimental characterization for torsion-vibration states of ethane lying below 1400 cm-1.},

@article{11LaLaHo,
abstract = {A high resolution Fourier transform infrared spectrum of C 2H 6, measured at a pressure of 173.3Pa and an optical path of 153.2m, was analysed between 1050 and 1295cm -1. Extensive absorption due to the difference bands v 11-v 4, and several rotation-torsion lines of the difference band v 2-v 4, in the region of the x, y-Coriolis resonance of v 2 and v 11, were observed. This allowed a detailed rotation-torsion analysis of the upper states v 11 and v 2. The anomalous torsional structure, found in the non-degenerate vibrational state v 2, can be explained as the effect of an Hamiltonian term accounting for a strong dependence of the torsional barrier height on the normal vibrational coordinate q 2. The value of the barrier height derivative @V 3/@q 2 is estimated to be 127 ± 10cm -1. Also detected and assigned were 'hot' difference transitions belonging to the (v 4+ v 11)-2v 4 band, yielding information on the upper state v 4 + v 11. It is believed that transitions from 3v 4 to 2v 4 + v 11 are also detectable in the investigated region. {\textcopyright} 2011 Copyright Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Lattanzi, Franca and {Di Lauro}, Carlo and Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2011.614283},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {barrier to internal rotation,high resolution infrared spectra,infrared difference bands,torsional Coriolis coupling,torsional splitting,vibration-rotation Coriolis coupling},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {19},
pages = {2375--2383},
title = {{High resolution difference bands of ethane C 2H 6 from torsionally excited lower states: Rotation-torsion structure of the v 2, v 11 and v 4 + v 11 vibrational states}},
volume = {109},
year = {2011}
}

@article{11LaLaVa,
abstract = {The Fourier transform infrared spectrum of ethane between 2860 and 3060 cm-1 has been re-investigated under high resolution at 229 K. The infrared absorption in this region is due mainly to the CH stretching fundamentals $
u$5 (parallel band) and $
u$7 (degenerate perpendicular band), and to the parallel combination system $
u$8 + $
u$11 (A4s, A3s). All the relevant perturbation mechanisms affecting the observed absorption patterns have been clarified. In particular, the main perturbers of the $
u$7 state are identified to be the degenerate vibrational combination states $
u$8 + $
u$11 (l-type interaction) and $
u$3 + 2$
u$4 + $
u$8 (Fermi-type interaction). Because of the last interaction, the K_$\Delta$K = -6 transitions occur with intensities comparable to both the infrared active fundamental $
u$7 and the almost dark combination $
u$3 + 2$
u$4 + $
u$8. The parallel combination system $
u$8 + $
u$11 (A 4s, A3s) is overlapped and heavily perturbed by the nearby parallel system $
u$4 + $
u$11 + $
u$12 (A4s, A3s), whose K-structure is spread by the strong z-Coriolis interaction of its two vibrational components. In this work, 95 new transitions to the perturbers of $
u$7 have been assigned. They belong mostly to the degenerate vibrational states $
u$8 + $
u$11 (E1d) and $
u$3 + 2$
u$4 + $
u$8 (E1d), and to the parallel system $
u$8 + $
u$11 (A4s, A3s). A least squares fit calculation, limited to the $
u$7 degenerate fundamental and its degenerate perturbers $
u$8 + $
u$11, $
u$3 + 2$
u$4 + $
u$8, $
u$4 + $
u$11 + $
u$12, and $
u$3 + 3$
u$4 + $
u$12 was performed. From the results of this fit, we created a line-by-line database containing the molecular parameters for 4969 transitions in these five bands of 12C2H6. Finally, we identified the degenerate combination band $
u$2 + $
u$8 (62 observed transitions) to be the main perturber (x, y-Coriolis-type interaction) of the parallel fundamental $
u$5. {	extcopyright} 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Lattanzi, F. and {Di Lauro}, C. and {Vander Auwera}, J.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2011.02.003},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Ethane,High resolution infrared spectra,Internal rotation,Planetary atmospheres,Titan,Vibration-rotation interactions},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1-2},
pages = {71--79},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{Toward the understanding of the high resolution infrared spectrum of C 2H6 near 3.3 $\mu$m}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2011.02.003},
volume = {267},
year = {2011}
}

@article{87HeFaKn,
abstract = {The vibrational Raman Stokes spectrum of ethan (C2H6) has been recorded from 600 to 6500 cm_1 using the powerful focused radiation of a free running Ar-ion laser. Measurements in bulk and in jet were performed in an intracavity arrangement. The present analysis is concentrated on totally, symmetric transitions. Numerous Q branches of overtones and binary combination tones appeared in the spectrum. All first overtones of both the degenerate and non-degenerate modes have been observed. Several multiple combination tones have also been identified. Some hot bands due to transitions starting from the thermally excited v4 torsional level appeared as satellite Q branches. From the measured band origins the anharmonic shifts are determined and a table with the anharmonicity constants is constructed. The occurrence of a few very strong Fermi resonances enhancing the intensity of otherwise weak bands has been observed. A comparative study of some overtone Raman spectra of three substituted ethanes (CH3single bondCF3, CH3, CH3single bondSiH3, CH3single bondCD3) has been undertaken. The existence of a strong interaction between the CH3 symmetric stretching modes and the overtones of the asymmetric deformation modes appears to be characteristic only for the CH3CH3 and CH3CD3 molecules.},
author = {Helvoort, Van K. and Fantoni, R. and Knippers, W. and Stolte, S.},
journal = {Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {445--465},
title = {{The Raman spectrum of ethane from 600 to 6500 cm_1 stokes shifts}},
volume = {111},
year = {1987}
}

@article{16KuWeWa,
abstract = {We recorded the $\nu$7 fundamental band of dimethyl-ether around 400 cm_1 for the normal and 13C-enriched isotopologues using the Fourier transform spectrometer at the SOLEIL Synchrotron facility. For all three species P, Q and R branch-transitions up to J=20 and Ka=5 were assigned and the band origins and rotational parameters of Watson's A-reduced Hamiltonian have been determined by the least-squares fitting procedure. The line splitting due to the torsional tunneling is observed for low J transitions, which is attributed to the ro-vibrational interaction with the excited torsional states.},
author = {Kutzer, P. and Weismann, D. and Wa{\ss}muth, B. and Pirali, O. and Roy, P. and Yamada, K. M.T. and Giesen, T. F.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2016.08.008},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Dimethyl-ether,Far-infrared spectroscopy,Isotopologue,Laboratory astrophysics,Large amplitude motion},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {28--34},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{Far-infrared spectra of dimethyl-ether and its 13C enriched isotopologues: The fundamental band of the CÐOÐC in plane bending mode, $\nu$7}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2016.08.008},
volume = {329},
year = {2016}
}

@article{12CoCaCh,
abstract = {The v6, v17, and v21 fundamental bands of dimethyl ether have been assigned and rotationally analyzed. The spectra used were recorded at 0.005 cm_1 spectral resolution with a Fourier-transform spectrometer coupled to a supersonic molecular beam leading to a rotational temperature of about 70 K. The v6 and v21 bands do not seem to be perturbed and the analysis of the rotational structure leads to band centers located at 933.906 6(9) and 1 103.951(1) cm_1, respectively, and to accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants. For the v17 band at 2817.385(2) cm_1, only the P and R branches could be assigned. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Coudert, L. H. and {\c{C}}ar{\c{c}}abal, P. and Chevalier, M. and Broquier, M. and Hepp, M. and Herman, M.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8541},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Dimethyl ether,Infrared,Jet-cooled FT spectroscopy,Large amplitude motion,Rotational analysis,Spectrum,Tunneling splitting},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {203--207},
title = {{High-resolution analysis of the v6, v17, and v21 bands of dimethyl ether}},
volume = {212},
year = {2002}
}

@article{12CoCaCh,
abstract = {The v6, v17, and v21 fundamental bands of dimethyl ether have been assigned and rotationally analyzed. The v6 and v21 bands do not seem to be perturbed and the analysis of the rotational structure leads to band centers located at 933.906 6(9) and 1 103.951(1) cm_1, respectively, and to accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants. _@article{64PeFoJo,
abstract = {Les spectres infrarouges des compos{\'{e}}s CH3OCH3 et CH3OCD3, {\`{a}} l'{\'{e}}tat gazeux et en solution dans CCl4, enregistr{\'{e}}s entre 650 et 3 000 cmÐ1, ont {\'{e}}t{\'{e}} interpr{\'{e}}t{\'{e}}s essentiellement {\`{a}} partir de la structure des bandes de vibration-rotation. On en d{\'{e}}duit pour la barri{\`{e}}re de potentiel s'opposant {\`{a}} la rotation du groupement m{\'{e}}thyle la valeur de 2,84 ± 0,12 kcal./mol.},
author = {Perchard, Jean-Pierre and Forel, Marie-Th{\'{e}}r{\`{e}}se and Josien, Marie-Louise},
doi = {10.1051/jcp/1964610632},

pages = {632--644},
publisher = {EDP Sciences},
title = {{{\'{E}}tude par spectroscopie infrarouge de quelques mol{\'{e}}cules gem-dym{\'{e}}thyl{\'{e}}es}},
url = {https://jcp.edpsciences.org/articles/jcp/abs/1964/01/jcp196461p632/jcp196461p632.html},
volume = {61},
year = {1964}
}

@article{12CoCaCh,
abstract = {The v6, v17, and v21 fundamental bands of dimethyl ether have been assigned and rotationally analyzed. The spectra used were recorded at 0.005 cm_1 spectral resolution with a Fourier-transform spectrometer coupled to a supersonic molecular beam leading to a rotational temperature of about 70 K. The v6 and v21 bands do not seem to be perturbed and the analysis of the rotational structure leads to band centers located at 933.906 6(9) and 1 103.951(1) cm_1, respectively, and to accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants. For the v17 band at 2817.385(2) cm_1, only the P and R branches could be assigned. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Coudert, L. H. and {\c{C}}ar{\c{c}}abal, P. and Chevalier, M. and Broquier, M. and Hepp, M. and Herman, M.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8541},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Dimethyl ether,Infrared,Jet-cooled FT spectroscopy,Large amplitude motion,Rotational analysis,Spectrum,Tunneling splitting},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {203--207},
title = {{High-resolution analysis of the v6, v17, and v21 bands of dimethyl ether}},
volume = {212},
year = {2002}
}

@article{98GoFr,
abstract = {The fundamental IR vibrational modes of CHF2OCF3 (E125), CHF2OCHF2 (E134), and CH3OCF3 (E143a) have been examined by ab initio molecular orbital calculations and have been compared with FT-IR measurements. A complete assignment of all fundamental vibrational modes has been made for each fluorinated ether. As a calibration for the fluorinated ethers, the fundamental IR vibrational modes of dimethyl ether have been reexamined by ab initio methods and have been compared with literature assignments.},
author = {Good, D. A. and Francisco, J. S.},
doi = {10.1021/jp980048n},
issn = {10895639},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {10},
pages = {1854--1864},
title = {{Structure and vibrational spectra of chlorofluorocarbon substitutes: An experimental and ab initio study of fluorinated ethers CHF2OCF3 (E125), CHF2OCHF2 (E134), and CH3OCF3 (E143A)}},
volume = {102},
year = {1998}
}

@article{18JaBeBe,
abstract = {The rovibrational spectrum of the v14 CH3-bending mode of dimethyl sulfide CH3SCH3 was recorded in the 945Ð1005 cm_1 spectral region combining data from a tunable infrared quantum cascade laser spectrometer coupled to a pulsed slit jet and from a high resolution Fourier transform spectrometer coupled to a room temperature gas absorption cell. The characteristic PQR band contour of a vibrational mode with a b1 symmetry species in the C2v group was observed with both infrared methods but the rovibrational cooling achieved in the pulsed supersonic expansion (20 K in rotation) proved to be essential for starting the rovibrational analysis of such asymmetric top molecule. Internal rotation splittings were recently observed and analyzed in the ground and first torsional excited states. However, they are expected to be very small and could not be resolved in the v14 state using our infrared spectroscopic probes. Therefore a classic reduced effective Hamiltonian of an asymmetric rigid rotor was used. Finally, 1119 transitions from both jet-cooled and room temperature experiments were assigned and included in a global fit with J ² 29. A total of 9 rovibrational parameters including pure rotational constants as well as quartic centrifugal distortion constants were determined with high accuracy. These parameters can be used to produce a reliable line-list for an atmospheric detection of DMS.},
author = {Jabri, Atef and Belkhodja, Yacine and Berger, Yann and Kleiner, Isabelle and Asselin, Pierre},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2018.03.012},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Fourier transform IR spectroscopy,Quantum cascade laser,Rovibrational spectroscopy,Supersonic pulsed jet},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jul},
pages = {32--36},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High resolution rovibrational analysis of dimethyl sulfide spectrum in the 10 µm atmospheric window combining supersonic jet-quantum cascade laser and FTIR spectroscopies}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022285218300687},
volume = {349},
year = {2018}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{94ElStGe,
abstract = {The structure and electric dipole moment of dimethyl sulphide have been calculated with a variety of basis sets. It is shown that the force fields computed with the 3-21G, 3-21G and 6-311G** bases are very similar after scaling. The vibrational assignments are discussed. The force field is compared with that of trimethyl phosphine. There is an excellent accord for the CH stretching modes, but the ab initio calculations indicate that the X-C/X-C (X = S,P) interaction terms have opposite signs. This appears to be incompatible with the experimental data. Effective atomic charges and atomic polar tensors (APT) are computed with the above bases and also with bond centred sp functions added to the 3-21G* basis. It is shown that the APT are much more sensitive to the basis set than are the effective atomic charges. The effects of the lone pair electrons on the bond electrical properties are much less than with oxy-ethers, though the overall perturbation of the sulphur atom on the intensities is greater. A number of inadequacies of the SCF calculations are identified. {\textcopyright} 1994.},
author = {Ellwood, Josephine A. and Steele, Derek and Gerrard, Donald},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(94)80140-1},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {5},
pages = {913--928},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Vibrational absorption intensities in chemical analysisÑVIII. Dimethyl sulphide}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0584853994801401},
volume = {50},
year = {1994}
}

@article{02NeNiVa,
abstract = {High-resolution vibration-rotation spectra of monochloroacetylene (HCCCl) have been recorded in two different wavenumber regions. Fourier transform infrared interferometer measurements in the 4000-10000 cm-1 range have been performed with a resolution of 0.005-0.016 cm-1 and titanium:sapphire ring laser intracavity photoacoustic measurements in the 12500-12600 cm-1 and 12800-12860 cm-1 regions have been carried out with a Doppler-limited resolution of about 0.02 cm-1. Altogether, 40 vibrational bands belonging to the HCC35Cl and 15 bands belonging to the HCC37Cl isotopic species have been rotationally assigned. A vibrational model, based on the conventional rectilinear normal coordinate theory including anharmonic Fermi, Darling-Dennison and vibrational l-type doubling resonances, has been used to attach vibrational labels to the bands. This approach is found to describe well the rovibrational energy level structure at least in the energy range covered in this work. The model shows that the CH oscillator becomes decoupled from the rest of the molecule as vibrational energy increases.},
author = {Nela, Maria and Niskanen, Kirsi and Vaittinen, Olavi and Halonen, Lauri and B{\"{u}}rger, Hans and Polanz, Oliver},
doi = {10.1080/00268970110101932},
isbn = {1250012600},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {5},
pages = {655--665},
title = {{High-resolution infrared and laser photoacoustic spectroscopy of monochloroacetylene}},
volume = {100},
year = {2002}
}

@article{02HoRuWe,
abstract = {High-resolution infrared spectra of the v2 band system of monochloroacetylene (chloroethyne, HCCCl) have been recorded in the wavenumber region 2066-2133 cm-1 using a tunable diode laser with an effective coverage > 70%. Despite the presence of the two chlorine isotopes and several hot bands, over 1000 vibration-rotation lines could be assigned. Rotational constants, bandcenters, and vibration-rotation constants were derived for the v2 fundamental and three hot bands for each chlorine isotopomer. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Hore, Nathan R. and Russell, Douglas K. and Wesendrup, Ralf},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8562},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {153--157},
title = {{High-resolution tunable diode laser study of the v2 band system of monochloroacetylene}},
volume = {213},
year = {2002}
}

@article{92HoNeMi,
abstract = {High-resolution vibration-rotation spectra of monofluoroacetylene are reported for many bands in the region 1700 to 7500 cm-1. The spectra were observed on Nicolet 7199 and Bruker IFS 120 Fourier spectrometers, with resolutions of about 0.06 and 0.003 cm-1, respectively. About 130 bands have been observed in this region, of which about 80 have been rotationally analyzed. The assignment of vibrational labels to the higher energy levels is complicated by the effects of strong Fermi resonances, and many weak localized rotational resonances are observed. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {Holland, J. K. and Newnham, D. A. and Mills, I. M. and Herman, M.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(92)90571-5},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {346--368},
title = {{Vibration-rotation spectra of monofluoroacetylene: 1700 to 7500 cm-1}},
volume = {151},
year = {1992}
}

@article{11Ma,
abstract = {The high-resolution spectrum of cyanogen (14N12C 12C14N) has been measured from 500 to 4900 cm -1. For this isotopomer many combination levels with both degenerate fundamentals, $\nu$4 and $\nu$5, have been measured for the first time and the effects of vibrational l-type resonance are observed as well as rotational l-type resonance. The effects of the vibrational resonance coupling $\nu$2 and 2$\nu$4 have also been studied. The data have been combined with earlier measurements below 500 cm-1 to give a comprehensive catalog of the vibrational energy levels and the rovibrational constants for the normal isotopomer of cyanogen. A comparison of the term value constants for the three major symmetric isotopomers is given and they are compared with a recent ab initio calculation. The present data were combined with earlier work on the two symmetric isotopomers, 13C 214N2 and 12C215N2, to obtain the equilibrium bond lengths, r CC = 138.109(60) pm and rCN = 115.976(40) pm. {\textcopyright} 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Maki, Arthur G.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2011.06.002},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Bond distances,Cyanogen,High-resolution infrared spectrum,NCCN,Rotational constants,Vibrational constants},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {166--174},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution infrared spectrum of cyanogen}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2011.06.002},
volume = {269},
year = {2011}
}

publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution infrared spectrum of cyanogen}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2011.06.002},
volume = {269},
year = {2011}
}

@article{11Ma,
abstract = {The high-resolution spectrum of cyanogen (14N12C 12C14N) has been measured from 500 to 4900 cm -1. For this isotopomer many combination levels with both degenerate fundamentals, $\nu$4 and $\nu$5, have been measured for the first time and the effects of vibrational l-type resonance are observed as well as rotational l-type resonance. The effects of the vibrational resonance coupling $\nu$2 and 2$\nu$4 have also been studied. The data have been combined with earlier measurements below 500 cm-1 to give a comprehensive catalog of the vibrational energy levels and the rovibrational constants for the normal isotopomer of cyanogen. A comparison of the term value constants for the three major symmetric isotopomers is given and they are compared with a recent ab initio calculation. The present data were combined with earlier work on the two symmetric isotopomers, 13C 214N2 and 12C215N2, to obtain the equilibrium bond lengths, r CC = 138.109(60) pm and rCN = 115.976(40) pm. {\textcopyright} 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Maki, Arthur G.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2011.06.002},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Bond distances,Cyanogen,High-resolution infrared spectrum,NCCN,Rotational constants,Vibrational constants},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {166--174},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution infrared spectrum of cyanogen}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2011.06.002},
volume = {269},
year = {2011}
}
