@article{15KiMaPi,
abstract = {Abstract The high resolution Fourier-transform spectrum of acrylonitrile covering the 40-700 cm-1 spectral region was recorded at the AILES infrared beamline of the SOLEIL synchrotron. The spectrum allowed assignment of vibration-rotation transitions in four different fundamental bands, five hot bands, one overtone band, as well as of some pure rotational transitions. The new infrared data and previous measurements made with microwave techniques have been combined into a single global fit encompassing over 31 000 measured transitions. Precise vibrational term values have been determined for the eight lowest excited vibrational states, including V11 = 228.299930(4), V15 = 332.678207(4), V10 = 560.716701(5), and V14=681.793862(13) cm-1. The new values are compared with those obtained previously entirely on the basis of rotational perturbations. Several anharmonicity coefficients are determined and compared with abinitio anharmonic force field calculations. The assignment of the V10 mode is also clarified.},
author = {Kisiel, Zbigniew and Martin-Drumel, Marie Aline and Pirali, Olivier},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2015.03.003},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Excited vibrational states,Global analysis,Infrared spectrum,Interstate perturbations,Synchrotron radiation,THz spectrum},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
pages = {83--91},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Lowest vibrational states of acrylonitrile from microwave and synchrotron radiation spectra}},
volume = {315},
year = {2015}
}

@article{99KhNoPa,
abstract = {Laboratory spectral data (peak positions and integrated band intensities) of the infrared bands of acrylonitrile (CH2CHCN) gas in the region 4000-220 cm-1are presented. Even though CH2CHCN has not yet been identified in Titan's atmosphere, it is among the possible photochemical and cosmic irradiation products of CH4+ N2chemistry in the atmosphere of Titan. Laboratory simulations of Titan's atmospheric chemistry also give CH2CHCN as a product species. The results of our evaluation of the infrared intensity data provide an upper limit of the stratospheric abundance of CH2CHCN. {\textcopyright} 1999 Academic Press.},
author = {Khlifi, M. and Nollet, M. and Paillous, P. and Bruston, P. and Raulin, F. and B{\'{e}}nilan, Y. and Khanna, R. K.},
doi = {10.1006/JMSP.1998.7795},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {2},
pages = {206--210},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Absolute Intensities of the Infrared Bands of Gaseous Acrylonitrile}},
volume = {194},
year = {1999}
}

@article{02NiHeJo,
abstract = {The high-resolution infrared spectrum of allene has been observed in the 280-380 cm-1 region at a nominal resolution of 0.00125 cm-1 using the IR beamline at the MAX-I electron storage ring in Lund. The spectrum shows the bending fundamental of the $\nu$11 band from which spectroscopic constants for the $\nu$11 level have been obtained. The accompanying hot band component 2$\nu$112-$\nu$111 has also been assigned and analyzed. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Nissen, S. and Hegelund, F. and Johnson, M. S. and Nelander, B.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8596},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Allene,High-resolution infrared spectroscopy,Molecular constants},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {197--202},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution infrared study of the $\nu$11 band of allene}},
volume = {216},
year = {2002}
}

@article{02NiHeJo,
abstract = {The high-resolution infrared spectrum of allene has been observed in the 280-380 cm-1 region at a nominal resolution of 0.00125 cm-1 using the IR beamline at the MAX-I electron storage ring in Lund. @article{14EsJoBe,
abstract = {Allene (a-C3H4; CH2CCH2) and propyne (p-C3H4; CH3C2H) have attracted much interest because of their relevance to the photochemistry in astrophysical environments as well as in combustion processes. Both allene and propyne have strong absorption in the infrared region. In the present work, infrared spectra of a-C3H4 and p-C3H4 are measured in the gas phase at temperatures ranging from 296 to 510 K. The spectra are measured over the 580-3400 cm-1 spectral region at resolutions of 0.08 and 0.25 cm-1 using Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy. Absolute integrated intensities of the main infrared bands are determined at room temperature and compared with values derived from literature for both molecules. Integrated band intensities are also determined as a function of temperature in various spectral regions.},
author = {Es-Sebbar, Et and Jolly, A. and Benilan, Y. and Farooq, A.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.004},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},

@article{14EsJoBe,
abstract = {Allene (a-C3H4; CH2CCH2) and propyne (p-C3H4; CH3C2H) have attracted much interest because of their relevance to the photochemistry in astrophysical environments as well as in combustion processes. Both allene and propyne have strong absorption in the infrared region. In the present work, infrared spectra of a-C3H4 and p-C3H4 are measured in the gas phase at temperatures ranging from 296 to 510 K. The spectra are measured over the 580-3400 cm-1 spectral region at resolutions of 0.08 and 0.25 cm-1 using Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy. Absolute integrated intensities of the main infrared bands are determined at room temperature and compared with values derived from literature for both molecules. Integrated band intensities are also determined as a function of temperature in various spectral regions.},
author = {Es-Sebbar, Et and Jolly, A. and Benilan, Y. and Farooq, A.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.004},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},

pages = {10--16},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{Quantitative mid-infrared spectra of allene and propyne from room to high temperatures}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.004},
volume = {305},
year = {2014}
}

@article{86OhYaKu,
abstract = {An infrared absorption spectrum of allene in the 7.2-$\mu$m region was measured by a tunable diode laser. The main band, $\nu$7(B2), is found to be coupled with the $\nu$9 + $\nu$11(l = ±2) bands by a strong Fermi interaction, and the l = ±2 components of $\nu$9 + $\nu$11 are perturbed by l resonance with the l = 0 components. In addition, a local Fermi resonance with the 4$\nu$11(l = 2) state is observed. A simultaneous analysis considering these interactions explicitly is carried out, and the unperturbed molecular constants are determined as follows: $\nu$0($\nu$7) = 1394.1839(6) cm-1, $\nu$0($\nu$9 + $\nu$11, l = ±2) = 1354.0611(5) cm-1, and |W7,9,11| = 4.8535(4) cm-1. {\textcopyright} 1986.},
author = {Ohshima, Yasuhiro and Yamamoto, Satoshi and Kuchitsu, Kozo and Nakanaga, Taisuke and Takeo, Harutoshi and Matsumura, Chi},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(86)90098-6},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {1},
pages = {138--151},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Diode laser spectrum of the $\nu$7 $\nu$9 + $\nu$11 band system of allene}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022285286900986},
volume = {117},
year = {1986}
}

@article{82PlMa,
abstract = {The infrared bands of allene between 1920 and 2028 cm-1 were measured on a large grating spectrometer with effective resolution of 0.006-0.007 cm-1 after deconvolution. The main band in this region is the antisymmetric CC stretching fundamental $\nu$6 of symmetry B2, accompanied on the high-frequency side by the overtone band 2$\nu$9 of the degenerate CH2 rocking vibration. The overtone has three components of species B2, B1, and A1, of which B2 is in Fermi resonance with $\nu$6, B1 has second-order Coriolis interaction with $\nu$6, while A1 is in l-type interaction with the B1 and B2 components. Additional perturbations by other unobserved states were detected in the spectrum. The observed transitions were analyzed with the aid of a general computer program system SYMTOP designed for analysis of symmetric-top spectra. The main program effects a least-squares refinement of the spectroscopic constants for a set of bands whose upper states interact through arbitrary matrix elements. Two sets of spectroscopic constants for the $\nu$6, 2$\nu$9 states were calculated. One, based only on those lines which appear to be unperturbed by unknown and unobserved states, and a second, obtained after inclusion in the H matrix of two perturbing states designed to simulate the effect of the perturbations on all of the data. Comparison indicates that the lower-order constants based merely on the "unperturbed" data are quite satisfactory. Molecular constants for the $\nu$9 vibration of C3H4 are reported. {\textcopyright} 1982.},
author = {Pl{\'{i}}va, J. and Martin, C. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(82)90041-8},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {218--237},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The spectrum of allene near 5 $\mu$m}},
volume = {91},
year = {1982}
}

@article{85MaPiDa,
abstract = {A difference-frequency laser spectrometer has been used to measure the infrared absorption spectrum of the $\nu$5 and $\nu$8 bands of allene (C3H4). In addition, the A1A2-E and B1B2-E components of the $\nu$8 + $\nu$11 - $\nu$11 hot band have been measured and analyzed. For the $\nu$8 and $\nu$11 states both the _k, l k ± 2, l ± 2_ and _k, l k ± 2, l _ 2_ splittings have been observed. For the $\nu$8 + $\nu$11 state the A1A2 and B1B2 interactions have been observed. Many weak perturbations have been found in the $\nu$5 and $\nu$8 bands. Recognition that a perturbation in the $\nu$5 band shares intensity between two QQ4 subband features has led to a reassignment of the K > 3 subbands of $\nu$5. The intensities of lines in both $\nu$5 and $\nu$8 have been measured and the least perturbed transitions have been fit to obtain intensity parameters for both bands. {\textcopyright} 1985.},
author = {Maki, Arthur G. and Pine, Alan S. and Dang-Nhu, M.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(85)90176-6},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {2},
pages = {459--481},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{A Doppler-limited study of the infrared spectrum of allene from 2965 to 3114 cm_1}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022285285901766},
volume = {112},
year = {1985}
}

@article{85HeTh,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of propyne (methyl acetylene) between 1300 and 1620 cm-1 has been reanalyzed at a resolution of 0.006 cm-1. The main Fermi and Coriolis interactions of the $\nu$7±1 band have been identified, as has the Fermi interaction between ($\nu$8 + $\nu$10)0 and $\nu$40. Reassignment of a subband shows that $\nu$40 has a very small transition moment. Thirty-eight molecular parameters for the interacting excited vibrational levels were determined by a least-squares analysis of 1550 lines. {\textcopyright} 1985.},
author = {Henfrey, N. F. and Thrush, B. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(85)90280-2},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {2},
pages = {426--450},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{A high-resolution study of the $\nu$7 band of propyne}},
volume = {113},
year = {1985}
}

@article{94KeLePa,
abstract = {We present the high resolution spectrum of the $\nu$1 fundamental of propyne near 3335 cm-1 obtained using a very warm free jet expansion in our optothermal detection spectrometer. By using a high concentration sample expanded at low backing pressures we have been able to observe transitions for K values up to K = 6. The additional data available allow us to reinvestigate this vibrational band. We find an unusual perturbation pattern in this band where the individual subbands (rovibrational transitions for a single K value) appear to be completely unperturbed at the level of precision of our data (7.5 MHz), but the subband origin orderings are perturbed through nonresonant interactions. Attempts to account for the subband ordering using a two-state anharmonic interaction are unsuccessful indicating that the perturbations are of multistate origin. This type of nonresonant perturbation to the subband origins of symmetric top molecules should be a common feature of symmetric tops with large A rotational constants. As a result of this investigation we conclude that the previously reported value of $\alpha$A, determined from a very cold expansion where only K = 0 and K = 1 were observed, is not a measure of the true (unperturbed) value of this constant. This conclusion is also supported by force field calculations presented here that use an empirical harmonic force field augmented by diagonal anharmonicities for the hydride stretches. These calculations, which reproduce measured values of $\alpha$A and $\alpha$B for lower energy bands quite successfully, also show that the previous determination of $\alpha$A is too large and must be dominated by perturbation contributions. We have also measured the weak Fermi resonant band $\nu$3+2$\nu$90 which acquires its intensity through interaction with $\nu$1. Again we find an anomalous subband ordering like that observed in $\nu$1. {\textcopyright} 1994 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Kerstel, E. R.Th and Lehmann, Kevin K. and Pate, Brooks H. and Scoles, G.},
doi = {10.1063/1.466455},
file = {::},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {ACETYLENE,DISTURBANCES,DOPPLER EFFECT,ENERGY-LEVEL TRANSITIONS,EXPANSION,HIGH-RESOLUTION METHODS,INFRARED SPECTRA,JETS,PHOTOTHERMAL SPECTROSCOPY,PROPYNE,RESONANCE,THERMO-OPTICAL EFFECTS,VIBRATIONAL STATES},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {4},
pages = {2588--2595},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Reinvestigation of the acetylenic C-H stretching fundamental of propyne via high resolution, optothermal infrared spectroscopy: Nonresonant perturbations to $\nu$1}},
url = {http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.466455},
volume = {100},
year = {1994}
}

@article{09PrMuUr,
abstract = {The study of vibration resonance physics in propyne is based on experimental measurements of about 600 new rotational transitions between 495-590 and 700-760 GHz in excited vibrational levels v5 = 1, v8 = 1, v10 = 3 and v9 = v10 = 1 with vibrational energies around 1000 cm-1. The limits to the assignments and analysis were imposed by as yet unresolved anharmonic resonances with the states of the next higher polyad of levels lying above 1200 cm-1, which affect the rotational states involved in transitions that would be measurable with non-vanishing intensities. Vibration-rotation spectra pertaining to the levels in question were studied in the regions 880-1150 cm-1 (the $\nu$5 and $\nu$8 fundamental bands), 550-750 cm-1 (the v9 = v10 = 1 _ v10 = 1 hot bands) and 250-400 cm-1 (the v10 = 3 _ v10 = 2 "superhot" bands). A simultaneous least-squares fit of both types of data provides their reliable but in the case of accurate rotational data not always fully quantitative reproduction. {\textcopyright} 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Pracna, P. and M{\"{u}}ller, H. S.P. and Urban, {\v{S}} and Horneman, V. M. and Klee, S.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2009.04.003},
file = {::},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {FTIR spectroscopy,High resolution,Methylacetylene,Submillemeter-wave spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {1},
pages = {152--162},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Interactions between vibrational polyads of propyne, H3C{single bond}C{triple bond, long}CH: Rotational and rovibrational spectroscopy of the levels around 1000 cm-1}},
volume = {256},
year = {2009}
}

keywords = {FTIR spectroscopy,High resolution,Methylacetylene,Submillemeter-wave spectroscopy},

pages = {152--162},

title = {{Interactions between vibrational polyads of propyne, H3C{single bond}C{triple bond, long}CH: Rotational and rovibrational spectroscopy of the levels around 1000 cm-1}},
volume = {256},
year = {2009}
}

@article{09PrMuUr,
abstract = {The study of vibration resonance physics in propyne is based on experimental measurements of about 600 new rotational transitions between 495-590 and 700-760 GHz in excited vibrational levels v5 = 1, v8 = 1, v10 = 3 and v9 = v10 = 1 with vibrational energies around 1000 cm-1. The limits to the assignments and analysis were imposed by as yet unresolved anharmonic resonances with the states of the next higher polyad of levels lying above 1200 cm-1, which affect the rotational states involved in transitions that would be measurable with non-vanishing intensities. Vibration-rotation spectra pertaining to the levels in question were studied in the regions 880-1150 cm-1 (the $\nu$5 and $\nu$8 fundamental bands), 550-750 cm-1 (the v9 = v10 = 1 _ v10 = 1 hot bands) and 250-400 cm-1 (the v10 = 3 _ v10 = 2 "superhot" bands). A simultaneous least-squares fit of both types of data provides their reliable but in the case of accurate rotational data not always fully quantitative reproduction. {\textcopyright} 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Pracna, P. and M{\"{u}}ller, H. S.P. and Urban, {\v{S}} and Horneman, V. M. and Klee, S.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2009.04.003},
file = {::},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {FTIR spectroscopy,High resolution,Methylacetylene,Submillemeter-wave spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {1},
pages = {152--162},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Interactions between vibrational polyads of propyne, H3C{single bond}C{triple bond, long}CH: Rotational and rovibrational spectroscopy of the levels around 1000 cm-1}},
volume = {256},
year = {2009}
}

@article{87HeTh,
abstract = {The $\nu$3 and 2$\nu$80 parallel bands of propyne (methyl acetylene) at 2137.88 and 2066.33 cm-1 have been studied at 0.006 cm-1 resolution. Their Fermi resonance and interaction with the $\nu$8 + 2$\nu$9, $\nu$7 + $\nu$9, and $\nu$8 + $\nu$9 + $\nu$10 levels have been investigated. Molecular constants were determined from the assignment of 1150 lines. However, the rms error of 0.0028 cm-1 showed the presence of additional perturbations which cannot be uniquely identified. {\textcopyright} 1987.},
author = {Henfrey, N. F. and Thrush, B. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(87)90178-0},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {150--166},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{A high-resolution study of the $\nu$3 and 2$\nu$80 bands of propyne}},
volume = {121},
year = {1987}
}

@article{14EsJoBe,
abstract = {Allene (a-C3H4; CH2CCH2) and propyne (p-C3H4; CH3C2H) have attracted much interest because of their relevance to the photochemistry in astrophysical environments as well as in combustion processes. Both allene and propyne have strong absorption in the infrared region. In the present work, infrared spectra of a-C3H4 and p-C3H4 are measured in the gas phase at temperatures ranging from 296 to 510 K. The spectra are measured over the 580-3400 cm-1 spectral region at resolutions of 0.08 and 0.25 cm-1 using Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy. Absolute integrated intensities of the main infrared bands are determined at room temperature and compared with values derived from literature for both molecules. Integrated band intensities are also determined as a function of temperature in various spectral regions.},
author = {Es-Sebbar, Et and Jolly, A. and Benilan, Y. and Farooq, A.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.004},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Allene,FTIR,Infrared absorption cross-section,Integrated intensities,Propyne},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {10--16},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{Quantitative mid-infrared spectra of allene and propyne from room to high temperatures}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.004},
volume = {305},
year = {2014}
}

@article{93GoCrPe,
abstract = {An infrared-infrared double resonance technique for the study of jet-cooled polyatomics is reported which offers state-selection, access to one-photon-forbidden vibrations, sub-Doppler resolution, and high sensitivity. It has been applied to the propyne $
u$6, $
u$1 + $
u$6, and 2$
u$1 bands. Several different manifestations of incipient IVR were observed in these bands: (i) scattered non-resonant perturbations in the $
u$6 band, (ii) in addition to this, the appearance of individual perturbers as spectral features in the $
u$1 + $
u$6 band and (iii) clumps of molecular eigenstates in the 2$
u$1 band. The qualitative behavior, multiple perturbing states and indications of z-axis Coriolis interactions, is consistent for the three bands. The extent of mixing increases monotonically with vibrational energy. For the 2$
u$1 band, a predicted doorway state was explicitly observed, and the interactions were treated in the context of a two-stage coupling mechanism. For the $
u$6 and $
u$1 + $
u$6 bands, the upper states were fit to a distortable rotor Hamiltonian and the following constants are reported: $
u$0 = 2980.8522(9) cm-1, A = 5.2969(8) cm-1, B=0.285039(12) cm-1, $\zeta$=0.07250(16), for the $
u$6 band, and $
u$0=6315.7998(9) cm-1, A=5.2915(8) cm-1, B=0.284379(10) cm-1, $\zeta$=0.07158(16), for the $
u$1 + $
u$6 band. {	extcopyright} 1993.},
author = {Go, Jungsug and Cronin, T. J. and Perry, David S.},
doi = {10.1016/0301-0104(93)80233-Y},
issn = {03010104},
journal = {Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {1},
pages = {127--145},
publisher = {North-Holland},
title = {{A free-jet infrared double resonance study of the threshold region of IVR. The $
u$6, $
u$1 + $
u$6, and 2$
u$1 bands of propyne}},
volume = {175},
year = {1993}
}

@article{07mCtOaP,
abstract = {The $
u$18 fundamental band (_158 cm-1) of acrolein is studied at high resolution (0.0015 cm-1) using synchrotron radiation from the Canadian Light Source facility and a Bruker IFS 125HR Fourier transform spectrometer. By fitting this band, together with some pure rotational transitions, molecular parameters are obtained to accurately determine the energies of the $
u$18 = 1 state levels for values of (J, Ka) up to at least (45, 24). These parameters should be useful for future high resolution studies of acrolein hot bands. This is demonstrated here by a detailed analysis of the ($
u$17 + $
u$18) - $
u$18 hot band at _589 cm-1. The upper state ($
u$17 + $
u$18) of this band is found to be perturbed by Coriolis interactions analogous to those affecting the $
u$17 state. {	extcopyright} 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Tokaryk, D. W. and Appadoo, D. R.T.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2007.06.001},journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Acrolein,Coriolis,Hot band,Infrared,Propenal,Synchrotron},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {146--152},
title = {{The far-infrared spectrum of acrolein, CH2CHCHO: The $
u$18 fundamental and ($
u$17 + $
u$18) - $
u$18 hot bands}},
volume = {244},
year = {2007}
}

@article{08McAp,
abstract = {The far-infrared spectrum of acrolein, CH2CHCHO, is studied in the 100-360 cm-1 region using continuum radiation from a synchrotron source. The combination of a very high resolution spectrometer, a long absorption path, and a low sample pressure, yields observed line widths of less than 0.0008 cm-1. Observation of the $\nu$18 (157.9 cm-1), and $\nu$13 (323.8 cm-1) fundamental bands, together with six hot bands in the same regions, gives information on eight low-lying vibrational states of the molecule, including the Fermi and Coriolis interactions among them. Combining the present assignments with previous data on the $\nu$12 (564.34 cm-1) and $\nu$17 (593.08 cm-1) fundamental bands, all ten excited vibrational levels below 700 cm-1 are analyzed in terms of one 1-state fit, two 2-state fits, and one 5-state fit. {\textcopyright} 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Appadoo, D. R.T.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2008.05.003},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Acrolein,Coriolis,Fermi,Hot band,Infrared,Propenal,Synchrotron},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {106--113},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron far-infrared spectroscopy of acrolein: The vibrational levels below 700 cm-1}},
volume = {250},
year = {2008}
}

@article{15McBiXu,
abstract = {Using spectra obtained at the Canadian Light Source synchrotron radiation facility, a previously unobserved out-of-plane vibration of trans-acrolein (propenal) is reliably assigned for the first time. Its origin is at 1002.01 cm-1, which is about 20 cm-1 higher than usually quoted in the past. This mode is thus labelled as v14, leaving the label v15 for the known vibration at 992.66 cm-1. Weak combination bands 171182 _ 182, 171131 _ 131, 121182 _ 181, and 171182 _ 181 are studied for the first time, and assignments in the known v11, v16, and v15 fundamental bands are also extended. The seven excited vibrations involved in these bands are analyzed, together with five more unobserved vibrations in the same region (850-1020 cm-1), in a large 12-state simultaneous fit which accounts for most of the many observed perturbations in the spectra.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Billinghurst, B. E. and Xu, Li Hong and Lees, R. M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.09.002},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Acrolein,Coriolis,Infrared,Perturbation,Synchrotron},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {16--25},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron infrared spectroscopy of acrolein: The vibrational levels between 850 and 1020 cm-1}},
volume = {317},
year = {2015}
}

@article{18McBiXu,
abstract = {Vibrational states of trans-acrolein (propenal) between 1020 and 1200 cm_1 are analyzed using high-resolution infrared spectra obtained at the Canadian Light Source synchrotron radiation facility. The one fundamental in this range, $\nu$10 (C-C stretch vibration) is found to be strongly mixed with a combination vibration $\nu$14 + $\nu$18 by a Fermi-type interaction. Five additional states are directly observed via hot, combination, and overtone bands: $\nu$11 + $\nu$18, $\nu$16 + $\nu$18, $\nu$15 + $\nu$18, 2$\nu$12, and 2$\nu$17. These seven vibrational states are analyzed in a large multi-state fit, along with nine more states which are not directly observed but which affect the observed states by means of many perturbations. Though this fit is cumbersome, incomplete, and not unique, it can account for 3668 out of 3835 assigned lines with an average error of less than 0.0004 cm_1.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Billinghurst, B. E. and Xu, Li Hong and Lees, R. M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2018.05.009},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Acrolein,Coriolis,Infrared,Perturbation,Propenal,Synchrotron},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {51--56},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron infrared spectroscopy of acrolein: The interacting 101 and 141181 states and other vibrational levels between 1020 and 1200 cm_1}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2018.05.009},
volume = {350},
year = {2018}
}

@article{85HaNiTs,
abstract = {The gas-phase infrared absorption spectrum of acrolein is observed from 4000 to 400 cm-1 with a resolution of 0.06 or 0.03 cm-1. The previously unlocated vinyl CH stretching band is observed at 3069 cm-1 and its CH out-of-plane modes whose assignments have been in confusion are investigated in detail. The mode assignments of some other bands are revised on the basis of the calculated frequencies and relative intensities by an ab initio MO method. {\textcopyright} 1985.},
author = {Hamada, Yoshiaki and Nishimura, Yoshifumi and Tsuboi, Masamichi},
doi = {10.1016/0301-0104(85)87062-2},
issn = {03010104},
journal = {Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {365--375},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of trans-acrolein}},
volume = {100},
year = {1985}
}

@article{85HaNiTs,
abstract = {The gas-phase infrared absorption spectrum of acrolein is observed from 4000 to 400 cm-1 with a resolution of 0.06 or 0.03 cm-1. The previously unlocated vinyl CH stretching band is observed at 3069 cm-1 and its CH out-of-plane modes whose assignments have been in confusion are investigated in detail. The mode assignments of some other bands are revised on the basis of the calculated frequencies and relative intensities by an ab initio MO method. {\textcopyright} 1985.},
author = {Hamada, Yoshiaki and Nishimura, Yoshifumi and Tsuboi, Masamichi},
doi = {10.1016/0301-0104(85)87062-2},
issn = {03010104},
journal = {Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {365--375},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of trans-acrolein}},
volume = {100},
year = {1985}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{73SiLaPe,
abstract = {Infrared and Raman spectra have been recorded between 4000 and 200 cm-1for four isotopic species of propene in the gaseous and liquid states. From a qualitative assignment a normal coordinate analysis and a 34 parameter valence field has been computed by an iterative process. The values of some force constants are discussed. {\textcopyright} 1973.},
author = {Silvi, B. and Labarbe, P. and Perchard, J. P.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(73)80070-4},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {2},
pages = {263--276},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Spectres de vibration et coordonn{\'{e}}es normales de quatre esp{\`{e}}ces isotopiques de prop{\`{e}}ne}},
volume = {29},
year = {1973}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{14EsAlFa,
abstract = {Propylene, a by-product of biomass burning, thermal cracking of hydrocarbons and incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, is a ubiquitous molecule found in the environment and atmosphere. Accurate infrared (IR) cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene are essential for quantitative measurements and atmospheric modeling. We measured absolute IR cross-sections of propylene using Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectroscopy over the wavenumber range of 400-6500cm-1 and at gas temperatures between 296 and 460K. We recorded these spectra at spectral resolutions ranging from 0.08 to 0.5cm-1 and measured the integrated band intensities for a number of vibrational bands in certain spectral regions. We then compared the integrated band intensities measured at room temperature with values derived from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) databases. Our results agreed well with the results reported in the two databases with a maximum deviation of about 4%. The peak cross-sections for the primary bands decreased by about 20-54% when the temperature increased from 296 to 460K. Moreover, we determined the integrated band intensities as a function of temperature for certain features in various spectral regions; we found no significant temperature dependence over the range of temperatures considered here. We also studied the effect of temperature on absorption cross-section using a Difference Frequency Generation (DFG) laser system. We compared the DFG results with those obtained from the FTIR study at certain wavenumbers over the 2850-2975cm-1 range and found a reasonable agreement with less than 10% discrepancy. {\textcopyright} 2013 Elsevier Ltd.},
author = {touhami Es-sebbar, Et and Alrefae, Majed and Farooq, Aamir},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {DFG spectroscopy,FTIR,IR cross-section,Integrated band intensity,Propylene},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
pages = {559--569},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Infrared cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene: Temperature-dependent studies}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},
volume = {133},
year = {2014}
}

@article{06LaFlHe,
abstract = {FT-jet spectra of propene were recorded at 0.005 cm-1 instrumental resolution around 950 cm-1. Thanks to the jet conditions, probably corresponding to Trot close to 80 K, the torsion degrees of freedom are efficiently cooled down and the fine structure of the $\nu$18 and $\nu$19 vibrational bands could be investigated. The bands are perturbed and approximate variation of the principal rotational constants are obtained, as well as band origins. The A/E torsional splitting appears totally unpredictable over the range of vibrational-torsional energy investigated. {\textcopyright} 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.},
author = {Lafferty, W. J. and Flaud, J. M. and Herman, M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.molstruc.2005.03.051},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
keywords = {80 K sample temperature,Fourier-transform jet spectra,Internal rotation,Propene,Propylene,Torsional splitting},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {SPEC. ISS.},
pages = {65--69},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Resolved torsional splitting in the $\nu$18 and $\nu$19- bands of propene}},
volume = {780-781},
year = {2006}
}

@article{94AiFrOr,
abstract = {Sub-Doppler infrared spectra of five normal-mode vibrations of propene between 900-1100 cm-1 reveal strongly perturbed torsional tunneling splittings due to nonresonant anharmonic couplings to vibrational states in which the torsional mode is excited. The present results suggest that perturbed tunneling splittings will be a general feature for vibrationally excited states. Consequently, care should be taken when using tunneling splittings to obtain the vibrational dependence of a tunneling barrier. Instead, tunneling splittings in excited states can be used as a probe of long-range vibrational-torsional state mixing in molecules. {\textcopyright} 1994 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Ainetschian, A. and Fraser, G. T. and Ortigoso, J. and Pate, B. H.},
doi = {10.1063/1.466939},
file = {::},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {ANHARMONICITY,DOPPLER EFFECT,EXCITATION,FREQUENCY MIXING,INFRARED SPECTRA,LINE SPLITTING,NORMAL-MODE ANALYSIS,POTENTIAL BARRIER,PROPYLENE,TORSION,TUNNEL EFFECT},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {729--732},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Contaminated torsional tunneling splittings in five normal-mode vibrations of propene}},
url = {http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.466939},
volume = {100},
year = {1994}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{14EsAlFa,
abstract = {Propylene, a by-product of biomass burning, thermal cracking of hydrocarbons and incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, is a ubiquitous molecule found in the environment and atmosphere. Accurate infrared (IR) cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene are essential for quantitative measurements and atmospheric modeling. We measured absolute IR cross-sections of propylene using Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectroscopy over the wavenumber range of 400-6500cm-1 and at gas temperatures between 296 and 460K. We recorded these spectra at spectral resolutions ranging from 0.08 to 0.5cm-1 and measured the integrated band intensities for a number of vibrational bands in certain spectral regions. We then compared the integrated band intensities measured at room temperature with values derived from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) databases. Our results agreed well with the results reported in the two databases with a maximum deviation of about 4%. The peak cross-sections for the primary bands decreased by about 20-54% when the temperature increased from 296 to 460K. Moreover, we determined the integrated band intensities as a function of temperature for certain features in various spectral regions; we found no significant temperature dependence over the range of temperatures considered here. We also studied the effect of temperature on absorption cross-section using a Difference Frequency Generation (DFG) laser system. We compared the DFG results with those obtained from the FTIR study at certain wavenumbers over the 2850-2975cm-1 range and found a reasonable agreement with less than 10% discrepancy. {\textcopyright} 2013 Elsevier Ltd.},
author = {touhami Es-sebbar, Et and Alrefae, Majed and Farooq, Aamir},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {DFG spectroscopy,FTIR,IR cross-section,Integrated band intensity,Propylene},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
pages = {559--569},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Infrared cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene: Temperature-dependent studies}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},
volume = {133},
year = {2014}
}

@article{14EsAlFa,
abstract = {Propylene, a by-product of biomass burning, thermal cracking of hydrocarbons and incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, is a ubiquitous molecule found in the environment and atmosphere. Accurate infrared (IR) cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene are essential for quantitative measurements and atmospheric modeling. We measured absolute IR cross-sections of propylene using Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectroscopy over the wavenumber range of 400-6500cm-1 and at gas temperatures between 296 and 460K. We recorded these spectra at spectral resolutions ranging from 0.08 to 0.5cm-1 and measured the integrated band intensities for a number of vibrational bands in certain spectral regions. We then compared the integrated band intensities measured at room temperature with values derived from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) databases. Our results agreed well with the results reported in the two databases with a maximum deviation of about 4%. The peak cross-sections for the primary bands decreased by about 20-54% when the temperature increased from 296 to 460K. Moreover, we determined the integrated band intensities as a function of temperature for certain features in various spectral regions; we found no significant temperature dependence over the range of temperatures considered here. We also studied the effect of temperature on absorption cross-section using a Difference Frequency Generation (DFG) laser system. We compared the DFG results with those obtained from the FTIR study at certain wavenumbers over the 2850-2975cm-1 range and found a reasonable agreement with less than 10% discrepancy. {\textcopyright} 2013 Elsevier Ltd.},
author = {touhami Es-sebbar, Et and Alrefae, Majed and Farooq, Aamir},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {DFG spectroscopy,FTIR,IR cross-section,Integrated band intensity,Propylene},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
pages = {559--569},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Infrared cross-sections and integrated band intensities of propylene: Temperature-dependent studies}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2013.09.019},
volume = {133},
year = {2014}
}

@article{73SiLaPe,
abstract = {Infrared and Raman spectra have been recorded between 4000 and 200 cm-1for four isotopic species of propene in the gaseous and liquid states. From a qualitative assignment a normal coordinate analysis and a 34 parameter valence field has been computed by an iterative process. The values of some force constants are discussed. {\textcopyright} 1973.},

@article{18SuToDr,
abstract = {In support of infrared remote sensing of Titan, we present temperature dependent cross-sections of propene (C3H6; CH2[dbnd]CHÐCH3; propylene) measured in the laboratory. A total of 27 high-resolution (up to 0.0022 cm_1) spectra of pure C3H6 and mixtures of C3H6 with N2 were obtained at 150Ð299 K in the 650Ð1534 cm_1 (6.5Ð15.4 µm) region. A custom-designed cold cell was used, which was configured with an active temperature control and could be integrated to a Fourier-transform spectrometer (Bruker 125HR) at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The observed C3H6 spectral features include its strong v19 band bearing the most prominent Q-branch peak at 912 cm_1 and three other strong bands: v18, v16 and v7 centered near 991, 1443, and 1459 cm_1, respectively. In addition, we have generated empirical pseudoline lists (PLLs) in HITRAN-format, in the two separate spectral regions, which are Region I: 800Ð1100 and Region II: 1340Ð1524 cm_1. The PLLs of C3H6 consists of spectroscopic line parameters (including line intensities and effective lower state energies) for all the individual pseudoline positions. The pseudoline parameters were determined by fitting 27 laboratory spectra of pure and N2-broadened propene simultaneously in the selected regions. A newly derived partition function was adopted in the line-by-line radiative transfer calculations. Based on the pseudoline intensities, the total integrated intensities in the 800Ð1120 and 1320Ð1524cm_1 regions were measured to be 8.79(47)_ 10_18 and 3.06(21)_10_18cm_1/(molecule cm_2) at 296 K, respectively. These values are found to be in a good agreement with the recent measurement made at KAUST at room temperature, but they are significantly lower than those reported by one of the most extensive previous studies at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL). Finally, the two PLLs are submitted as electronic supplements and are also available from the website, https://mark4sun.jpl.nasa.gov/pseudo.html.},
author = {Sung, Keeyoon and Toon, Geoffrey C. and Drouin, Brian J. and Mantz, Arlan W. and Smith, Mary Ann H.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.03.011},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
pages = {119--132},
publisher = {Elsevier Ltd},
title = {{FT-IR measurements of cold propene (C3H6) cross-sections at temperatures between 150 and 299 K}},
volume = {213},
year = {2018}
}

@article{70GrPuLi,
abstract = {The A2 and B2 torsional vibrational frequencies in propane gas have been directly measured at 217±8 and 265±8 cm -1, respectively, with inelastically scattered neutrons using the "small K" method of neutron molecular spectroscopy. The theoretical basis of the scattering experiment is discussed, and factors affecting resolution and intensity are enumerated. Not subject to the same selection rules as optical spectroscopy, neutron molecular spectroscopy is capable of observing vibrational transitions which are otherwise forbidden by molecular symmetry. The vibrational frequencies are interpreted by numerically solving the two-dimensional wave equation giving librational motion with a two-dimensional Fourier expansion. In this approach, the potential energy is Conveniently expanded also in Fourier form and we obtain a V3 = 3680±190 cal/mole for individual methyl-group librations and a V33 or F 6=- 280±130 cal/mole term which couples the two methyl tops. Evaluation of additional Fourier constants in the potential-energy expansion must await additional spectroscopic data concerning higher vibrational levels. Intermolecular perturbations of the librational frequencies were observed in both liquid and solid propane. These are sufficiently small, however, that one can conclude, to a first approximation, that the librational motions are not greatly effected in condensed states of propane.},
author = {Grant, David M. and Pugmire, Ronald J. and Livingston, Robert C. and Strong, Kenneth A. and McMurry, Henry L. and Brugger, Robert M.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1673668},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {9},
pages = {4418--4423},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Methyl Libration in Propane Measured with Neutron Inelastic Scattering}},
url = {https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.1673668},
volume = {52},
year = {1970}
}

The theoretical basis of the scattering experiment is discussed, and factors affecting resolution and intensity are enumerated. Not subject to the same selection rules as optical spectroscopy, neutron molecular spectroscopy is capable of observing vibrational transitions which are otherwise forbidden by molecular symmetry. The vibrational frequencies are interpreted by numerically solving the two-dimensional wave equation giving librational motion with a two-dimensional Fourier expansion. In this approach, the potential energy is Conveniently expanded also in Fourier form and we obtain a V3 = 3680±190 cal/mole for individual methyl-group librations and a V33 or F 6=- 280±130 cal/mole term which couples the two methyl tops. Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{10KwTcFl,
abstract = {The $\nu$9 fundamental band (C-C-C deformation) of propane (C3H8) at 369cm-1 has been studied at high-resolution (0.0011cm-1) with spectra recorded using the synchrotron radiation from the French light source facility at SOLEIL coupled to a Bruker IFS 125HR Fourier transform spectrometer. A 2.526m base multipass cell with optical paths from 10.296 to 151.78m was used. In addition, a spectrum was also recorded using a conventional globar source. Comparison of these experimental spectra shows clearly the gain obtained on the signal-to-noise ratios with the synchrotron radiation. The spectra have been thoroughly analyzed and transitions up to J=65 and Ka=33 have been assigned. The upper-state rotational levels were fitted using an A-type Watson Hamiltonian written in the Ir representation. An accurate band center $\nu$0 ($\nu$9)=369.228080(25)cm-1 as well as accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants have been obtained and used to simulate a synthetic spectrum. These parameters should be useful to simulate hot bands of propane involving the 91 vibrational level as their lower state. {\textcopyright} 2010.},
author = {{Kwabia Tchana}, F. and Flaud, J. M. and Lafferty, W. J. and Manceron, L. and Roy, P.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2009.12.009},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Nu9 band,Propane,Ro-vibrational analysis,Synchrotron source},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {9},
pages = {1277--1281},
publisher = {Pergamon},
title = {{The first high-resolution analysis of the low-lying $\nu$9 band of propane}},
volume = {111},
year = {2010}
}

@article{10FlTcLa,
abstract = {Using high-resolution Fourier transform spectra of propane recorded in the 13.4 m (resolution 0.002 cm-1) and in the 27.4 m (resolution 0.0011 cm-1) spectral regions, it was possible to perform a thorough assignment of both the 26 band at 745 cm-1 and the 29-9 band at about 370 cm-1. This simultaneous assignment was necessary since the 261 and 92 rotational levels interact strongly through an A-type Coriolis interaction. The experimental upper-state rotational levels were fit using a Hamiltonian matrix which takes into account explicitly this strong A-type Coriolis interaction. With this model the experimental energy levels were fit to within their experimental uncertainties and accurate band centres, rotational, centrifugal distortion and coupling constants were determined. The following band centres were derived: o(26) = 748.530882(80) cm-1 and o(29) = 740.29213(10) cm-1. Finally, it is shown how the use of these new spectral parameters greatly improves the accuracy of modelling of Titan's infrared spectrum at 13.4 m, relative to the currently available GEISA atlas for the same band. {\textcopyright} 2010 Taylor & Francis.},
author = {Flaud, J. M. and Tchana, F. Kwabia and Lafferty, W. J. and Nixon, C. A.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970903501709},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {High resolution IR,Molecular parameters,Propane},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {6},
pages = {699--704},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{High resolution analysis of the v26 and 2v9-v 9 bands of propane: Modelling of Titan's infrared spectrum at 13.4 $\mu$m}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970903501709},
volume = {108},
year = {2010}
}

@article{19PeFlKw,
abstract = {We present the first investigation of the $\nu$8 band (CÐC symmetric stretch at 870.3137 cm_1), together with an extended analysis of the neighbouring $\nu$21 band (CH3 rock at 921.3756 cm_1) of propane (C3H8). Our previous investigation of the $\nu$21 A-type band [A.Perrin, F. Kwabia-Tchana, J.M.Flaud, L.Manceron, P.Groner, W.J.Lafferty. J. Mol. Spectrosc. 315, 55 (2015)] revealed that the rotational energy levels of 211 are split because of interactions with the internal rotations of the methyl groups, leading to the identification of AA, EE, AE and EA torsional components. In this work, a similar behaviour was observed for the B-type $\nu$8 band and the analysis of the $\nu$21 band was greatly extended. One of the results of the present study is to show that these torsional splittings are due to the existence of anharmonic and Coriolis resonances, coupling the 211 and 81 rotational levels to nearby highly excited levels of the two internal rotations of the methyl groups. Accordingly, an effective ÔvibrationÐtorsion- rotation' Hamiltonian model was built in the G36 symmetry group which accounts for both types of resonances. In parallel, a code computing the line intensities was developed to allow unambiguous torsional component assignments. The line assignments were performed using a high resolution (0.0015 cm_1) infrared spectrum of propane, recorded with synchrotron radiation at the SOLEIL French light source facility coupled to a Bruker IFS-125 Fourier transform spectrometer. Finally, a linelist of positions and intensities which can be used for the detection of propane in the Earth and outer planets atmospheres was produced.},
author = {Perrin, A. and Flaud, J. M. and Kwabia-Tchana, F. and Manceron, L. and Groner, P.},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2018.1512720},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {High resolution infrared spectroscopy,large amplitude tunnelling,propane (CH3CH2CH3),two equivalent methyl rotors,vibration- rotation resonances},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {3},
pages = {323--339},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis},
title = {{Investigation of the $\nu$8 and $\nu$21 bands of propane CH3CH2CH3 at 11.5 and 10.9 µm: evidence of large amplitude tunnelling effects}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268976.2018.1512720},
volume = {117},
year = {2019}
}

@article{65GaKi,
abstract = {The infrared spectra of C3H8, C3D8, (CH3)2CD2, (CD3)2CH3 and C2H5CD3 have been obtained over the spectral region from about 10000 cm-1, to 250 cm-1, using both prism and grating spectrometers. From these data it was possible to assign 109 fundamentals of the 115 infrared active transitions in these five molecules, and to estimate the frequencies for four other fundamental transitions by use of the Teller-Redlich Product Rule. In addition, the frequencies for eight of the twenty inactive fundamentals were estimated by analysis of the observed, and assigned, combination and overtone bands. {\textcopyright} 1965.},
author = {Gayles, J. N. and King, W. T.},
doi = {10.1016/0371-1951(65)80145-X},
issn = {0371-1951},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {3},
pages = {543--557},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{The infrared spectrum of propane}},
volume = {21},
year = {1965}
}

From these data it was possible to assign 109 fundamentals of the 115 infrared active transitions in these five molecules, and to estimate the frequencies for four other fundamental transitions by use of the Teller-Redlich Product Rule. In addition, the frequencies for eight of the twenty inactive fundamentals were estimated by analysis of the observed, and assigned, combination and overtone bands. {\textcopyright} 1965.},
author = {Gayles, J. N. and King, W. T.},
doi = {10.1016/0371-1951(65)80145-X},
issn = {0371-1951},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta},

title = {{The infrared spectrum of propane}},
volume = {21},
year = {1965}
}

@article{94AuHoJe,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of the $\nu$6 band system of carbon suboxide, C3O2, has been recorded between 500 and 600 cm-1 at a resolution of 0.002 cm-1. Altogether 23 bands have been assigned. They correspond to transitions $\nu$6 + n$\nu$7 _ n$\nu$7, n ² 9, where $\nu$6 is the asymmetric CCO bending mode and $\nu$7 is the very anharmonic CCC bending mode. Among these bands, 20 have been rotationally analyzed and 1220 lines assigned. The line positions were fitted to effective parameters which characterize these 20 vibrational levels in the $\nu$6 state. The results of the fits were then fitted so a semirigid bender model in order to determine the effective CCC bending potential function in the $\nu$6 state. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Auwera, J. Vander and Holland, J. K. and Jensen, P. and Johns, J. W.C.},
doi = {10.1006/JMSP.1994.1045},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {2},
pages = {529--540},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The $\nu$6 Band System of C3O2 Near 540 cm_11}},
volume = {163},
year = {1994}
}

@article{94AuHoJe,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of the $\nu$6 band system of carbon suboxide, C3O2, has been recorded between 500 and 600 cm-1 at a resolution of 0.002 cm-1. Altogether 23 bands have been assigned. They correspond to transitions $\nu$6 + n$\nu$7 _ n$\nu$7, n ² 9, where $\nu$6 is the asymmetric CCO bending mode and $\nu$7 is the very anharmonic CCC bending mode. Among these bands, 20 have been rotationally analyzed and 1220 lines assigned. The line positions were fitted to effective parameters which characterize these 20 vibrational levels in the $\nu$6 state. The results of the fits were then fitted so a semirigid bender model in order to determine the effective CCC bending potential function in the $\nu$6 state. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},

volume = {163},

}

@article{81HaMiKa,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of carbon suboxide has been recorded with a resolution of 0-01 cm-1 from 400 to 700 cm-1. The region from 530 to 570 cm-1 shows intense absorption due to the $\nu$6($\Pi$u) band system, of which the fundamental band only has been assigned and analysed, giving ve = 540-221 cm-1. The region 590 to 660 cm-1 shows weaker absorption due to the $\nu$5(IIg) band system appearing in combination with odd quanta of the $\nu$7($\Pi$u) fundamental at 18 cm-1. The v5 + v7 band and several hot bands have been assigned and analysed, and the effective v7 bending potential in the v5 state has been deduced. This potential shows a splitting as the large amplitude bending coordinate q7 is displaced due to interaction between v5 and v7 analogous to the Renner-Teller effect in electronic spectroscopy. This splitting is about 4 cm-1 for the classical turning points in q7 and the mean q7 bending potential is closely similar to that in the ground state. {\textcopyright} 1981 Taylor & Francis Ltd.},
author = {Halonen, L. and Mills, I. M. and Kauppinen, J.},
doi = {10.1080/00268978100101761},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {4},
pages = {913--931},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{Vibrational renner-teller effects in the infrared spectrum of carbon suboxide}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268978100101761},
volume = {43},
year = {1981}
}

@article{81HaMiKa,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of carbon suboxide has been recorded with a resolution of 0-01 cm-1 from 400 to 700 cm-1. The region from 530 to 570 cm-1 shows intense absorption due to the $\nu$6($\Pi$u) band system, of which the fundamental band only has been assigned and analysed, giving ve = 540-221 cm-1. The region 590 to 660 cm-1 shows weaker absorption due to the $\nu$5(IIg) band system appearing in combination with odd quanta of the $\nu$7($\Pi$u) fundamental at 18 cm-1. The v5 + v7 band and several hot bands have been assigned and analysed, and the effective v7 bending potential in the v5 state has been deduced. This potential shows a splitting as the large amplitude bending coordinate q7 is displaced due to interaction between v5 and v7 analogous to the Renner-Teller effect in electronic spectroscopy. volume = {43},

}

@article{78LoBr,
abstract = {The $
u$2, $
u$2 + 2$
u$70 and 2$
u$70 Raman band-accumulations of carbon suboxide C3O2 have been photographed with a resolution of 0.25 cm-1, using 50 Torr sample pressure without serious polymerization. Each of the three bands is accompanied by series of hot bands, as v7$
u$7l7$
u$2 + v7$
u$7l7, due to the extremely low, highly anharmonic $
u$7 fundamental vibration, forming a complex band-accumulation. The unresolved Q-branches in the $
u$2 and $
u$2 + 2$
u$70 band-accumulations have been assigned and utilized, in conjunction with infrared and microwave data, to determine the $
u$7 energy levels in the ground state and in the $
u$2 state. The Q-branch of the $
u$2 fundamental band has been resolved and analyzed, yielding $
u$2 = 787.72 ± 0.05 cm-1. The results obtained are in excellent agreement with theoretical predictions by Weber. {	extcopyright} 1978.},
author = {Lolck, Jens Erik and Brodersen, Svend},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(78)90143-1},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {3},
pages = {445--462},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The $
u$2, $
u$2 + 2$
u$70, and 2$
u$70 Raman band-accumulations of C3O2}},

@article{79LoBr,
abstract = {The $
u$1, $
u$5, 2$
u$5, and 2$
u$6 Raman band accumulations of carbon suboxide, C3O2, have been photographed with a resolution of 0.2-0.3 cm-1. Each band accumulation consists, in addition to the main band, of a large number of "hot" bands due to the extremely low, highly anharmonic $
u$7 fundamental vibration. In the 2$
u$6 band accumulation a few series of unresolved Q branches have been assigned. In the $
u$1 and 2$
u$5 band accumulations most Q branches almost coincide, forming a very intense peak, whereas the dominating feature of the $
u$5 band accumulation is a minimum, in agreement with the expectation of an extremely weak Q branch for a $\Pi$g fundamental band. Tentative values of $
u$1 = 2196.9 ± 0.1 cm-1 and $
u$5 = 580.2 ± 0.5 cm-1 as well as several energy values in the $
u$7 manifold of the 2$
u$60 state are obtained. Further, improved exposures of the $
u$2 + 2$
u$70 band accumulation yield some levels in the $
u$7 manifold of the $
u$2 state, in addition to those determined previously. {	extcopyright} 1979.},
author = {Lolck, Jens Erik and Brodersen, Svend},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(79)90119-X},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {2},
pages = {234--244},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Some Raman bands of C3O2}},
volume = {75},
year = {1979}
}

@article{80FuMiGu,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of carbon suboxide has been recorded from 1800 to 2600 cm-1 at a resolution of 0.003 cm-1. About 7% of the ca. 40 000 lines observed have been assigned and analyzed, belonging to 36 different bands. Most of these are associated with the fundamental $\nu$3, at 2289.80 cm-1, and the combination band $\nu$2 + $\nu$4, at 2386.61 cm-1, each of which give rise to a system of sum bands, difference bands, and hot bands involving the low-wave-number fundamental $\nu$7 at 18 cm-1. A few other tentative assignments are made. The bands have been analyzed for vibrational and rotational constants. {\textcopyright} 1980.},
author = {Fusina, L. and Mills, I. M. and Guelachvili, G.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(80)90296-9},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {101--122},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Carbon suboxide: The infrared spectrum from 1800 to 2600 cm_1}},
volume = {79},
year = {1980}
}

@article{92McBr,
abstract = {The $\nu$6 + $\nu$8 combination band of diacetylene has been remeasured at 0.0019 cm-1 resolution with a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Analysis and assignment of the improved data sets were carried out with an interactive Loomis-Wood fitting program. Altogether more than 1400 assignments were made and band origins, rotational and distortion constants for the main band and associated hot bands were determined. The band centre was found to be 1241.060828(37) cm-1 and the ground-state rotational and distortion constants, B0 and D0, were found to be 0.14641021(52) cm-1 and 1.6085(49) _ 10-8 cm-1, respectively. The experimental values of B0 for diacetylene, triacetylene and dicyanoacetylene are compared with values predicted from ab initio calculations, and with values obtained from estimates derived from the known structural parameters of HC3N and HC5N. Several very weak difference bands, 110901, 110801 and 410601, and combination bands, 510610 and 110910, in the region 3600-2600 cm-1 were also assigned. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {McNaughton, D. and Bruget, D. N.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2860(92)87072-4},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {C},
pages = {11--25},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{The high-resolution infrared spectrum of diacetylene and structures of diacetylene, triacetylene and dicyanoacetylene}},
volume = {273},
year = {1992}
}

@article{84GuCrRa,
abstract = {High-resolution absorption spectra of diacetylene in the regions 1850-2523 and 2860-3584 cm-1 have been recorded with a Fourier transform spectrometer. Rotational analyses are given for the $\nu$4 and $\nu$5 fundamentals and associated "hot" bands. Analyses are also reported for 11 combination bands. Vibrational constants are summarized for all the fundamentals, and rotational constants are given for all the low-lying bending vibrations. Intensity data are given for the $\nu$4 band, which is found to be stronger than the $\nu$5 band by a factor of 45 ± 5. {\textcopyright} 1984.},
author = {Guelachvili, G. and Craig, A. M. and Ramsay, D. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(84)90110-3},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {1},
pages = {156--192},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution Fourier studies of diacetylene in the regions of the $\nu$4 and $\nu$5 fundamentals}},
volume = {105},
year = {1984}
}

@article{08CrSa,
abstract = {A wide-ranging investigation of high-resolution infrared spectra of 1,3-butadiene was undertaken with the prime objective of finding subbands in the rotational structure attributable to the gauche rotamer, from which information about the molecular structure could be derived. A weak band near 750 cm -1, which had previously been assigned to the gauche rotamer, has been shown to be a difference band for the trans rotamer. In support of the analysis of this band, the rotational structure, including two hot bands, was analyzed in the C-type band for the v12(au) mode near 525 cm-1 and in the C-type band near 162 cm-1 for the v 13(au) mode. An unsuccessful attempt was made to extend the analysis of the B-type component of the A/B-type band for V 17(bu) near 3000 cm-1. With the exception of the two weak Q branches at 463.82 and 462.16 cm-1, no new evidence for the gauche rotamer in the gas phase was found. {\textcopyright} 2008 American Chemical Society.},
author = {Craig, Norman C. and Sams, Robert L.},
doi = {10.1021/jp807677y},
issn = {10895639},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {49},
pages = {12637--12646},
title = {{An investigation of the rotamers of butadiene by high-resolution infrared spectroscopy}},
volume = {112},
year = {2008}
}

@article{20MaPoGu,
abstract = {The high resolution far-infrared spectrum of trans-butadiene has been reinvestigated by Fourier-transform spectroscopy at two synchrotron radiation facilities, SOLEIL and the Canadian Light Source, at temperatures ranging from 50 to 340 K. Beyond the well-studied bands, two new fundamental bands lying below 1100 cm-1, $\nu$10 and $\nu$24, have been assigned using a combination of cross-correlation (ASAP software) and Loomis-Wood type (LWWa software) diagrams. While the $\nu$24 analysis was rather straightforward, $\nu$10 exhibits obvious signs of a strong perturbation, presumably owing to interaction with the dark $\nu$9 + $\nu$12 state. Effective rotational constants have been derived for both the v10 = 1 and v24 = 1 states. Since only one weak, infrared active fundamental band ($\nu$23) of trans-butadiene remains to be observed at high resolution in the far-infrared, searches for the elusive gauche conformer can now be undertaken with considerably greater confidence in the dense ro-vibrational spectrum of the trans form.},
author = {Martin-Drumel, Marie Aline and Porterfield, Jessica P. and Goubet, Manuel and Asselin, Pierre and Georges, Robert and Soulard, Pascale and Nava, Matthew and Changala, P. Bryan and Billinghurst, Brant and Pirali, Olivier and McCarthy, Michael C. and Baraban, Joshua H.},
doi = {10.1021/acs.jpca.0c00623},
issn = {15205215},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {12},
pages = {2427--2435},
pmid = {32118434},
title = {{Synchrotron-Based High Resolution Far-Infrared Spectroscopy of trans-Butadiene}},
volume = {124},
year = {2020}
}

@article{15KrCrBo,
abstract = {A quantum-mechanical (hybrid MP2/cc-pVTZ and CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ) full quartic potential energy surface (PES) in rectilinear normal coordinates and the second-order operator canonical Van Vleck perturbation theory (CVPT2) are employed to predict the anharmonic vibrational spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-butadiene (BDE). These predictions are used to interpret their infrared and Raman scattering spectra. New high-temperature Raman spectra in the gas phase are presented in support of assignments for the gauche conformer. The CVPT2 solution is based on a PES and electro-optical properties (EOP; dipole moment and polarizability) expanded in Taylor series. Higher terms than those routinely available from Gaussian09 software were calculated by numerical differentiation of quadratic force fields and EOP using the MP2/cc-pVTZ model. The integer coefficients of the polyad quantum numbers were derived for both conformers of BDE. Replacement of harmonic frequencies by their counterparts from the CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ model significantly improved the agreement with experimental data for s-trans-BDE (root-mean-square deviation Å 5.5 cm-1). The accuracy in predicting the rather well-studied spectrum of fundamentals of s-trans-BDE assures good predictions of the spectrum of s-gauche-BDE. A nearly complete assignment of fundamentals was obtained for the gauche conformer. Many nonfundamental transitions of the BDE conformers were interpreted as well. The predictions of multiple Fermi resonances in the complex CH-stretching region correlate well with experiment. It is shown that solving a vibrational anharmonic problem through a numerical-analytic implementation of CVPT2 is a straightforward and computationally advantageous approach for medium-size molecules in comparison with the standard second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2) based on analytic expressions.},
author = {Krasnoshchekov, Sergey V. and Craig, Norman C. and Boopalachandran, Praveenkumar and Laane, Jaan and Stepanov, Nikolay F.},
doi = {10.1021/acs.jpca.5b07650},
issn = {15205215},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {43},
pages = {10706--10723},
title = {{Anharmonic Vibrational Analysis of the Infrared and Raman Gas-Phase Spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-1,3-Butadiene}},
volume = {119},
year = {2015}
}

@article{08CrSa,
abstract = {A wide-ranging investigation of high-resolution infrared spectra of 1,3-butadiene was undertaken with the prime objective of finding subbands in the rotational structure attributable to the gauche rotamer, from which information about the molecular structure could be derived. A weak band near 750 cm -1, which had previously been assigned to the gauche rotamer, has been shown to be a difference band for the trans rotamer. In support of the analysis of this band, the rotational structure, including two hot bands, was analyzed in the C-type band for the v12(au) mode near 525 cm-1 and in the C-type band near 162 cm-1 for the v 13(au) mode. An unsuccessful attempt was made to extend the analysis of the B-type component of the A/B-type band for V 17(bu) near 3000 cm-1. With the exception of the two weak Q branches at 463.82 and 462.16 cm-1, no new evidence for the gauche rotamer in the gas phase was found. {\textcopyright} 2008 American Chemical Society.},
author = {Craig, Norman C. and Sams, Robert L.},

@article{15KrCrBo,
abstract = {A quantum-mechanical (hybrid MP2/cc-pVTZ and CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ) full quartic potential energy surface (PES) in rectilinear normal coordinates and the second-order operator canonical Van Vleck perturbation theory (CVPT2) are employed to predict the anharmonic vibrational spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-butadiene (BDE). These predictions are used to interpret their infrared and Raman scattering spectra. New high-temperature Raman spectra in the gas phase are presented in support of assignments for the gauche conformer. The CVPT2 solution is based on a PES and electro-optical properties (EOP; dipole moment and polarizability) expanded in Taylor series. Higher terms than those routinely available from Gaussian09 software were calculated by numerical differentiation of quadratic force fields and EOP using the MP2/cc-pVTZ model. The integer coefficients of the polyad quantum numbers were derived for both conformers of BDE. Replacement of harmonic frequencies by their counterparts from the CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ model significantly improved the agreement with experimental data for s-trans-BDE (root-mean-square deviation Å 5.5 cm-1). The accuracy in predicting the rather well-studied spectrum of fundamentals of s-trans-BDE assures good predictions of the spectrum of s-gauche-BDE. A nearly complete assignment of fundamentals was obtained for the gauche conformer. Many nonfundamental transitions of the BDE conformers were interpreted as well. The predictions of multiple Fermi resonances in the complex CH-stretching region correlate well with experiment. It is shown that solving a vibrational anharmonic problem through a numerical-analytic implementation of CVPT2 is a straightforward and computationally advantageous approach for medium-size molecules in comparison with the standard second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2) based on analytic expressions.},
author = {Krasnoshchekov, Sergey V. and Craig, Norman C. and Boopalachandran, Praveenkumar and Laane, Jaan and Stepanov, Nikolay F.},
doi = {10.1021/acs.jpca.5b07650},
issn = {15205215},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {43},
pages = {10706--10723},
title = {{Anharmonic Vibrational Analysis of the Infrared and Raman Gas-Phase Spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-1,3-Butadiene}},
volume = {119},
year = {2015}
}

@article{04CrDaHa,
abstract = {Rotational constants for butadiene and butadiene-2,3-d2 are derived from the analysis of the rotational structure of bands in the high-resolution infrared (IR) spectra. Corresponding moments of inertia computed from three quantum chemical calculations agree acceptably with the experimental values. Evidence is growing that the C=C bond lengthens some and the C-C bond shortens some in support of partial $\pi$-electron delocalization in butadiene. Refinements are made in the assignment of vibrational fundamentals of butadiene and butadiene-2,3-d2 from new observations of IR and Raman spectra of these species. {\textcopyright} 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.},
author = {Craig, Norman C. and Davis, Jedidiah L. and Hanson, Keith A. and Moore, Michael C. and Weidenbaum, Kevin J. and Lock, Michael},
doi = {10.1016/j.molstruc.2003.11.051},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
keywords = {High-resolution infrared spectra,Quantum chemical calculations,Raman spectra,Rotational constants,Structural parameters},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {59--69},
title = {{Analysis of the rotational structure in bands in the high-resolution infrared spectra of butadiene and butadiene-2,3-d2: Refinement in assignments of fundamentals}},
volume = {695-696},
year = {2004}
}

@article{15KrCrBo,
abstract = {A quantum-mechanical (hybrid MP2/cc-pVTZ and CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ) full quartic potential energy surface (PES) in rectilinear normal coordinates and the second-order operator canonical Van Vleck perturbation theory (CVPT2) are employed to predict the anharmonic vibrational spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-butadiene (BDE). These predictions are used to interpret their infrared and Raman scattering spectra. New high-temperature Raman spectra in the gas phase are presented in support of assignments for the gauche conformer. The CVPT2 solution is based on a PES and electro-optical properties (EOP; dipole moment and polarizability) expanded in Taylor series. Higher terms than those routinely available from Gaussian09 software were calculated by numerical differentiation of quadratic force fields and EOP using the MP2/cc-pVTZ model. The integer coefficients of the polyad quantum numbers were derived for both conformers of BDE. Replacement of harmonic frequencies by their counterparts from the CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ model significantly improved the agreement with experimental data for s-trans-BDE (root-mean-square deviation Å 5.5 cm-1). The accuracy in predicting the rather well-studied spectrum of fundamentals of s-trans-BDE assures good predictions of the spectrum of s-gauche-BDE. A nearly complete assignment of fundamentals was obtained for the gauche conformer. Many nonfundamental transitions of the BDE conformers were interpreted as well. The predictions of multiple Fermi resonances in the complex CH-stretching region correlate well with experiment. It is shown that solving a vibrational anharmonic problem through a numerical-analytic implementation of CVPT2 is a straightforward and computationally advantageous approach for medium-size molecules in comparison with the standard second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2) based on analytic expressions.},
author = {Krasnoshchekov, Sergey V. and Craig, Norman C. and Boopalachandran, Praveenkumar and Laane, Jaan and Stepanov, Nikolay F.},
doi = {10.1021/acs.jpca.5b07650},

number = {43},

title = {{Anharmonic Vibrational Analysis of the Infrared and Raman Gas-Phase Spectra of s-trans- and s-gauche-1,3-Butadiene}},
volume = {119},
year = {2015}
}
