@article{21UnNaOz,
abstract = {Vibrational scale factors were determined for the M06-2X method. The calculated scale factors were supported statistically. The main objective is to determine the concordance between frequencies. Descriptive statistics of the experimental and corrected frequencies are given. The relationship between corrected and experimental frequencies is formed by a simple linear regression method. The Concordance Correlation Coefficient determines the consistency between the two variables. It evaluates the direct relationship between X and Y variables measured under constraints. Also, the difference between the mean of the two variables was tested. All results are interpreted and presented with their graphs.},
author = {{\"{U}}nal, Yener and Nassif, Wassim and {\"{O}}zaydin, Burak Can and Sayin, Koray},
doi = {10.1016/j.vibspec.2020.103189},
issn = {09242031},
journal = {Vibrational Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Concordance correlation coefficient,Correlation,M06-2X method,Regression,Vibrational scale factor},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/2_ScalingFactors},
month = {jan},
pages = {103189},
publisher = {Elsevier B.V.},
title = {{Scale factor database for the vibration frequencies calculated in M06-2X, one of the DFT methods}},
volume = {112},
year = {2021}
}

@article{16LeXuBi,
abstract = {The C-S stretching fundamental band of 12CH332SH, the principal isotopologue of methyl mercaptan, has been investigated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy on the Far-Infrared beamline at the Canadian Light Source synchrotron. The band is centered around 710 cm-1 and shows well-resolved a-type parallel structure. Most of the A and E spectral sub-bands have been assigned up to K = 12 for the vt = 0 torsional state and K = 9 for the vt = 1 state, along with a smaller variety of sub-bands for vt = 2. C-S stretching energy term values have been determined employing known ground-state energies, and have been fitted to series expansions in powers of J(J + 1) to determine the substate origins. The origins have in turn been fitted to a Fourier model to characterize the oscillatory torsional energy structure of the C-S stretching state. The amplitude of oscillation of the vt = 0 torsional curves is significantly larger for the C-S stretch state compared to the ground state. A strategy devised to relate this amplitude to an effective torsional barrier height indicates a decrease of about 7% in the effective V3 for the C-S stretch. The vibrational frequency determined for the stretching fundamental from the Fourier fit is 710.3 cm-1. The C-S stretching manifold is crossed by excited vt = 4 torsional levels of the ground state, and strong torsion-vibrational resonant coupling is observed via perturbations in the spectrum together with forbidden sub-bands induced by mixing and intensity borrowing.},
author = {Lees, R. M. and Xu, Li Hong and Billinghurst, B. E.},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2015.12.006},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {C-S stretching band,CH3SH,Infrared spectra,Internal rotation,Methyl mercaptan,Torsion-vibration interactions},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
pages = {30--38},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution Fourier transform synchrotron spectroscopy of the CÐS stretching band of methyl mercaptan, CH332SH}},
volume = {319},
year = {2016}
}

@article{16DuZhZh,
abstract = {Attention has been focused recently on the harmful effects and malodor of methyl mercaptan (CH3SH), so it is desired to detect CH3SH in situ, sensitively, and selectively. We detected methyl mercaptan via tunable laser absorption spectroscopy (TLAS) with a room-temperature distributed feedback interband cascade laser emitting around 3393 nm and a hollow waveguide gas cell with 5 m length. The fundamental characteristic fingerprint absorptions of CH3SH from 3260 to 3400 nm were examined, and the spectral line 3393.584 nm (corresponding to the $\nu$2 CÐH symmetric stretch) was determined to be the optimum for CH3SH detection. The response characteristics of the TLAS system were established by implementing a set of CH3SH concentration gradient experiments with wavelength-scanned direct absorption spectroscopy. The results show that CH3SH TLAS spectra are in excellent agreement with spectra from the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory database; the TLAS response linearity is 0.987, and the detection limit is as low as 25 ppbv (parts per billion by volume, 10_9) with integrated time 1.84 s, corresponding to an absorbance of 1.34 _ 10_4 (near the theoretical detection limit). Overall, the TLAS system is a robust method for CH3SH monitoring of industrial waste gas emissions.},
author = {Du, Zhenhui and Zhen, Weimeng and Zhang, Zheyuan and Li, Jinyi and Gao, Nan},
doi = {10.1007/S00340-016-6378-Z/FIGURES/12},
issn = {09462171},
journal = {Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics},
keywords = {Engineering,Lasers,Optical Devices,Optics,Photonics,Physical Chemistry,Physics,Quantum Optics,general},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {4},
pages = {1--8},
publisher = {Springer Verlag},
title = {{Detection of methyl mercaptan with a 3393-nm distributed feedback interband cascade laser}},
url = {https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00340-016-6378-z},
volume = {122},
year = {2016}
}

@article{16DuZhZh,
abstract = {Attention has been focused recently on the harmful effects and malodor of methyl mercaptan (CH3SH), so it is desired to detect CH3SH in situ, sensitively, and selectively. We detected methyl mercaptan via tunable laser absorption spectroscopy (TLAS) with a room-temperature distributed feedback interband cascade laser emitting around 3393 nm and a hollow waveguide gas cell with 5 m length. The fundamental characteristic fingerprint absorptions of CH3SH from 3260 to 3400 nm were examined, and the spectral line 3393.584 nm (corresponding to the $\nu$2 CÐH symmetric stretch) was determined to be the optimum for CH3SH detection. The response characteristics of the TLAS system were established by implementing a set of CH3SH concentration gradient experiments with wavelength-scanned direct absorption spectroscopy. The results show that CH3SH TLAS spectra are in excellent agreement with spectra from the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory database; the TLAS response linearity is 0.987, and the detection limit is as low as 25 ppbv (parts per billion by volume, 10_9) with integrated time 1.84 s, corresponding to an absorbance of 1.34 _ 10_4 (near the theoretical detection limit). Overall, the TLAS system is a robust method for CH3SH monitoring of industrial waste gas emissions.},
author = {Du, Zhenhui and Zhen, Weimeng and Zhang, Zheyuan and Li, Jinyi and Gao, Nan},
doi = {10.1007/S00340-016-6378-Z/FIGURES/12},
issn = {09462171},
journal = {Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics},
keywords = {Engineering,Lasers,Optical Devices,Optics,Photonics,Physical Chemistry,Physics,Quantum Optics,general},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {4},
pages = {1--8},
publisher = {Springer Verlag},
title = {{Detection of methyl mercaptan with a 3393-nm distributed feedback interband cascade laser}},
url = {https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00340-016-6378-z},
volume = {122},
year = {2016}
}

@article{18LeXuGu,
abstract = {High-resolution Fourier transform spectra of the asymmetric methyl-bending and methyl-stretching bands of CH3SH have been recorded employing synchrotron radiation at the FIR beamline of the Canadian Light Source. Analysis of the torsion-rotation structure and relative intensities has revealed the novel feature that for both bend and stretch the in-plane and out-of-plane modes behave much like a Coriolis-coupled l-doublet pair originating from degenerate E modes of a symmetric top. As the axial angular momentum K increases, the energies of the coupled Òl = ±1Ó modes diverge linearly, with effective Coriolis $\zeta$ constants typical for symmetric tops. For the methyl-stretching states, separated at K = 0 by only about 1 cm_1, the assigned sub-bands follow a symmetric top $\Delta$(K _ l) = 0 selection rule, with only $\Delta$K = _1 transitions observed to the upper l = _1 in-plane A_ component and only $\Delta$K = +1 transitions to the lower l = +1 out-of-plane A_ component. The K = 0 separation of the CH3-bending states is larger at 9.1 cm_1 with the l-ordering reversed. Here, both $\Delta$K = +1 and $\Delta$K = _1 transitions are seen for each l-component but with a large difference in relative intensity. Term values for the excited state levels have been fitted to J(J + 1) power-series expansions to obtain substate origins. These have then been fitted to a Fourier model to characterize the torsion-K-rotation energy patterns. For both pairs of vibrational states, the torsional energies display the customary oscillatory behaviour as a function of K and have inverted torsional splittings relative to the ground state. The spectra show numerous perturbations, indicating local resonances with the underlying bath of high torsional levels and vibrational combination and overtone states. The overall structure of the two pairs of bands represents a new regime in which the vibrational energy separations, torsional splittings and shifts due to molecular asymmetry are all of the same order, creating a challenging and complex vibration-torsion-rotation coupling environment.},
author = {Lees, R. M. and Xu, Li Hong and Guislain, B. G. and Reid, E. M. and Twagirayezu, S. and Perry, D. S. and Dawadi, M. B. and Thapaliya, B. P. and Billinghurst, B. E.},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2017.06.013},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {C-H stretching bands,CH3-bending bands,CH3SH,Infrared spectra,Internal rotation,Methyl mercaptan,Torsion-vibration interactions},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
pages = {18--27},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Torsion-rotation structure and quasi-symmetric-rotor behaviour for the CH3SH asymmetric CH3-bending and C-H stretching bands of E parentage}},
volume = {343},
year = {2018}
}

As the axial angular momentum K increases, the energies of the coupled Òl = ±1Ó modes diverge linearly, with effective Coriolis $\zeta$ constants typical for symmetric tops. For the methyl-stretching states, separated at K = 0 by only about 1 cm_1, the assigned sub-bands follow a symmetric top $\Delta$(K _ l) = 0 selection rule, with only $\Delta$K = _1 transitions observed to the upper l = _1 in-plane A_ component and only $\Delta$K = +1 transitions to the lower l = +1 out-of-plane A_ component. The K = 0 separation of the CH3-bending states is larger at 9.1 cm_1 with the l-ordering reversed. @article{18LeXuTw,
abstract = {The infrared Fourier transform spectrum of the SÐH stretching fundamental band of 12CH332SH has been recorded using synchrotron radiation at the far-infrared beamline of the Canadian Light Source in Saskatoon. The SÐH stretch is a hybrid band predominantly of perpendicular b-type with a small parallel a-component. With both $\Delta$K = +1 and $\Delta$K = _1 sub-bands present, the assignments are well determined from ground-state combination difference relations. The identified sub-bands access SÐH stretching ground torsional substates from K_ = 0Ð14 for A and E torsional species. The substate origins have been obtained by expanding the term values in J(J + 1) power series, and have been fitted to a simple 6-parameter Fourier Hamiltonian to deduce the torsional energies. The oscillation amplitude of the SÐH stretching torsional curves is 0.547 cm_1 compared to 0.653 cm_1 for the ground state, implying an increase on the order of 6.9% in the torsional barrier height. The vibrational wavenumber for the SÐH stretch mode is found to be 2603.5 cm_1.},
author = {Lees, R. M. and Xu, Li Hong and Twagirayezu, S. and Perry, D. S. and Dawadi, M. B. and Billinghurst, B. E.},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2018.1451931/SUPPL_FILE/TMPH_A_1451931_SM0297.ZIP},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {CH3SH,Methyl mercaptan,SÐH stretching band,infrared spectra,internal rotation,torsionÐvibration interactions},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {23-24},
pages = {3554--3563},
publisher = {Taylor and Francis Ltd.},
title = {{FTIR synchrotron spectroscopy of the SÐH stretching fundamental of the 12CH332SH species of methyl mercaptan}},
url = {https://www-tandfonline-com.wwwproxy1.library.unsw.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1080/00268976.2018.1451931},
volume = {116},
year = {2018}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{17DuLiGa,
abstract = {The ultrahigh-resolution mid-infrared absorption spectrum of methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) was recorded and analyzed in the region of 2945Ð2953 cm-1, where the strong $\nu$2-band is located. Benefitting from the high-resolution of tunable laser absorption spectrometry (TLAS) with a distributed feedback interband cascade laser (DFB-ICL), 12-strong and 27-weak air-broadened absorption peaks belonging to the $\nu$2-band of CH3SH were assigned with resolution of better than 2.24_10-5 cm-1($\sim$26 fm/670 kHz) and absorption cross section precision of 2.0%, at temperature of 298.15 K and pressure of 1 atm. For further description of the assigned transitions, the spectral line parameters and cross sections of these absorption peaks versus pressure were investigated. These ultrahigh resolution air-broadened spectra can be used as reference data for CH3SH remote sensing and absolute spectral measurement applications.},
author = {Du, Zhenhui and Li, Jinyi and Gao, Hong and Luo, Gang and Cao, Xiuhan and Ma, Yiwen},
doi = {10.1016/J.JQSRT.2017.03.027},
issn = {0022-4073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Distributed feedback interband cascade laser (DFB-,Methyl mercaptan,Mid-infrared,Molecular spectral analysis,Tunable laser absorption spectrometry (TLAS),Ultrahigh-resolution spectrum},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jul},
pages = {123--129},
publisher = {Pergamon},
title = {{Ultrahigh-resolution spectroscopy for methyl mercaptan at the $\nu$2-band by a distributed feedback interband cascade laser}},
volume = {196},
year = {2017}
}

@article{18LeXuGu,
abstract = {High-resolution Fourier transform spectra of the asymmetric methyl-bending and methyl-stretching bands of CH3SH have been recorded employing synchrotron radiation at the FIR beamline of the Canadian Light Source. Analysis of the torsion-rotation structure and relative intensities has revealed the novel feature that for both bend and stretch the in-plane and out-of-plane modes behave much like a Coriolis-coupled l-doublet pair originating from degenerate E modes of a symmetric top. As the axial angular momentum K increases, the energies of the coupled Òl = ±1Ó modes diverge linearly, with effective Coriolis $\zeta$ constants typical for symmetric tops. For the methyl-stretching states, separated at K = 0 by only about 1 cm_1, the assigned sub-bands follow a symmetric top $\Delta$(K _ l) = 0 selection rule, with only $\Delta$K = _1 transitions observed to the upper l = _1 in-plane A_ component and only $\Delta$K = +1 transitions to the lower l = +1 out-of-plane A_ component. The K = 0 separation of the CH3-bending states is larger at 9.1 cm_1 with the l-ordering reversed. Here, both $\Delta$K = +1 and $\Delta$K = _1 transitions are seen for each l-component but with a large difference in relative intensity. Term values for the excited state levels have been fitted to J(J + 1) power-series expansions to obtain substate origins. These have then been fitted to a Fourier model to characterize the torsion-K-rotation energy patterns. For both pairs of vibrational states, the torsional energies display the customary oscillatory behaviour as a function of K and have inverted torsional splittings relative to the ground state. The spectra show numerous perturbations, indicating local resonances with the underlying bath of high torsional levels and vibrational combination and overtone states. The overall structure of the two pairs of bands represents a new regime in which the vibrational energy separations, torsional splittings and shifts due to molecular asymmetry are all of the same order, creating a challenging and complex vibration-torsion-rotation coupling environment.},

@article{20GuKr,
abstract = {Recent progress is reported on the assignment and fitting of a rotational spectrum of methylamine in the ground vibrational state and first and second torsional states. The high resolution infrared spectrum has been analyzed in the 40 to 360 cm_1 region with a resolution of 0.00125 cm_1. In the IR spectrum the complete RR and RQ series of rotational transitions were assigned up to high values of K and J, and for all symmetry species. For each set of rotational transitions a joint fit of all symmetry species has been carried out. The assigned transitions were fit to a single state model based on the group theoretical formalism of Hougen and Ohashi. The standard deviation of the fit for the ground state with K ² 20 and J ² 50 to 78 parameters was 0.00031 cm_1. The standard deviation of the fit for the first excited state with K ² 20 and J ² 45 to 89 parameters was 0.00066 cm_1, whereas for the second excited torsional state with K ² 14 and J ² 40 and with 95 parameters a standard deviation of 0.00207 cm_1 was obtained. About 8300 new infrared rotational transitions have been assigned in the ground, first and second torsional states using an original Loomis-Wood program dedicated to methylamine.},
author = {Gulaczyk, Iwona and Kr{\c{e}}glewski, Marek},
doi = {10.1016/J.JQSRT.2020.107097},
issn = {0022-4073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Effective Hamiltonian,Ground state,Large amplitude motions,Methylamine,Rotational transitions,Torsional states},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
pages = {107097},
publisher = {Pergamon},
title = {{IR rotational spectrum of methylamine}},
volume = {252},
year = {2020}
}

@article{10GuLoKr,
abstract = {The assignment of the wagging band, 9, of methylamine was extended to weak and perturbed series in a new high-resolution spectrum in the region from 640 to 960 cm-1 with extensive use of new Loomis-Wood software for Windows for the LAV molecules. Compared with previous reports, the number of assigned transitions in the wagging band (13,000) has been doubled. Most series extend as far as J = 40, even for symmetry species of lower statistical weight. For low K values (K_ = 0 and 1), even transitions of mixed type, E1+1 _ E1-1, have been observed. Several branches are strongly perturbed by Fermi and Coriolis-type resonances. An attempt to fit the observed transitions to a single-state model resulted in a standard deviation of 0.018 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 2010 Taylor & Francis.},
author = {Gulaczyk, Iwona and {\L}odyga, Wiesaw and Kr_glewski, Marek and Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2010.499114},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {Loomis-Wood diagram,high resolution infrared spectrum,methylamine,wagging band},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {18},
pages = {2389--2394},
title = {{Reinvestigation of the wagging band of methylamine}},
volume = {108},
year = {2010}
}

@article{11GuKrHo,
abstract = {For the first time the C-N stretching band of methylamine has been assigned in a high resolution spectrum in the region from 960 to 1200 cm-1. Over 3500 transitions with a resolution of 0.001 cm-1 for K from 0 to 12 have been assigned. A global fit has been made and the band center was determined at 1044.8134(33) cm-1. Several branches of the C-N band are strongly perturbed through Fermi and Coriolis type resonances. The sources of the perturbations have been identified - the fourth torsional state 4$\nu$15 and the combination state $\nu$9 + $\nu$15. An attempt to fit the observed transitions to a single state model based on the group theoretical formalism of Ohashi and Hougen [1] resulted in the standard deviation of 0.04 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Gulaczyk, Iwona and Kr_glewski, Marek and Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2011.09.003},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {C-N stretching,Coriolis and Fermi resonances,High resolution infrared spectrum,Loomis-Wood diagram,Methylamine},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {1},
pages = {70--74},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The C-N stretching band of methylamine}},
volume = {270},
year = {2011}
}

_@article{57GrLo,
abstract = {Methyl amine, methyl amine-d2, methyl-d3 amine and methyl-d3 amine-d2 of high chemical and isotopic purity have been synthesized and their infrared spectra studied at both prism and grating resolution. The rotation-vibration band centers of methyl amine have been measured with improved accuracy over previous investigations and with the aid of the spectra of the deuterium analogs a vibrational assignment differing in some important respects from those hitherto suggested has been made. The grating spectra in some cases show irregularities in the rotational fine structure but none which can be associated with effects due to hindered internal rotation. Recent studies in the microwave region have shown that these effects should not be observed within the resolution limits of the grating spectrometers used in this work. However, the first overtone of the torsional frequency in methyl amine, methyl amine-d2 and methyl-d3 amine has been observed in a position consistent with calculations based on a barrier height of 690 cm-1. The rotational structure of a number of unperturbed vibrational bands has been analyzed in terms of equations applicable to an approximate symmetric top and rotational constants have been obtained in good agreement with values calculated from parameters obtained from microwave investigations.},
author = {Gray, Allan P. and Lord, R. C.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1743369},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {3},
pages = {690--705},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Rotation-vibration spectra of methyl amine and its deuterium derivatives}},
url = {https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.1743369},
volume = {26},
year = {1957}
}

Recent studies in the microwave region have shown that these effects should not be observed within the resolution limits of the grating spectrometers used in this work. However, the first overtone of the torsional frequency in methyl amine, methyl amine-d2 and methyl-d3 amine has been observed in a position consistent with calculations based on a barrier height of 690 cm-1. The rotational structure of a number of unperturbed vibrational bands has been analyzed in terms of equations applicable to an approximate symmetric top and rotational constants have been obtained in good agreement with values calculated from parameters obtained from microwave investigations.},
author = {Gray, Allan P. and Lord, R. C.},

@article{20GuKrAs,
abstract = {For the first time the $\nu$4 NH2 scissors band has been assigned in a high-resolution infrared spectrum. A rotationally resolved spectrum of methylamine was recorded using two infrared spectroscopic techniques. A White-type multi-pass cell device coupled to the Bruker IFS 125 HR Fourier transform spectrometer was implemented on the AILES beamline at the SOLEIL synchrotron facility and a room-temperature spectrum of the whole band in the region of 1540Ð1710 cm_1 was recorded with a resolution of 0.001 cm_1. Then, a low-temperature high-resolution spectrum in the 1622.5Ð1655.6 cm_1 range of Q and R branches of the $\nu$4 band was recorded using a quantum cascade laser spectrometer. Preliminary assignment was carried out in the NH2 scissors band region, and about 2200 transitions for K from 0 to 6 have been assigned for A, B, and E1 symmetry species. The simultaneous fit of assigned lines using a group-theoretical effective Hamiltonian was not successful; instead simple polynomial series expansions were used for each symmetry and K value.},
author = {Gulaczyk, Iwona and Kr{\c{e}}glewski, Marek and Asselin, Pierre and Pirali, Olivier and Kleiner, Isabelle},
doi = {10.1139/cjp-2019-0469},
issn = {00084204},
journal = {Canadian Journal of Physics},
keywords = {High-resolution infrared spectrum,Laser spectrum,LoomisÐWood for Windows,Methylamine,NH2 scissors band},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {6},
pages = {560--566},
publisher = {NRC Research Press},
title = {{The NH2 scissors band of methylamine}},
url = {https://cdnsciencepub.com/doi/abs/10.1139/cjp-2019-0469 http://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/10.1139/cjp-2019-0469},
volume = {98},
year = {2020}
}

_@article{57GrLo,
abstract = {Methyl amine, methyl amine-d2, methyl-d3 amine and methyl-d3 amine-d2 of high chemical and isotopic purity have been synthesized and their infrared spectra studied at both prism and grating resolution. The rotation-vibration band centers of methyl amine have been measured with improved accuracy over previous investigations and with the aid of the spectra of the deuterium analogs a vibrational assignment differing in some important respects from those hitherto suggested has been made. The grating spectra in some cases show irregularities in the rotational fine structure but none which can be associated with effects due to hindered internal rotation. Recent studies in the microwave region have shown that these effects should not be observed within the resolution limits of the grating spectrometers used in this work. However, the first overtone of the torsional frequency in methyl amine, methyl amine-d2 and methyl-d3 amine has been observed in a position consistent with calculations based on a barrier height of 690 cm-1. The rotational structure of a number of unperturbed vibrational bands has been analyzed in terms of equations applicable to an approximate symmetric top and rotational constants have been obtained in good agreement with values calculated from parameters obtained from microwave investigations.},
author = {Gray, Allan P. and Lord, R. C.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1743369},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {3},
pages = {690--705},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Rotation-vibration spectra of methyl amine and its deuterium derivatives}},
url = {https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.1743369},
volume = {26},
year = {1957}
}

@article{01KiZe,
abstract = {The normal mode frequencies and the corresponding vibrational assignments of methylphosphine and selected deuterated methylphosphines are studied theoretically. The GAUSSIAN 98 quantum chemistry code was used at the HF, MP2 and DFT/B3LYP level of theory with the 6-311G**basis set. Comparison was made for the infrared spectra of methylphosphine and its deuterated isotopomers between our theoretically predicted values and the experimentally determined vibrational frequencies. Correction factors of the calculated frequencies compared to the experimental values are reported for methylphosphine and its deuterated isotopomers for predominant vibrational motions. The root mean square deviation is reported as a measure of the quality of the predicted frequencies compared to the experimental values. {\textcopyright} 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.},
author = {Kim, Hae Won and Zeroka, Daniel},
doi = {10.1016/S0166-1280(01)00506-1},
issn = {0166-1280},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure: THEOCHEM},
keywords = {Deuterated methylphosphines,Infrared spectra,Methylphosphine,Normal mode frequencies,Vibrational motion},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {1-3},
pages = {59--70},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{A theoretical study of methylphosphine CH3PH2 and selected isotopomers: vibrational analysis and infrared spectra}},
volume = {571},
year = {2001}
}

@article{62Wi,
abstract = {The low-resolution infrared spectra of methyl silane and methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 450-10,000 cm-1 region. All the fundamental frequencies are assigned to normal modes, and tentative assignments are given to many of the overtone and combination bands. The analyses of two parallel- and four perpendicular-type bands of methyl silane and of one parallel- and one perpendicular-type band of methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 2000-5000 cm-1 region. The combination difference-sum method of analysis is employed. In the case of the parallel bands, the rotational constants A_, B_, B_, and DJ are reported. In the case of the perpendicular bands, values are reported for A_, B_, $\zeta$i, and DK. The ground-state rotational constants A_ and B_ are obtainable from previous microwave studies. {\textcopyright} 1962.},
author = {Wilde, R. E.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(62)90042-5},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1-6},
pages = {427--454},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The infrared spectrum of CH3SiH3 and CH3SiD3}},
volume = {8},
year = {1962}
}

@article{09BoOzBa,
abstract = {The vibration-torsion-rotation spectrum of CH3SiH3 has been measured from 470 to 725 cm-1 at near-Doppler resolution. The full-width at half - maximum of the lines observed near 600 cm-1 was 0.0011 cm-1. The spectra were obtained using a Bruker IFS 125 HR Fourier transform spectrometer with the broadband source radiation being supplied from the synchrotron emission of the storage ring at the Canadian Light Source. Three vibrational bands were investigated: the lowest lying perpendicular fundamental $
u$12 centred near 524 cm-1, the lowest lying parallel fundamental $
u$5 near 703 cm-1, and the torsional hot band $
u$12 + $
u$6 - $
u$6 near 534 cm-1. For $
u$12 and $
u$5, the resolution and sensitivity are much improved over those in earlier studies, with many of the torsional multiplets now being resolved even in the cases where the upper levels are unperturbed. The primary motivation for the present work was the hot band, here reported for the first time, where the dependence of the silyl rock in $
u$12 on the torsional motion is much more pronounced. In addition, for the vibrational ground state (gs), two "forbidden" high torsional overtones v6 = 3 _ 0 and 5 _ 0 have been observed that become allowed through resonant mixing of the upper states with $
u$12 and $
u$5, respectively. In each case, two (K, $\sigma$) series have been measured where the mixing is largest. Here $\sigma$ = 0, 1, -1 labels the torsional sub-levels. Using the Fourier transform waveguide spectrometer at E. T. H., the three $\sigma$-components of the (J = 1 _ 0) transition in $
u$12 + $
u$6 were observed, and a series of direct l-doubling transitions in $
u$12 + $
u$6 were measured for $\sigma$ = 0. In a global fit, all the new data have been analysed along with the frequencies for other transitions obtained in earlier investigations. The analysis takes into account the relevant interactions among the torsional stacks of levels in the gs, $
u$12, and $
u$5. These include the previously known (gs, $
u$12) Coriolis-like and (gs, $
u$5) Fermi-like interactions along with a higher order ($
u$12, $
u$5) Coriolis-like coupling introduced here. This last is responsible for the strong perturbation of the $
u$5 series with K = 10, 11, and 12, and of the corresponding hot band series. A good fit to 9282 frequencies including 7942 new measurements was obtained both with the Free Rotor model in which the torsion is classified as a rotation, and with the High Barrier model in which the torsion is classified as a vibration. The Hamiltonian is discussed with emphasis on the new terms required for treating $
u$12 + $
u$6 - $
u$6. {	extcopyright} 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Borvayeh, L. and Ozier, I. and Bauder, A. and Moazzen-Ahmadi, N.},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2009.03.008},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Coriolis,Fermi,Infrared,Internal rotation,Methyl silane,Microwave,Synchrotron,Torsion,Vibration},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {2},
pages = {122--133},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High resolution infrared spectrum and global analysis of $
u$5, $
u$12, and $
u$12 + $
u$6 _ $
u$6 in CH3SiH3}},
volume = {255},
year = {2009}
}

@article{62Wi,
abstract = {The low-resolution infrared spectra of methyl silane and methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 450-10,000 cm-1 region. All the fundamental frequencies are assigned to normal modes, and tentative assignments are given to many of the overtone and combination bands. The analyses of two parallel- and four perpendicular-type bands of methyl silane and of one parallel- and one perpendicular-type band of methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 2000-5000 cm-1 region. The combination difference-sum method of analysis is employed. In the case of the parallel bands, the rotational constants A_, B_, B_, and DJ are reported. In the case of the perpendicular bands, values are reported for A_, B_, $\zeta$i, and DK. The ground-state rotational constants A_ and B_ are obtainable from previous microwave studies. {\textcopyright} 1962.},
author = {Wilde, R. E.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(62)90042-5},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1-6},
pages = {427--454},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The infrared spectrum of CH3SiH3 and CH3SiD3}},
volume = {8},
year = {1962}
}

@article{62Wi,
abstract = {The low-resolution infrared spectra of methyl silane and methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 450-10,000 cm-1 region. All the fundamental frequencies are assigned to normal modes, and tentative assignments are given to many of the overtone and combination bands. The analyses of two parallel- and four perpendicular-type bands of methyl silane and of one parallel- and one perpendicular-type band of methyl trideuterosilane are reported for the 2000-5000 cm-1 region. The combination difference-sum method of analysis is employed. In the case of the parallel bands, the rotational constants A_, B_, B_, and DJ are reported. In the case of the perpendicular bands, values are reported for A_, B_, $\zeta$i, and DK. The ground-state rotational constants A_ and B_ are obtainable from previous microwave studies. {\textcopyright} 1962.},
author = {Wilde, R. E.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(62)90042-5},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1-6},
pages = {427--454},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The infrared spectrum of CH3SiH3 and CH3SiD3}},
volume = {8},
year = {1962}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{12PrCeHo,
abstract = {The paper reports on the first high-resolution study of the weak $\nu$ 6 fundamental rovibrational band of monoisotopic chloroform HC 35Cl 3. More than 4500 infrared transitions pertaining to the $\nu$ 6 band have been assigned, spanning the rotational states J=0-95 and -73²K$\Delta$K²89. The new Fourier transform infrared data were combined with accurate submillimeter-wave transition frequencies in the v 6=1 state measured previously [Journal of Molecular Structure 795; 2006: 157-162] in a simultaneous fit. The existence of resonance crossings due to the $\Delta$k=±1, $\Delta$l=_2 l-type resonance in the v 6=1 state, which generated perturbation-allowed rotational transitions, provided independent values of the C and C$\zeta$ 6 constants. When we combined them with the wavenumbers of the fundamental $\nu$ 6 band, we were able to determine accurately the axial rotational constants in the vibrational ground state C 0=0.05715783 (20) cm -1, DK0=2.759 (63)10 -8cm -1, and even HK0=-8.27 (75)10 -14cm -1. {\textcopyright} 2012 Elsevier Ltd.},
author = {Pracna, Petr and Ceausu-Velcescu, Adina and Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2012.01.024},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Chloroform,Fundamental bands,High-resolution IR spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {11},
pages = {1220--1225},
publisher = {Pergamon},
title = {{The ground and $\nu$ 6=1 vibrational levels of HC 35Cl 3: The first high-resolution analysis of the $\nu$ 6 fundamental band}},
volume = {113},
year = {2012}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer

@article{99PiHoAn,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of chloroform in the region of the parallel fundamental band $\nu$3 around 367 cm_1 has been measured with a Fourier spectrometer at a resolution of 0.001 cm_1. An isotopically pure sample of CH35Cl3 was used. More than 5000 lines were assigned in the $\nu$3 band. A reanalysis of the ground state constants was performed by combining 1671 combination differences from this work, 712 differences from a previous study of the $\nu$2 band, and 80 millimetre wave lines from the literature. In the analysis of the $\nu$3 band, a model of an unperturbed symmetric top band was applied. The data were fitted with a standard deviation of 0.18 _ 10_3 cm_1, and the following leading parameters were obtained: $\nu$0 = 367.295 550(8) cm_1, B 3ÑB 0 = _77.058(4) _ 10_6 cm_1 and C 3ÑC 0 = _18.600(11) _ 10_6 cm_1. In addition, several hot bands have been studied. The isotopic effects were studied also by analysing spectra of the isotopically natural sample. {\textcopyright} 1999 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Pietil{\"{A}}, J. and Horneman, V. and Anttila, R.},
doi = {10.1080/00268979909483089},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {10},
pages = {1449--1456},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{High resolution infrared study of the parallel band $\nu$3 of chloroform CH35 Cl3}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268979909483089 http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268979909483089},
volume = {96},
year = {1999}
}

@article{95PaHoPi,
abstract = {The Fourier transform spectrum of the $\nu$2 band around 676 cm-1 of isotopically pure CH35Cl3 has been measured. The experimental resolution was near 0.0010 cm-1. In this parallel band more than 3000 rotational lines, with Jmax = 100 and Kmax = 56, were assigned. In the analysis a model for an unperturbed symmetric top band was applied. The fit of 2852 lines, with a standard deviation of 0.17 _ 10-3 cm-1, led, among others, to the following results: $\nu$0 = 676.643310(9) cm-1, B2 - B0 = -0.493903(6) _ 10-3 cm-1 and C2 - C0 = -0.109899(22) _ 10-3 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 1995.},
author = {Pasa, R. and Horneman, V. M. and Pietil{\"{a}}, J. and Anttila, R.},
doi = {10.1016/0009-2614(95)01212-7},
issn = {00092614},
journal = {Chemical Physics Letters},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {3},
pages = {277--282},
publisher = {North-Holland},
title = {{High-resolution study of the infrared band $\nu$2 of CH35Cl3}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0009261495012127},
volume = {247},
year = {1995}
}

@article{00PiHoAn,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of the perpendicular fundamental v5 of chloroform around 776 cm_1 has been studied by applying two high resolution methods. A short range from the central part of the spectrum was measured with a diode laser by using a cold jet sample including chloroform in natural isotopic abundancies. More than 100 rotational lines of 12CH35Cl3 could be assigned. The whole band region was measured by a Fourier transform spectrometer at a resolution of 0.0010cm_1. In this case an isotopically pure sample of 12CH35Cl3 was used. Starting from the results of the diode laser investigation more than 2000 lines could be assigned with Jmax = 91 and Kmax = 58. In addition to the infrared spectra, millimetre-wave lines also were measured. A total of 58 lines corresponding to J values 22, 23 and 35 at the excited vibration state v5 = 1 were assigned and analysed. All the data from three different spectra were simultaneously fitted and, for example, the results v0 = 775.961 50(3) cm_1, 98, B5-B0 = _0.180171(22) _ 10_3cm_1, C5 _ C0 = _0.170 57(15) _ 10_3cm_1, and (C$\zeta$)5 = 0.047 5294(11) cm_1 were obtained. {\textcopyright} 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Pietil{\'{A}}, J. and Horneman, V. and Anttila, R. and Lemoine, B. and Raynaud, F. and Colmont, J.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970009483321},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {9},
pages = {549--557},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{The perpendicular fundamental v5 of chloroform 12CH35Cl3: High resolution infrared study of the v5 band together with the millimetre-wave rotational spectrum}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970009483321 https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00268970009483321},
volume = {98},
year = {2000}
}

@article{04AnAlHo,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of the C-H bending vibration band $\nu$4 of chloroform around 1220 cm-1 has been measured with a Fourier transform spectrometer at an instrumental resolution of 0.0018 cm-1. An isotopically pure sample of CH35Cl3 was used. More than 3000 lines were assigned in the very congested spectrum. In the analysis the ground state rotational constants were fixed. The model included _(2, 2)-resonance and altogether 16 free parameters. The fit gave, for example, the molecular parameters $\nu$0= 1220.33803(5) cm-1, $\alpha$4B = 0.068 850 (37) _ 10-3 cm -1, $\alpha$4C = 0.01237(17) _ 10 -3 cm-1, (C$\zeta$)4 = 0.0560362(18) cm -1 and q4 = 0.17756 (15) _ 10-3 cm -1.},
author = {Anttila, R. and Alanko, S. and Horneman, V. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970410001725846},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {14-15},
pages = {1537--1542},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{The C-H bending vibration $\nu$4 of chloroform CH 35Cl3}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970410001725846 https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00268970410001725846},
volume = {102},
year = {2004}
}

@article{02PiAlHo,
abstract = {The C-H stretching fundamental band $\nu$1 (3033 cm-1) of chloroform CH35 Cl3 has been investigated together with the first overtone 2$\nu$1 (5941 cm-1) in order to determine the rotation vibration parameters. From the $\nu$1 band $\alpha$1C = 0.025 46(41)_10-3 cm-1 and $\alpha$1B = -0.010 688(44)_10-3 cm-1 were obtained. The hot bands connected to the low lying fundamentals $\nu$3 and $\nu$6 have been analyzed and anharmonicity constants have been derived. Both the parallel and the perpendicular component band of the C-H bending overtone 2$\nu$4 have also been studied. In the perpendicular band (2410 cm-1) more than 900 lines were included in the fit. In the parallel band (2410 cm-1) 2615 lines were fitted using a model with one resonance. Among other things the results C0 - C$\nu$ = 0.025 262 (20)_10-3 cm-1, B0 - B$\nu$ = 0.134 883 (25)_10-3 cm-1, and (C$\zeta$)$\nu$ = -0.111 867 56 (30) cm-1 were obtained. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Pietil{\"{a}}, J. and Alanko, S. and Horneman, V. M. and Anttila, R.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8627},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {271--283},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution infrared studies of $\nu$1, 2$\nu$1, and 2$\nu$4 bands of CH35Cl3}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022285202986273},
volume = {216},
year = {2002}
}

@article{18AlBaBe,
abstract = {We report high-resolution ((Formula presented.) 0.001 cm_1) Fourier Transform Infrared spectra of fluoroform (CHF3) including the pure rotational (far infrared or THz) range (28Ð65 cm_1), the $
u$3 fundamental ((Formula presented.) = 700.099 cm_1), as well as the associated Òhot' band 2$
u$3 _ $
u$3 ((Formula presented.) = 699.295 cm_1) and the Ôatmospheric window' range 1100Ð1250 cm_1 containing the strongly coupled polyad of the levels $
u$2, $
u$5 and $
u$3 + $
u$6, at room temperature and at 120 K using the collisional cooling cell coupled to our Bruker IFS 125 HR prototype (ZP2001) spectrometer and Bruker IFS 125 HR ETH-SLS prototype at the Swiss Light Source providing intense synchrotron radiation. The pure rotational spectra provide new information about the vibrational ground state of CHF3, which is useful for further analysis of excited vibrational states. The $
u$3 fundamental band is re-investigated together with the corresponding Ôhot' band 2$
u$3 _ $
u$3 leading to an extension of the existing line lists up to 4430 transitions with Jmax = 66 for $
u$3 and 1040 transitions with Jmax = 43 for 2$
u$3 _ $
u$3. About 6000 transitions were assigned to rovibrational levels in the polyad $
u$2/$
u$5/$
u$3 + $
u$6 with Jmax = 63 for $
u$2 ((Formula presented.) = 1141.457 cm_1), Jmax = 63 for $
u$5 ((Formula presented.) = 1157.335 cm_1) and Jmax = 59 for $
u$3 + $
u$6 ((Formula presented.) = 1208.771 cm_1)(Kmax = Jmax in each case). The resonance interactions between the $
u$2, $
u$5 and $
u$3 + $
u$6 states have been taken into account providing an accurate set of effective hamiltonian parameters, which reproduce the experimental results with an accuracy close to the experimental uncertainties (with a root mean square deviation drms = 0.00025 cm_1). The analysis is further extended to the $
u$4 fundamental ((Formula presented.) = 1377.847 cm_1) interacting with 2$
u$3 ((Formula presented.) = 1399.394 cm_1). The results are discussed in relation to the importance of understanding the spectra of CHF3 as a greenhouse gas and as part of our large effort to measure and understand the complete spectrum of CHF3 from the far-infrared to the near-infrared as a prototype for intramolecular quantum dynamics and rovibrational energy redistribution.},
author = {Albert, S. and Bauerecker, S. and Bekhtereva, E. S. and Bolotova, I. B. and Hollenstein, H. and Quack, M. and Ulenikov, O. N.},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2017.1392628},journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {CHF3,FTIR,THz,fluoroform,greenhouse gas absorption,high-resolution infrared spectroscopy,intramolecular quantum dynamics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {9},
pages = {1091--1107},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis},
title = {{High resolution FTIR spectroscopy of fluoroform 12CHF3 and critical analysis of the infrared spectrum from 25 to 1500 cm_1}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1080/00268976.2017.1392628},
volume = {116},
year = {2018}
}

@article{84DuQu,
abstract = {The absorption spectrum of trifluoromethane has been recorded between 900 and 14 000 cm-1 with resolutions between 0.004 and 0.5 cm -1 (pressure broadened). 22 bands were assigned as arising from the interacting CH stretching and bending manifolds, which account for most of the absorption in the overtone region. The results can be understood quantitatively with an effective, tridiagonal many-level Fermi resonance Hamiltonian. The experimental and theoretical results are summarized in Table II. The Hamiltonian is given in Table III and shows a very large stretching-bending interaction constant |ksbb|=106 cm-1, which is even larger than the diagonal anharmonic constant for the stretching vibration |x_ ss|=62 cm-1. This leads to extensive vibrational redistribution between stretching and bending motions at high levels of excitation. The time dependent redistribution is calculated with the spectroscopic Hamiltonian. A rotational analysis is presented for some of the bands involved in the Fermi resonance. The effect of the Fermi resonance on hot bands is investigated using the same Hamiltonian in comparison with experiment. The results are discussed in relation to the universal local dynamics of the isolated alkyl CH-stretching chromophore and in relation to the vibrational dynamics of highly excited polyatomic molecules as a function of certain elements of molecular structure. {\textcopyright} 1984 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {D{\"{u}}bal, Hans Rolf and Quack, Martin},
doi = {10.1063/1.448178},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {9},
pages = {3779--3791},
title = {{Tridiagonal Fermi resonance structure in the IR spectrum of the excited CH chromophore in CF3H}},
volume = {81},
year = {1984}
}

@article{03CeCoDe,
abstract = {An analysis of the v6 = 1 state of fluoroform is performed using rotational and high resolution infrared spectra. Previously radiofrequency data [Chem. Phys. Lett. 214 (1993) 265-270] and millimeter data [J. Mol. Spectrosc. 131 (1988) 1-8] were combined with new millimeter and infrared measurements, and a set of 27 parameters has been derived. A multiple fit analysis was performed confirming the assumption that the v6 = 1 excited state is not affected by intervibrational resonances.},
author = {Ceausu-Velcescu, A. and Cosl{\'{e}}ou, J. and Demaison, J. and Graner, G. and Duxbury, G. and B{\"{u}}rger, H.},
doi = {10.1016/S0022-2852(03)00132-2},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Rovibrational spectra of HCF3},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {291--297},
title = {{The v6 = 1 state of fluoroform, HCF3: Analysis of the rotational and vibrational spectra}},
volume = {220},
year = {2003}
}

@article{75DoHo,
abstract = {The resonance fluorescence spectrum of Cl 2 first observed by Rao and Venkateswarlu in 1962, has been photographed at high resolution and analyzed. The assignments of the lines have been revised and new resonance series have been observed. It is shown that the ground state of Cl 2 , dissociates into Cl atoms with no potential hill and that the dissociation energy isD 0 = 19 997.28 cm _1 .Vibrational and rotational constants and the R.K.R. curve of the ground state of Cl 2 have been determined. The long-range portion of the ground state potential of Cl 2 has been examined and shown to be consistent with the predictions of theory and measurements from the B 3 $\Pi$ 0 potential.},
author = {Douglas, A. E. and Hoy, A. R.},
doi = {10.1139/p75-246},
issn = {0008-4204},
journal = {Canadian Journal of Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {19},
pages = {1965--1975},
publisher = {Canadian Science Publishing},
title = {{The Resonance Fluorescence Spectrum of Cl 2 in the Vacuum Ultraviolet}},
url = {https://cdnsciencepub.com/doi/abs/10.1139/p75-246},
volume = {53},
year = {1975}
}

@article{Rochkind1965,
abstract = {Infrared studies of chlorine monoxide (16O and 18O) in the region 200-4000 cm-1 for both gas and condensed phases are presented. The spectra require reassignment of the stretching fundamentals and reveal the previously unknown bending fundamental. The new assignment (solid phase: v1 = 630.7, v2 = 296.4, v3 = 670.8 cm-1) results in a new value for the Cl-O bond stretching force constant, Kr=2.75 mdyn/{\AA}, which is strikingly lower than values previously cited. The bond in chlorine monoxide is proposed as the prototype Cl-O single bond. The low stretching-force constant indicates little ionic character in the Cl-O bond, in disagreement with conclusions based on nuclear quadrupole coupling data.},
author = {Rochkind, Mark M. and Pimentel, George C.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1696121},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {65RoPi},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {4},
pages = {1361--1368},
title = {{Infrared spectrum and vibrational assignment for chlorine monoxide, Cl 2O}},
volume = {42},
year = {1965}
}

@article{96XuMcBu,
abstract = {The v1 (symmetric stretch) and v3 (asymmetric stretch) fundamental bands of the semistable molecule ClOCl have been recorded and analyzed. This is the first high-resolution infrared study of dichlorine monoxide. The spectrum, which occurs in the 600 to 700 cm-1 region, is very dense, and its assignment was greatly aided by the results of previous microwave studies of the ground and excited vibrational states. About 5400 transitions belonging to the two most abundant isotopic forms, 35Cl16O35Cl and 35Cl16O37Cl, were assigned and fitted. For each isotope, the v1 and v3 bands were analyzed simultaneously in order to account for the Coriolis interaction which couples these vibrations. The band origins for the 35Cl16O35Cl isotope were determined to be v1 = 641.9694(1) cm-1 and v3 = 686.5936(1) cm-1. The Coriolis interaction parameter was determined to be Gc = 0.21087(2) cm-1, which corresponds to $\zeta$C13 = 0.928. {\textcopyright} 1996 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Xu, Yunjie and McKellar, A. R.W. and Burkholder, James B. and Orlando, John J.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1996.0010},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {68--72},
title = {{High-resolution infrared spectrum of the v1 and v3 bands of dichlorine monoxide, Cl2O}},
volume = {175},
year = {1996}
}

@article{94SaDuBl,
abstract = {The Fourier transform spectra of ClCN have been recorded between 2860 to 3030 cm_1 with a resolution of 0.0026 cm_1. The $\nu$1 + $\nu$3 and 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3 bands and the associated hot bands have been analyzed. A band-by-band analysis has been performed and also, for the first time, a global analysis has been made including all available data for the rotational and rovibrational energies of both 35Cl12C14N and 37Cl12C14N isotopomers. The 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3 band has been analyzed for the less abundant isotopic species 35Cl13C14N, 35Cl12C15N, and 37ClC14N.},
author = {{Saouli, A. Dubois, I. Blavier, J. F. Bredhol, H. Blanquet, G. Meyer, Cl. Meyer}, F.},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {349 -- 357},
title = {{Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrum of ClCN: Analysis of the $\nu$1 + $\nu$3, 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3, and Associated Hot Bands}},
volume = {165},
year = {1994}
}

abstract = {The Fourier transform spectra of ClCN have been recorded between 2860 to 3030 cm_1 with a resolution of 0.0026 cm_1. The $\nu$1 + $\nu$3 and 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3 bands and the associated hot bands have been analyzed. A band-by-band analysis has been performed and also, for the first time, a global analysis has been made including all available data for the rotational and rovibrational energies of both 35Cl12C14N and 37Cl12C14N isotopomers. The 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3 band has been analyzed for the less abundant isotopic species 35Cl13C14N, 35Cl12C15N, and 37ClC14N.},
author = {{Saouli, A. Dubois, I. Blavier, J. F. Bredhol, H. Blanquet, G. Meyer, Cl. Meyer}, F.},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {349 -- 357},
title = {{Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrum of ClCN: Analysis of the $\nu$1 + $\nu$3, 2$\nu$2 + $\nu$3, and Associated Hot Bands}},
volume = {165},
year = {1994}
}

@article{86BuScJa,
abstract = {Fourier transform infrared spectra of CIF and BrF have been measured with a resolution of 0.04 cm-1 in the region of the fundamental and first overtone with an accuracy of 2 and 4 x 10Ð3 cm-1, respectively. The rotational structure was resolved up to JÓ = 58/62 (CIF/BrF), and v0 values have been obtained from rotational analyses of the v 1 _0, 2 _ 1, 2 _0 and. in part, 3 _1 and 3 _0 vibrational bands. @article{70SeClHo,
abstract = {The infrared and Raman spectra of the interhalogens ClF3 and BrF3 have been studied in the vapor phase. @article{19Or,
abstract = {The $\nu$ 3 fundamental bands of 35 ClNO and 37 ClNO and the 2$\nu$ 3 -$\nu$ 3 band of 35 ClNO around 30 µm have been recorded using a high-resolution Fourier-transform spectrometer. The line-by-line analysis of the spectrum provides improved rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for the $\nu$ 3 fundamental band of 35 ClNO, and the first determination of these constants together with accurate band centers for the $\nu$ 3 band of 37 ClNO and for the 2$\nu$ 3 -$\nu$ 3 band of 35 ClNO. The band centers are 331.970996(28) cm _1 for the $\nu$ 3 fundamental band of 35 ClNO, 327.944735(78) cm _1 for the $\nu$ 3 fundamental band of 37 ClNO, and 329.962453(92) cm _1 for the 2$\nu$ 3 -$\nu$ 3 band of 35 ClNO.},
author = {Orphal, Johannes},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2019.03.024},issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {ClNO,High resolution,Infrared,NOCl,Nitrosyl chloride,ONCl,Spectroscopy},

title = {{High-resolution spectroscopy and analysis of the $\nu$ 3 bands of ClNO (nitrosyl chloride) around 30 µm}},

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{20AnKwMa,
abstract = {A new investigation of the $\nu$3 bands of 35ClNO2 and37ClNO2, located around 370 cm_1 has been performed using a high resolution (0.00102 cm_1) Fourier transform spectrum recorded at SOLEIL with highly improved experimental conditions as compared to previous work [Orphal J, Morillon-Chapey M, Klee S, Mellau GC, Winnewisser M. J Mol Spectrosc 1998;190:101Ð6]: (i) the use of synchrotron radiation which resulted in a better signal-to-noise ratio; (ii) a resolution twice better; (iii) a low temperature (221 K) with an optical path length of 8.16 m, allowing low pressure (0.025 hPa) in the sample leading to a well resolved spectrum. As a consequence, significantly better results than previously were obtained. Thanks to the new experimental conditions, the line assignments were pursued up to higher J and Ka quantum number values, J = 83 and Ka = 44. For both isotopomers, a total of 6331 transitions were reproduced with a root-mean-square deviation of 2 _ 10_4 cm_1 using a Watson-type A-reduced Hamiltonian. Improved rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for the $\nu$3 fundamental bands of 35ClNO2 and37ClNO2 have been determined. The band centers are 370.1510773(92) cm_1 for the $\nu$3 fundamental band of 35ClNO2 and 364.5218094(96) cm_1 for the $\nu$3 fundamental band of 37ClNO2. The synthetic line list obtained in this study could be interesting for future measurements of ClNO2 in the atmosphere, e.g. using the new space mission FORUM which is one of the concepts chosen by ESA to be developed further and which opens up a new window (150Ð1400 cm_1) for understanding and quantifying the radiative processes, as well as air quality and pollution effects.},
author = {Anantharajah, A. and {Kwabia Tchana}, F. and Manceron, L. and Orphal, J. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2020.107078},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {ClNO2,Far infrared high-resolution Fourier transform spe,Line positions,Nitryl chloride},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {107078},
publisher = {Elsevier Ltd},
title = {{New analysis of line positions of the $\nu$3 bands of 35ClNO2 and 37ClNO2 around 370 cm_1}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2020.107078},
volume = {253},
year = {2020}
}

@article{94DuKiGu,
abstract = {The FT-Raman spectra (2000-30 cm -1) of liquid and solid nitryl chloride, ClNO 2, along with the infrared spectra (2000-80 cm -1) of the gas and solid have been recorded. All six fundamentals are confidently identified and the potential energy distributions determined from the force fields obtained from ab initio calculations. Several different basis sets have been utilized to determine the harmonic frequencies and force constants which are compared to the previously reported valence force constants. Structural parameters have been calculated with these basis sets including electron correlation with MP2, MP3 and MP4 perturbation. The calculated equilibrium structural parameters are compared to the experimental r0 structural parameters. The spectra of the solid indicate that there are at least two molecules per primitive cell. All of these results are compared to the corresponding quantities for some similar molecules.},
author = {Durig, J. R. and Kim, Young Hae and Guirgis, G. A. and McDonald, J. K.},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {463--472},
title = {{FT-Raman and infrared spectra, r0 structural parameters, ab initio calculations and vibrational assignment for nitryl chloride}},
volume = {50},
year = {1994}
}

abstract = {The 12.6 µm region of nitryl chloride (ClNO2) has been recorded at high resolution (0.00102 cm_1) using a Fourier transform spectrometer and the SOLEIL synchrotron light source. ClNO2 was found during our studies of chlorine nitrate and, after fractional distillations it was introduced into a multipass White cell made of inert materials, with an optical path length of 5.4 m. 320 scans were recorded for the range 600Ð980 cm_1 at a total pressure of 0.23 hPa and a temperature of 250 K. u$6) = 774.6826(30) cm_1 for 37ClNO2 where the uncertainties are one standard deviation. Due to their sharp Q branches falling into an atmospheric ÒwindowÓ, the detection of the $
u$2 bands might be an advantageous route for future attempts to quantify atmospheric ClNO2, using infrared techniques.},

@misc{94OrMoGu,
abstract = {Nitryl chloride (ClNO2) is involved in heterogeneous stratospheric chemistry by the reaction of HCI with N2O5 on polar stratospheric cloud particles. The present work reports the first high-resolution infrared absorption spectra of nitryl chloride. We have recorded two infrared absorption spectra of ClNO2 at room temperature between 450 and 2450 cm-1 with a stepping-mode Fourier transform spectrometer at 0.0028 cm-1 nonapodized resolution. The spectrum shows rich. well-resolved rotational structure in the $\nu$6 (652 cm-1), $\nu$2 (792 cm-1), $\nu$1 (1268 cm-1), 2$\nu$6 (1318 cm-1), and $\nu$4 (1684 cm-1) bands. We have carried out a rotational analysis of the $\nu$4 band of 35ClNO2 around 1684 cm-1, leading to the assignment of 1691 b-type transitions. We have determined new rotational constants for the ground state, and the rotational constants for the v4 = 1 vibrational state. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Orphal, Johannes and Morillon-Chapey, Mireille and Guelachvili, Guy},
booktitle = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1994.1135},
issn = {1096083X},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {315--322},
title = {{The high-resolution infrared spectrum of nitryl chloride: Rotational analysis of the 35cino2 $\nu$4 band around 6 $\mu$m}},
volume = {165},
year = {1994}
}

@article{01DrMiCo,
abstract = {Pure rotational transitions of the chlorine monoxide radical have been observed up to v = 2 in the X12$\Pi$3/2 and X22$\Pi$1/2 states and transitions of the 35Cl18O isotopomer have been observed in natural abundance. Additionally, rotational transitions for levels up to J_ = 115/2 have been measured in the far infrared. These data have been merged with the existing microwave, submillimeter, and high-resolution infrared transition frequencies and fit simultaneously with a set of isotopically independent parameters. Isotopic substitution of both the Cl and O atoms has enabled the first determination of the electron spin-rotation constant $\gamma$ = -296.0(43) MHz as well as the Born-Oppenheimer corrections to the rotational constants. {\textcopyright} 2001 Academic Press.},
author = {Drouin, Brian J. and Miller, Charles E. and Cohen, Edward A. and Wagner, Georg and Birk, Manfred},
doi = {10.1006/JMSP.2001.8332},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {1},
pages = {4--9},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Further Investigations of the ClO Rotational Spectrum}},
volume = {207},
year = {2001}
}

@article{92PrBe,
abstract = {The red (A2$\Pi$i-X2$\Sigma$+) system of the CN free radical was produced in a jet-cooled coronaexcited supersonic expansion of helium using diazoacetonitrile as a precursor molecule. This spectrum was recorded with the McMath Fourier transform spectrometer of the National Solar Observatory. A total of 27 bands with v_ = 8 to 21 and v_ = 1 to 11 (LeBlanc bands) in the range 16570-22760 cm-1 were observed and rotationally analyzed. The line positions of this system were fitted along with those of the violet (B2$\Sigma$+-X2$\Sigma$+) system, infrared vibration-rotation data, and microwave data in a global fit. RKR potential energy curves were constructed for the X2$\Sigma$+, A2$\Pi$i, and B2$\Sigma$+ states of this molecule, and Franck-Condon factors were calculated for the vibrational bands of the A-X, and B-X systems. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {Prasad, C. V.V. and Bernath, P. F.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(92)90235-G},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {327--340},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Fourier transform jet-emission spectroscopy of the A2$\Pi$i-X2$\Sigma$+ transition of CN}},
volume = {156},
year = {1992}
}

@article{91Le,
abstract = {The Dunham parameters of the ground state of the CO molecule are determined by a least squares fit of recent high-quality microwave and heterodyne frequency measurements. It is shown that these new parameters are more accurate than others obtained recently. Revised equilibrium molecular constants have been deduced from these new Dunham parameters and the mass-scaling coefficients determined by Guelachvili el al. The most important constants are $\omega$e = 65 047 645(7) MHz, $\omega$e $\chi$e = 398 365-1(14) MHz, $\omega$e ye = 31211(14) MHz, Be = 57 907-98(6) MHz, $\alpha$e = 524-791(13) MHz, De = 0183 520 8(57) MHz and Re = 1-128 243(1) {\AA}. The new ground state parameters allow precise determination of the transition frequencies, which can now be used as secondary standards in the microwave and infrared ranges. {\textcopyright} 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {{Le Floch}, Andr{\'{e}}},
doi = {10.1080/00268979100100081},
file = {::},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {133--144},
publisher = {Andr{\'{e}} Le Floch},
title = {{Revised molecular constants for the ground state of CO}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?journalCode=tmph20},
volume = {72},
year = {1991}
}

@article{82KaJoHo,
abstract = {The pure rotational lines of H2O, the $\nu$2 band of CO2, and the $\nu$1 band of OCS were simultaneously recorded by a Fourier transform spectrometer. The resolution achieved was $\sim$0.0045 cm_1, and the precision of the line position was typically 3.6 _ 10_5 cm_1 or 1.2 MHz (standard deviation). The spectrum improves the accuracy of wave numbers of calibration lines in the region between 500 and 720 cm_1 by a factor of $\sim$10.},
author = {Kauppinen, J. and Jolma, K. and Horneman, V.-M.},

title = {{New wave-number calibration tables for H2O, CO2, and OCS lines between 500 and 900 cm_1}},

_@article{04MiBr,
abstract = {High-resolution near-infrared (4000-9000cm-1) spectra of carbon dioxide have been recorded using the McMath-Pierce Fourier transform spectrometer at the Kitt Peak National Solar Observatory. Some 2500 observed positions have been used to determine spectroscopic constants for 53 different vibrational states of the 16O12C16O isotopologue, including eight vibrational states for which laboratory spectra have not previously been reported. Calibration by simultaneous use of CO near 4200cm-1 and C2H2 near 6500cm-1 provides absolute line position accuracies of 6.0_10-5cm -1 (RMS) for strong, isolated transitions throughout the observed range. Fits with RMS errors <3.8_10-5cm-1 have been obtained for the 20013_00001, 20012_00001, and 20011_00001 bands, RMS errors <6_10-5cm-1 have been obtained for the 30014_00001, 30013_00001, 30012_00001, and 00031_00001 bands, and RMS errors <5_10-4cm -1 for even the weakest fitted bands. This work reduces CO 2 near-infrared line position uncertainties by a factor of 10 or more compared to the 2000 HITRAN line list, which has not been modified since the comprehensive work of Rothman et al. [J. Quant. Spectrosc. Rad. Transfer 48 (1992) 537]. The new line list satisfies the line position accuracies required for the next generation of CO2 remote sensing instruments, improves the capability of solar-viewing spectrometers to retrieve precise column CO 2 measurements, and provides a secondary frequency standard in the near-infrared. {\textcopyright} 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Miller, Charles E. and Brown, Linda R.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2003.11.001},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Calibration standards,Carbon dioxide,Near-infrared,Positions},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2 SPEC. ISS.},
pages = {329--354},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Near infrared spectroscopy of carbon dioxide I. 16O 12C16O line positions}},
volume = {228},
year = {2004}
}

@article{16NdPeKw,
abstract = {The high-resolution absorption spectra of phosgene (Cl2CO) has been recorded at 0.001 cm_1 resolution in the 250Ð350 cm_1 region by Fourier transform spectroscopy at synchrotron SOLEIL. To reduce the spectral congestion, the spectra have been recorded at low temperature (197 K) using a 93.14 m optical path length cryogenic cell. This enables the first detailed infrared analysis of the $\nu$3 bands of the 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO isotopologues of phosgene. Using a Watson-type Hamiltonian, it was possible to reproduce the upper state rovibrational infrared energy levels, together with, for 35Cl2CO, the available microwave data in the 31 excited state (Yamamoto et al. 1984) to within their experimental accuracy. In this way, accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants together with the following band centers: $\nu$0($\nu$3, 35Cl2CO) = 301.545622(17) cm_1 and $\nu$0($\nu$3, 35Cl37ClCO) = 298.199194(81) cm_1, were derived for the $\nu$3 bands of 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO.},
author = {Ndao, M. and Perrin, A. and {Kwabia Tchana}, F. and Manceron, L. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.12.001},
file = {::},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Far infrared,Hamiltonian constants,High-resolution spectra,Line position analysis,Phosgene,SOLEIL synchrotron},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
pages = {90--94},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{First far-infrared high resolution analysis of the $\nu$3 band of phosgene 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO}},
volume = {326},
year = {2016}
}

@article{16FlTcLa,
abstract = {A Fourier transform spectrum of phosgene (Cl2CO) has been recorded in the 22.5 $\mu$m spectral region at a resolution of 0.00102 cm_1 using a Bruker IFS125HR spectrometer coupled to synchrotron radiation leading to the observation of the $\nu$6 vibrational bands of the two isotopologues 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO. The corresponding upper state ro-vibrational levels were fit using Watson-type Hamiltonians. In this way it was possible to reproduce the upper state ro-vibrational levels to within the experimental uncertainty i.e. _0.30 _ 10_3 cm_1. Very accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants were derived from the fit together with the following band centers: $\nu$0($\nu$6,35Cl2CO) = 443.172062(15) cm_1, $\nu$0($\nu$6,35Cl37ClCO) = 440.534956(17) cm_1.},
author = {Flaud, J. M. and Tchana, F. Kwabia and Lafferty, W. J. and Manceron, L. and Ndao, M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.10.009},
file = {::},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {High resolution,Phosgene,Spectroscopic constants},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
pages = {87--89},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{First far-infrared high resolution analysis of the $\nu$6 band of phosgene 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO}},
volume = {326},
year = {2016}
}

@article{17FlKwLa,
abstract = {A Fourier transform spectrum of phosgene (Cl2CO) has been recorded in the 17.3-$\mu$m spectral region at a temperature of 180 K and at a resolution of 0.00102 cm_1 using a Bruker IFS125HR spectrometer coupled to synchrotron radiation, leading to the observation of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$4 vibrational bands of the two isotopologues 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO. The corresponding upper-state ro-vibrational levels were fit using a Hamiltonian model accounting for the A-type Coriolis interaction linking the rotational levels of the 21 and 41 vibrational states. In this way, it was possible to reproduce the upper-state ro-vibrational levels to within the experimental uncertainty, i.e. _0.30 _ 10_3 cm_1. Very accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion and interaction constants were derived from the fit, together with the following band centres: $\nu$0($\nu$2,35Cl2CO) = 572.526299(30) cm_1, $\nu$0($\nu$4,35Cl2CO) = 582.089026(30) cm_1, $\nu$0($\nu$2,35Cl37ClCO) = 568.951791(35) cm_1 and $\nu$0($\nu$4, 35Cl37ClCO) = 581.758279(35) cm_1.},
author = {Flaud, J. M. and {Kwabia Tchana}, F. and Lafferty, W. J. and Perrin, A. and Manceron, L. and Ndao, M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2017.1390616},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {Phosgene,high resolution,spectroscopic constants,$\nu$2,$\nu$4 bands},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {23-24},
pages = {3463--3467},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis},
title = {{First far-infrared high-resolution analysis of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$4 bands of phosgene 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1080/00268976.2017.1390616},
volume = {116},
year = {2018}
}

@article{17FlKwLa,

@article{15KwLaFl,
abstract = {Fourier transform spectra of phosgene (Cl2CO) have been recorded in the 11.75 and 5.47 $\mu$m spectral regions using a Bruker IFS125HR spectrometer at resolutions of 0.00102 and 0.0015 cm-1, respectively, leading to the observation of the v5 and v1 vibrational bands of the two isotopologues 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO. The corresponding upper state ro-vibrational levels were fit using Watson-type Hamiltonians and/or a Hamiltonian matrix accounting for resonance effects when necessary. In this way, it was possible to reproduce the upper state ro-vibrational levels to within the experimental accuracy, i.e. _0.17 _ 10-3 cm-1. Very accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion constants were derived from the fit together with the following band centres: v0(v5, 35Cl2CO) = 851.012737(20) cm-1, v0(v5, 35Cl37ClCO) = 849.995451(90) cm-1, v0(v2 + v3, 35Cl37ClCO) = 864.42370(50) cm-1, v0(v1, 35Cl2CO) = 1828.202514(40) cm-1 and v0(v1, 35Cl37ClCO) = 1827.246444(20) cm-1.},
author = {{Kwabia Tchana}, F. and Lafferty, W. J. and Flaud, J. M. and Manceron, L. and Ndao, M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268976.2015.1015638},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
keywords = {High-resolution infrared specta,Phosgene,Spectroscopy constants},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {21},
pages = {3241--3246},
title = {{High-resolution analysis of the v1 and v5 bands of phosgene 35Cl2CO and 35Cl37ClCO}},
volume = {113},
year = {2015}
}

@article{01PeFlBu,
abstract = {Concern about the implication of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in atmospheric ozone depletion has led to numerous measurements of the concentrations of halogen-containing compounds in the stratosphere. Of the various possible oxidation products of CFC's in the stratosphere, carbonyl chlorofluoride (COFCl) may receive special attention. High-resolution atmospheric infrared spectra are potential means of monitoring COFCl. However, there is little information on the spectroscopy of this molecule in the literature. We have therefore recorded spectra of pure 35Cl-enriched and natural samples of COFCl at ²0.0033 cm_1 resolution with the BRUKER Fourier transform spectrometer at the University of Wuppertal. We present here the first high-resolution analysis of the six fundamental bands v1 (CO stretching mode), v2 (C-F stretching mode), v3 (C-Cl stretching mode), v4 (CFCl bending mode), v5 (CFCl rocking mode), and v6 (out of plane bending mode) located at 1875.8256, 1095.0646, 764.3876, 501.5941, 408.8099, and 666.5862 cm_1, respectively, for the COF35Cl isotopic species of carbonyl chlorofluoride. The v3, v4, v5, and v6 bands which are mainly of A-type, B-type, B-type, and C-type, respectively, appear as unperturbed. On the other hand, both the v1 and v2 bands have a hybrid character (with both A- and B-type transitions), and the analysis of these two bands was complicated by numerous resonances. Excellent results are obtained for the unperturbed v3 - v6 bands and for the perturbed v2 band, but for the v1 band, the resonance scheme of which is more complex, the results of the analysis are slightly less satisfactory. {\textcopyright} 2001 Academic Press.},
author = {Perrin, A. and Flaud, J. M. and B{\"{u}}rger, H. and Pawelke, G. and Sander, S. and Willner, H.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2001.8415},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {122--132},
title = {{First high-resolution analysis of the six fundamental bands v1, v2, v3, v4, v5, and v6 of COF35Cl in the 340- to 2000-cm_1 region}},
volume = {209},
year = {2001}
}
