@article{13CoDrBr,
abstract = {The rotational spectrum of COF2 has been observed near 1, 1.6 and 2.5THz as part of a continuing program to precisely characterize the spectra of atmospheric molecules. THz spectra of the ground, $\nu$2, $\nu$3, $\nu$5, and $\nu$6 states have been assigned, combined with other available rotational data and high resolution infrared data, and fit in a single calculation up to JÅ90 for a wide range of Kc. Watson IIIlS or IrA parameters produce fits of essentially the same quality. A preliminary fit of the 2$\nu$6 band is also reported as well as all hot bands in the $\nu$6 region which originate in the states below 1000cm-1. The THz rotational spectrum of naturally abundant 13COF2 in its ground vibrational state has also been observed and fit separately as has the infrared spectrum of its $\nu$6 band. These results provide more accurate prediction of high J rotational spectra and infrared spectra of the fundamental vibrations below 1000cm-1. {\textcopyright} 2012 Elsevier Ltd.},
author = {Cohen, Edward A. and Drouin, Brian J. and Brown, Linda R. and Oh, Jung Jin},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2012.08.021},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Carbonyl fluoride,Frequencies,Hot bands,Infrared spectra,THz spectra},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {13--19},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Terahertz and infrared spectra of carbonyl fluoride, COF2: Vibration-rotation analyses of the four lowest bands, 2$\nu$6, and $\nu$6 hot bands; 13COF2 ground state and $\nu$6 band}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2012.08.021},
volume = {114},
year = {2013}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer

_@article{91CaPeFl,
abstract = {Using 0.0025-cm-1 resolution Fourier transform laboratory spectra, a thorough analysis of the $\nu$4 band of COF2 has been performed leading to an extensive (up to J = 77 and Ka = 46) and precise (±0.0002 cm-1) set of energy levels for the v4 = 1 vibrational state of this molecule. It proved not possible to reproduce these experimental levels when considering the v4 = 1 vibrational state as isolated, and it has been necessary to take into account the Coriolis-type resonance between the levels of this state and those of a nearby state located about 4 cm-1 below. In this way, an accurate band center ($\nu$0($\nu$4) = 1243.26609 ± 0.00014 cm-1) and rotational and coupling constants were derived. These constants were then used to generate a comprehensive list of line parameters suitable for high-resolution atmospheric studies. {\textcopyright} 1991.},
author = {Camy-Peyret, C. and Flaud, J. M. and Goldman, A. and Murcray, F. J. and Blatherwick, R. D. and Bonomo, F. S. and Murcray, D. G. and Rinsland, C. P.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(91)90303-R},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {481--490},
title = {{The $\nu$4 band of carbonyl fluoride}},
volume = {149},
year = {1991}
}

@article{97McDuMa,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of carbonyl fluoride, COF2, has been measured in the region from 1880 to 1980 cm_1using a Bruker Fourier transform spectrometer at 0.003 cm_1resolution and diode laser spectroscopy at Doppler-limited resolution. In this region the $
u$1band at 1945 cm_1dominates the spectrum and is in Fermi resonance with the 2$
u$2band at 1914 cm_1and in B-type Coriolis resonance with the 2$
u$3+ $
u$4band at 1936 cm_1. From the $
u$1band, 820 lines were successfully fitted using an S-type Watson Hamiltonian in theIIIlrepresentation, yielding rotational and fourth order centrifugal distortion constants, a Coriolis parameter of 0.00339(24) cm_1, and an obs-calc RMS of 0.0006 cm_1. Only 400 lines from 2$
u$2could be successfully fitted, with an obs-calc RMS of 0.0005 cm_1, because of interference from $
u$1over much of the 2$
u$2Rbranch.},
author = {McPhail, Mark J. W. and Duxbury, Geoffrey and May, Randy D.},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {118 -- 123},
title = {{The $
u$1, 2$
u$2, and 2$
u$3+ $
u$4Band System of Carbonyl Fluoride}},
volume = {182},
year = {1997}
}

@article{95RaBeDa,
abstract = {The vibration-rotation spectrum of CS was observed in emission in the spectral region 1000-1400 cm-1 with a Fourier transform spectrometer. The observed spectrum consists of nine $\Delta$$\nu$ = 1 vibration-rotation bands with $\nu$ ² 9. The present data combined with previous infrared and microwave measurements provide an improved set of molecular constants. {\textcopyright} 1995 Academic Press, Inc.},

year = {1995}
}

@article{88WeScMa,
abstract = {Heterodyne frequency measurements have been made on the $\nu$3 band of both 12CS2 and 13CS2 near 1500 cm-1. The data were fitted and new molecular constants determined. title = {{Calibration tables covering the 1460- to 1550-cm-1 region from heterodyne frequency measurements on the $\nu$3 bands of 12CS2 and 13CS2}},
volume = {132},
year = {1988}
}

@article{70FrBlBe,
abstract = {The Raman and infrared spectra of thiophosgene and its dimer have been reinvestigated and assignments based on new data and a normal coordinate analysis of the monomer are presented. The spectra obtained in gas, liquid, and solid phases are compared and two polymeric species and their spectra are discussed. A description of the fundamentals of thiophosgene is presented in terms of atom displacements, potential energy distributions, and Coriolis coupling coefficients. The transferability of the valence force field between thiophosgene and phosgene is demonstrated.},
author = {Frenzel, C. A. and Blick, K. E. and Bennett, C. R. and Niedenzu, K.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1673765},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {198--204},
title = {{Investigations of the Raman and infrared spectra of thiophosgene and polymeric species}},
volume = {53},
year = {1970}
}

@article{10McBi,
abstract = {Thiophosgene (Cl2CS) is a favorite model system for studies of photophysics, vibrational dynamics, and intersystem interaction effects. But there are no previous rotationally-resolved infrared studies because the spectra are very congested due to hot bands and multiple isotopic species. This paper reports a detailed study of the $\nu$2 (_504 cm-1) and $\nu$4 (_471 cm-1) fundamental bands for the two most abundant isotopomers, 35Cl2CS and 35Cl37ClCS, based on spectra with observed line widths of _0.0008 cm-1 obtained at the Canadian Light Source far-infrared beamline using synchrotron radiation and a Bruker IFS125 Fourier transform spectrometer. Crown Copyright {\textcopyright} 2009.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Billinghurst, B. E.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2009.12.004},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Infrared,Synchrotron,Thiophosgene},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {66--71},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron infrared spectroscopy of thiophosgene: The $\nu$2 and $\nu$4 fundamental bands near 500 cm-1}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2009.12.004},
volume = {260},
year = {2010}
}

@article{15McBi,
abstract = {Abstract Thiophosgene (Cl2CS) is a favorite model system for studies of photophysics, vibrational dynamics, and intersystem interactions. But its infrared spectra tend to be very congested due to hot bands and multiple isotopic species. This paper reports the first detailed study of the $\nu$1 (_1139 cm-1) and $\nu$5 (_820 cm-1) fundamental bands for the two most abundant isotopologues, 35Cl2CS and 35Cl37ClCS, based on spectra with a resolution of about 0.001 cm-1 obtained at the Canadian Light Source far-infrared beamline using synchrotron radiation and a Bruker IFS125 Fourier transform spectrometer. The 2$\nu$4 (_942 cm-1) and $\nu$2 + 2$\nu$6 (_1104 cm-1) bands are also studied here, but the $\nu$2 + $\nu$6 band (_795 cm-1) resisted full analysis.},
author = {McKellar, A. R.W. and Billinghurst, B. E.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.01.003},issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Infrared,Synchrotron,Thiophosgene},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {24--29},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron infrared spectroscopy of thiophosgene: The $\nu$1, $\nu$5, 2$\nu$4, and $\nu$2 + 2$\nu$6 bands}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2015.01.003},
volume = {315},
year = {2015}
}

@article{94MaBeSa,
abstract = {The high-resolution stimulated Raman spectrum of F2 has been recorded with a quasi cw technique. Q branches of the fundamental and first hot band have been fully resolved. Forty-one transitions of the Q branch of the fundamental up to J = 43 have been measured, in addition to 21 transitions of the O and S branches of this band. Twenty-one transitions of the Q branch of the first hot band up to J = 27 have also been measured. From the analysis of these data a more accurate set of molecular parameters for the v = 0, v = 1, and v = 2 states of this molecule has been derived. From our data and some previous fluorescence data a new set of equilibrium parameters is also proposed. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Martinez, R. Z. and Bermejo, D. and Santos, J. and Cancio, P.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1994.1283},
file = {::},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {343--349},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution stimulated raman spectrum of F2}},
volume = {168},
year = {1994}
}

Journal: _Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
BibTex_Code:
@article{87Ta,
abstract = {Portions of the v3, asymmetric stretch band of OF2 have been measured under conditions of Doppler-limited resolution and the frequencies of 176 transitions measured with a nominal accuracy of 0.001 cm_1. The remaining band constants were determined by constraining the ground state parameters to the values determined earlier and carring out a simultaneous fit of the existing infrared and v3 = 1 microwave data. No evidence for the anticipated effects of weak Coriolis coupling for levels with K_1 _ 16 and J _ 30 was observed although such effects may present in levels with much higher quantum numbers. {\textcopyright} 1987, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.},
author = {Taubmann, Gerhard},
doi = {10.1515/zna-1987-0115},
issn = {18657109},
journal = {Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {87--90},
publisher = {Verlag der Zeitschrift f{\"{u}}r Naturforschung},
title = {{Diode Laser Spectroscopy of the v3 Band of OF2}},
url = {https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/zna-1987-0115/html},
volume = {42},
year = {1987}
}

@article{86TaJoRu,
abstract = {An analysis of the strong Fermi resonance between $\nu$1 and 2$\nu$2 in OF2 in which a varying degree of wavefunctions mixing was considered has been carried out. Apparently anomalous distortion constants in (1, 0, 0) and (0, 2, 0) were explained on this basis. Some 350 transition frequencies were fitted to determine accurate effective band constants for both $\nu$1 and 2$\nu$2. The unperturbed band parameters and the cubic force constant, k122, were evaluated. {\textcopyright} 1986.},
author = {Taubmann, Gerhard and Jones, Harold and Rudolph, H. D. and Takami, Michio},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(86)90072-X},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {1},
pages = {90--100},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Diode laser spectroscopy of the $\nu$1 2$\nu$2 Fermi diad of OF2}},
volume = {120},
year = {1986}
}

@article{82OhNo,
abstract = {The vibrational spectrum of thionyl fluoride, SOF2, has been reinvestigated by means of high resolution infrared and Raman spectroscopy. Substitution of oxygen-16 by oxygen-18 led to a definitive identification of those modes to which sulfur-oxygen motion makes a large contribution. The band structure of the sulfur-oxygen stretching vibration, which is obscured by Fermi resonance with a combination band in S16OF2, has been resolved in S18OF2. The experimental isotopic splittings are compared with those calculated by previous investigators. {\textcopyright} 1982.},
author = {O'Hara, T. J. and Noftle, R. E.},
doi = {10.1016/S0022-1139(00)82202-2},
issn = {00221139},
journal = {Journal of Fluorine Chemistry},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {149--156},
title = {{The vibrational spectrum of thionynyl fluoride and its oxygen-18 isotopomer[1]}},
volume = {20},
year = {1982}
}

@article{82OhNo,
abstract = {The vibrational spectrum of thionyl fluoride, SOF2, has been reinvestigated by means of high resolution infrared and Raman spectroscopy. Substitution of oxygen-16 by oxygen-18 led to a definitive identification of those modes to which sulfur-oxygen motion makes a large contribution. The band structure of the sulfur-oxygen stretching vibration, which is obscured by Fermi resonance with a combination band in S16OF2, has been resolved in S18OF2. The experimental isotopic splittings are compared with those calculated by previous investigators. {\textcopyright} 1982.},
author = {O'Hara, T. J. and Noftle, R. E.},
doi = {10.1016/S0022-1139(00)82202-2},
issn = {00221139},
journal = {Journal of Fluorine Chemistry},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {149--156},
title = {{The vibrational spectrum of thionynyl fluoride and its oxygen-18 isotopomer[1]}},
volume = {20},
year = {1982}
}

@article{03DaNeSm,
abstract = {The high-resolution vibration-rotation spectrum of the $\nu$2 fundamental band of gas-phase thionyl fluoride, SOF2 has been observed centred at 808 cm-1. Spectra were recorded in absorption using a Fourier-transform spectrometer with the sample of SOF2 held in a gas cell at a temperature of 294 K. In total, 1929 a- and c-type vibration-rotation transitions of the most abundant isotopomer, 32S16OF2, have been assigned and included in a least-squares fit. The least-squares analysis, performed using a standard semi-rigid rotor Hamiltonian, has yielded precise spectroscopic parameters for the $\nu$2 = 1 level. The analysis confirms the assignment of the band to excitation of the symmetric S-F stretching vibration. Additional, partially resolved features are attributed to the Q-branches of the $\nu$2 fundamental band of 34S16OF2 and of $\nu$2 difference bands from low-lying excited vibrational levels.},
author = {Davies, Cari J. and Newnham, David A. and Smith, David M.},
doi = {10.1039/b210153j},
issn = {14639076},
journal = {Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {446--450},
title = {{High-resolution Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy of the $\nu$2 fundamental band of thionyl fluoride, SOF2}},
volume = {5},
year = {2003}
}

@article{85JoLiTa,
abstract = {Diode laser spectroscopy measurements have been carried out in the $\nu$1 band (CF stretch) region of three isotopic forms of cyanogen fluoride (normal FCN, FC15N, and F13CN). Wave-numbers of infrared transitions were determined with a nominal accuracy of ±0.001 cm-1, and were combined with all the available microwave data to produce constants for the bands (1, 0, 0) _ (0, 0, 0), (1, 11, 0) _ (0, 11, 0), (1, 20, 0) _ (0, 20, 0), and (1, 22, 0) _ (0, 22, 0) for normal FCN and FC15N, and (1, 0, 0) _ (0, 0, 0) and (1, 11, 0) _ (0, 11, 0) for F13CN. {\textcopyright} 1985.},
author = {Jones, Harold and Lindenmayer, Josef and Takami, Michio},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(85)90273-5},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {339--354},
title = {{The $\nu$1 fundamental and associated hot bands of three isotopic forms of cyanogen fluoride by diode laser spectroscopy}},
volume = {113},
year = {1985}
}

@article{97FaBrDu,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of cyanogen fluoride (FCN) in the 1800 to 2800 cm-1 region has been recorded with a Fourier transform spectrometer at an instrumental resolution of 0.0026 cm-1. A total of 6822 absorption lines have been measured with an accuracy better than 6 _ 10-4 cm-1. Forty-nine bands of 19F12C14N, twelve of 19F13C14N, and four of 19F12C15N have been analyzed. For these bands, the band origins and rotational constants Bv, D11, H11, and Lv as well as qv qDv, and q are reported. We have also detected for the first time a perturbation in the 3000 vibrational state. This perturbation is interpreted as due to an indirect effect of the two first-order anharmonic resonances between 3000 and 0201. {\textcopyright} 1997 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Farkhsi, A. and Bredohl, H. and Dubois, I. and Remy, F. and Fayt, A.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1996.7141},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {119--126},
title = {{Fourier transform infrared spectrum of FCN: The 1800-2800 cm-1 spectral range}},
volume = {181},
year = {1997}
}

@article{03PeKeFl,
abstract = {This work, besides its fundamental interest is mainly motivated by the atmospheric importance of formaldehyde. The 10-$\mu$m region is indeed a possible spectral domain for the detection of this molecule in the atmosphere and no line parameters are presently available in the atmospheric databases for H2CO in this spectral range. Using the experimental data available in the literature for the v3, v4 and v6 bands [J. Chem. Phys. 91 (1989) 646 and references therein] and for the v2(band [J. Mol. Spectrosc. 96) (1982) 353 and references therein] and adequate theoretical models it proved possible to reproduce satisfactorily the experimental data and to generate a list of line positions and intensities for the 5-10 $\mu$m region. The Hamiltonian model accounts for the various Coriolis-type resonances which perturb the energy levels of the 31, 41, and 61 vibrational states as well as for the weaker anharmonic resonances coupling the 21 and 31 energy levels. This is also the case for the line intensity calculations which allow one to reproduce satisfactorily the line by line intensity measurements as well as the integrated available in the literature.},
author = {Perrin, A. and Keller, F. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1016/S0022-2852(03)00207-8},
isbn = {3316915753},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {192--198},
title = {{New analysis of the v2, v3, v4 and v6 bands of formaldehyde H212C16O line positions and intensities in the 5-10 $\mu$m spectral region}},
volume = {221},
year = {2003}
}

@article{76CaFl,
abstract = {The constants involved in the rotational expansion of the transformed transition moment operator of the v2 band of H216O have been determined through a fit of about 110 measured line intensities. A comparison between theoretical and experimental values of these constants is given. The coefficient 2$\mu$x of the expansion of the dipole moment with respect to normal coordinates is deduced to be 2$\mu$x= 0{\textperiodcentered}1.7946 ± 0{\textperiodcentered}0020 D. Moreover, a knowledge of the transformed transition moment operator has been used to compute the whole spectrum of the v2 band. {\textcopyright} 1976 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Camy-Peyret, C. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268977600103261},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {523--537},
title = {{Line positions and intensities in the v2 band of H216O}},
volume = {32},
year = {1976}
}

@article{56BeGaPl,
abstract = {Spectra of heavy water have been obtained under high resolution between 1.25-4.1$\mu$ (2400-8000 cm-1). Approximately 4500 lines have been measured, and the majority of them analyzed into ten bands of D2O and nine bands of HDO. The analysis is described in some detail, spectra of all bands are shown and a partial table of lines and a complete table of energy levels are presented. The vibration-rotation constants are derived and compared with those of H2O.},
author = {Benedict, W. S. and Gailar, N. and Plyler, Earle K.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1742731},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {6},
pages = {1139--1165},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Rotation-vibration spectra of deuterated water vapor}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1680328},
volume = {24},
year = {1956}
}

@article{96UlMaKo,
abstract = {The high resolution infrared spectrum of H2S has been recorded on a Fourier transform spectrometer Bruker IFS 120 HR in the region of the fundamental band v2 with an instrumental resolution of about 0.0020 cm-1. Lines have been assigned to the v2 bands of the isotopic species H232S, H234S, and H233S and in addition to the hot band 2v2 - v2 of H232S. In the case of the fundamental band of H232S, 226 upper state energy levels with Jmax = 17 were obtained and fitted with a standard deviation of 9.96 _ 10-5 cm-1. For H234S, 126 energy levels with Jmax = 14 were obtained, and for H233S, 57 lines could be assigned, {\textcopyright} 1996 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Ulenikov, O. N. and Malikova, A. B. and Koivusaari, M. and Alanko, S. and Anttila, R.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1996.0082},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {2},
pages = {229--235},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{High resolution vibrational-rotational spectrum of H2S in the region of the v2 fundamental band}},
volume = {176},
year = {1996}
}

@article{98BrCrCr,
abstract = {The two triad systems of hydrogen sulfide (2$
u$2, $
u$1, and $
u$3 near 4 $\mu$m and 3$
u$2, $
u$1 + $
u$2, and $
u$2 + $
u$3 near 2.7 $\mu$m) were analyzed using 14 spectra recorded at 0.0056 and 0.011 cm-1 resolution with the McMath Fourier transform spectrometer located at Kitt Peak National Observatory. Experimental upper state levels of H232S, H234S, and H233S were obtained from assigned positions (as high as J= 20 and Ka = 15 for the main isotope). These were fitted to the A-reduced Watson Hamiltonian to determine precise sets of rotational constants through J10 and up to nine Fermi and Coriolis coupling parameters. Intensities of the two H232S triads were modeled with rms values of 2.5%, using the transformed transition moment expansion with 19 terms for 568 intensities of the first triad and 11 terms for the 526 intensities of the second triad. The second derivatives of the dipole moment with respect to normal coordinates were estimated in Debye to be: 22$\mu$x = -0.004873 (90); 12$\mu$x = 0.01372 (30); and 23$\mu$z 0.01578 (30). This confirmed that for hydrogen sulfide some of the second derivatives are larger than the first derivatives. The calculated line intensities were summed yielding integrated band strengths (in cm-2/atm at 296 K) as follows: 0.3315 for 2$
u$2, 0.4522 for V1, 0.1201 for $
u$3, 0.0303 for 3$
u$2, 1.820 for $
u$1 + $
u$2, and 2.869 for $
u$2 + $
u$3. In addition, the hot band transitions were identified in both regions. Finally, a composite database of hydrogen sulfide line parameters was predicted for the 5- to 2.5-$\mu$m region, {	extcopyright} 1998 Academic Press.},

u$2, $

u$2, and $
u$2 + $
u$3) triad regions}},
volume = {188},

}

@article{99PaHiLe,
abstract = {The authors report new high-resoln. IR emission spectra of DCl. Vibration-rotation line position of the .nu. = 1 .fwdarw. 0, 2 .fwdarw. 1, 3 .fwdarw. 2 and 4 .fwdarw. 3 bands of D37Cl, and of the .nu. = 1 .fwdarw. 0, 2 .fwdarw. 1 and 3 .fwdarw. 2 of D35Cl were measured. Sep. sets of band consts. were detd. for D35Cl and D37Cl. A combined isotopomer anal. was then performed together with analogous high-quality literature data for H35Cl and H37Cl to det. the Born-Oppenheimer breakdown correction. The results are compared to literature IR and microwave data. (c) 1999 Academic Press.},
author = {Parekunnel, Treana and Hirao, Tsuyoshi and {Le Roy}, Robert J. and Bernath, Peter F.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1999.7824},

journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},

month = {may},

pages = {185--191},
publisher = {Elsevier BV},
title = {{FTIR Emission Spectra and Molecular Constants for DCl}},
volume = {195},
year = {1999}
}

@article{00MaMeKl,
abstract = {High-resolution measurements have been made on the infrared emission spectrum of H12C14N, H12C15N, and H13C14N at temperatures on the order of 1370 K. The measurements cover the region 400-850 cm-1 with a resolution of 0.006 cm-1. New room-temperature absorption measurements are also reported for H13C14N in the regions, 1200-1500 cm-1 and 2500-3700 cm-1. These measurements are combined with earlier measurements to obtain improved values for the rovibrational constants for these three isotopomers. The high temperatures allowed us to measure the bending vibrational levels up to the 01111 0 state, at more than 7900 cm-1 above the ground vibrational level, for H12C15N and H13C14N, and the 01010 0 state for H12C14N. The Coriolis interaction responsible for the laser transitions of H12C14N and H12C15N has also been observed, for the first time, for H13C14N. New re values are given using the Be values found in this paper and in a recent paper on deuterated isotopomers.},
author = {Maki, A. G. and Mellau, G. Ch and Klee, S. and Winnewisser, M. and Quapp, W.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2000.8113},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {bending vibrations,bond distances,constants,coriolis perturbations,emission spectra,hcn,infrared spectra,isotope shifts,molecular spectra,rovibrational},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {67--82},
title = {{High-temperature infrared measurements in the region of the bending fundamental of H12C14N, H12C15N, and H13C14N}},
volume = {202},
year = {2000}
}

@article{78JoMcRi,
abstract = {The $\nu$3 fundamental band (0-0 stretch; $\nu$0=1097. 626 cm-1) of the hydroperoxyl radical HO2 has been studied using the technique of laser magnetic resonance, in which molecular transitions are tuned into resonance with fixed laser lines by means of the Zeeman effect. The HO2 was produced by reacting O atoms with methyl or allyl alcohol in a flow system incorporating an absorption cell inside the CO2 laser cavity. Over 200 resonances involving different MJ components of a-type HO2 transitions with 1²N²7 and 0²K a²4 were assigned, and from an analysis of the spectra the band origin and excited state rotational, centrifugal distortion, and spin-rotation interaction parameters were determined. The possible application of these results to the remote spectroscopic detection of HO2 is discussed. {\textcopyright} 1978 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Johns, J. W.C. and McKellar, A. R.W. and Riggin, M.},
doi = {10.1063/1.436308},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {9},
pages = {3957--3966},
title = {{Laser magnetic resonance spectroscopy of the $\nu$3 fundamental band of HO2 at 9.1 $\mu$m}},
volume = {68},
year = {1978}
}

@article{88DaLaCu,
abstract = {The high resolution infrared spectrum of the CH stretching fundamental of the formyl radical (HCO) has been observed by means of infrared kinetic spectroscopy using 308 nm (XeCl) excimer laser flash photolysis of formaldehyde or acetaldehyde followed by diode or difference frequency laser probing of the transient absorption. The high resolution spectra obtained were assigned and fitted with rotational, spin-rotational, and centrifugal distortion constants. The $\nu$1 band origin is 2434.48 cm-1. New ground-state constants are reported from a least-squares fit combining this $\nu$1 data with previous microwave and FIR LMR measurements. {\textcopyright} 1988 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Dane, C. Brent and Lander, D. R. and Curl, R. F. and Tittel, F. K. and Guo, Yili and Ochsner, Martin I.F. and Moore, C. Bradley},
doi = {10.1063/1.454095},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {4},
pages = {2121--2128},
title = {{Infrared flash kinetic spectroscopy of HCO}},
volume = {88},
year = {1988}
}

@article{79StWiWi,
abstract = {The high resolution infrared spectrum between 465 and 1100 cm-1 of HNCO, a quasilinear slightly asymmetric-top molecule is presented. An identification consistent with the microwave and far-infrared data is made for the ground state and the first excited states of the three angle-bending vibrations. The analysis confirms the assignment of the out-of-plane vibration $\nu$6 as the band with band origin at about 600 cm-1, in agreement with the original assignment of Herzberg and Reid. {\textcopyright} 1979.},
author = {Steiner, D. A. and Wishah, K. A. and Polo, S. R. and McCubbin, T. K.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(79)90233-9},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {1-3},
pages = {341--373},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of isocyanic acid between 465 and 1100 cm-1}},
volume = {76},
year = {1979}
}

@article{97BrBeCr,
abstract = {The authors report the 1st gas-phase Raman spectra of the N-C-O stretching fundamentals in isocyanic acid. Using stimulated Raman excitation to prep. vibrationally excited mols., the authors record spectra via two different techniques, photoacoustic Raman spectroscopy and action spectroscopy. The former detects the sound wave generated as the Stokes laser tunes through resonances and deposits heat in the gas sample. The latter detects transitions by photodissociating the vibrationally excited states prepd. in the vibrational excitation step and detecting the photofragments by laser induced fluorescence. In analogy with the stretching modes in CO2, the N-C-O sym. stretch ($\nu$3) Raman fundamental in HNCO is strong while the antisym. stretch ($\nu$2) is weak, although neither is symmetry forbidden. Both vibrational states are strongly perturbed. The sym. stretch interacts with combination states that contain two quanta of bending excitation, and the antisym. stretch interacts with several different combination states. Both Raman spectra have strong QQ branch rotational structure in which the band origins for different K sublevels in this near-prolate sym. top follow no simple pattern. Photodissocn. of the vibrationally excited states demonstrates the influence of the initial state prepn. on the rotational resonances, photofragment appearance thresholds, and Franck-Condon factors in the transition to a dissociative excited electronic state. [on SciFinder(R)]},
author = {Brown, Steven S. and Berghout, H. Laine and Crim, F. Fleming},
doi = {10.1063/1.475274},
issn = {0021-9606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {23},
pages = {9764--9771},
title = {{Raman spectroscopy of the NÐCÐO symmetric ($\nu$3) and antisymmetric ($\nu$2) stretch fundamentals in HNCO}},
volume = {107},
year = {1997}
}

@article{83StPoMc,
abstract = {The $
u$2 fundamental band of HNCO has been observed for the first time under a resolution of 0.015 cm-1. The band origin for this NCO antisymmetric stretching vibration is found to be at 2268.893 cm-1, rather distant from the previously reported value of 2274 cm-1. Nineteen subbands have been analyzed and term values for both ground and $
u$2 states with K up to 4 have been obtained. Effective rotational constants B and centrifugal distortion constants D and H have also been determined. Interactions are observed with 2$
u$4 + $
u$5 and $
u$3 + $
u$4. Large perturbations are observed for K = 0 and K = 1 levels of $
u$2. Transitions are also seen for three other vibrations, $
u$4 + $
u$5 + $
u$6, $
u$3 + $
u$6, and 2$
u$4 + $
u$6. {	extcopyright} 1983.},
author = {Steiner, D. A. and Polo, S. R. and McCubbin, T. K. and Wishah, K. A.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(83)90254-0},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {453--483},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of the fundamental $
u$2 of isocyanic acid}},
volume = {98},
year = {1983}
}

@article{90YaWiJo,
abstract = {The $\nu$1 fundamental band of HNCO has been recorded with high resolution using a Bomem FTIR spectrometer. The spectrum is so strongly perturbed by accidental resonances that a global fit using an effective Hamiltonian for asymmetric rotors has not been successful. The molecular parameters including the band origin have been determined by analyzing each Ka substate separately. The combination differences for the ground state allowed us to improve the ground state spectroscopic constants. {\textcopyright} 1990.},
author = {Yamada, Koichi M.T. and Winnewisser, Manfred and Johns, J. W.C.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(90)90147-I},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {353--372},
title = {{High-resolution spectrum of the $\nu$1 fundamental band of isocyanic acid, HNCO}},
volume = {140},
year = {1990}
}

abstract = {HNO has been observed in emission from a radiofrequency discharge through a mixture of ammonia and oxygen. @article{88GoBuHo,
abstract = {High-resolution infrared measurements have been made on the $\nu$9 band of HNO3 from 414 to 500 cm-1. Over 2300 transitions have been measured, assigned, and fit to obtain 15 rovibrational constants for the v9 = 1 state that reproduce the observed spectrum with a RMS deviation of 0.0004 cm-1. The band center for $\nu$9 is at 458.2287 ± 0.0005 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 1988.},
author = {Goldman, Aaron and Burkholder, James B. and Howard, Carleton J. and Escribano, Rafael and Maki, Arthur G.},

volume = {131},
year = {1988}
}

@article{04PeOrFl,
abstract = {Nitric acid (HNO3) plays an important role in the Earth's atmosphere as a reservoir molecule of NOx species. It has a strong infrared signature at 11$\mu$m which is one of the most commonly used for the infrared retrieval of this species in the atmosphere since this spectral region coincides with an atmospheric window. It is therefore essential to have high quality spectral parameters in this spectral region. The main goal of this work is then to generate as reliable as possible line positions and intensities for the $\nu$5 and 2$\nu$9 cold bands centered at 879.1075 and 896.4467cm-1, respectively. In particular the existing line parameters need improvement in the wings of the 11$\mu$m window in order to retrieve more accurately the CFC-11 (CCl3F) and CFC-12 (CCl 2F2) atmospheric species at _850 and _920cm -1, respectively. This work is also motivated by theoretical considerations. Very strong resonances couple indeed the 51 and 92 rotational levels. In addition the $\nu$9 mode (OH torsion) is a "large amplitude" motion, and torsional splittings affect both the v9=2 and the v5=1 rotational transitions. In the present study, these effects are accounted for simultaneously both for the line position and line intensity calculations. To calculate the line positions the Hamiltonian matrix accounts for the very strong Fermi and the weaker Coriolis interactions linking the 51_92 rotational levels, and the torsional effects are accounted for within the frame of the IAM (Internal Axis Method) approach. In addition, the v-diagonal blocks involve non-orthorhombic operators together with Watson's type rotational operators. This means that the z-quantization axis deviates from the a inertial axis for both the 51 and 92 vibrational states. The line intensity calculations were performed accounting also for the axis switching effects. As far as the experimental line positions are concerned we have used the millimeter wave data available in the literature [J. Mol. Spectrosc., 175 (1996) 395; J. Mol. Spectrosc., 208 (2001) 121; and references therein], as well as new centimeter wave measurements performed in Kiel and new Fourier transform infrared spectra recorded in Giessen. For the line intensities we have used an extensive set of individual line intensities measured recently [J. Mol. Spectrosc., 218 (2003) 151]. All these experimental data were very satisfactorily reproduced using the theoretical model described above and an improved set of line positions and intensities was generated for the $\nu$ 5 and 2$\nu$9 bands allowing one to better model the HNO3 absorption in the 11$\mu$m spectral domain. {\textcopyright} 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Perrin, A. and Orphal, J. and Flaud, J. M. and Klee, S. and Mellau, G. and M{\"{a}}der, H. and Walbrodt, D. and Winnewisser, M.},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2004.02.002},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2 SPEC. ISS.},
pages = {375--391},
title = {{New analysis of the $\nu$5 and 2 $\nu$9 bands of HNO3 by infrared and millimeter wave techniques: Line positions and intensities}},
volume = {228},
year = {2004}
}

@article{13Pe,
abstract = {A new line position analysis of the $
u$3 and $
u$4 bands of nitric acid (HNO3) at 1326.186 and 1303.072 cm-1 together with its associated interacting bands is presented. The 31 and 41 energy levels were obtained from an extended analysis of high-resolution Fourier transform spectra recorded at Giessen in the 7.6 $\mu$m region. The energy levels of 31 and 41 upper states of nitric acid are strongly interacting with those of the 93, 6 2, 5191, and 7181 dark states centered at 1288.899, 1289.46, 1341.05, and 1343.78 cm-1, respectively. Informations on these perturbing dark states were achieved through previous partial investigations of hot bands in high-resolution Fourier transform spectra recorded at 22 $\mu$m in Giessen (for 3$
u$9- 2$
u$9 and 3$
u$9-$
u$5), at 12 $\mu$m in Denver (for 3$
u$9-$
u$9), and at 11 $\mu$m in Orsay (for $
u$5+$
u$9-$
u$9). The energy levels calculation accounts for the various Fermi, anharmonic, A-type, B-type, and C-type Coriolis resonances, which couple together the {62,9 3,41,31,5191,7 181} interacting energy levels. For nitric acid, the $
u$9 mode (OH torsion relative to the -NO2 moiety) is a large amplitude motion. The theoretical model used in this work accounts also for large amplitude effects in the 93 dark state, which lead to a splitting of the 93 energy levels of about 0.060 cm-1. In this way, the existence of torsional splittings for several $
u$4 perturbed lines was explained by the occurrence of local A-type and B-type Coriolis resonances coupling the 41 energy levels with those of 93. Because four dark bands had to be accounted for in the model, the results of the energy level calculations are reasonable, although not perfect. However, a very significant improvement was achieved in terms of understanding the 7.6 $\mu$m absorbing bands of nitric acid as compared to the analysis of the $
u$3 and $
u$4 bands performed several years ago [Perrin, A.; Lado-Bordowski, O.; Valentin, A. Mol. Phys. 1989, 67, 249-267]. Finally, the present analysis also features, for the first time, the $
u$ 3+$
u$9-$
u$9 hot band located at 1331.09 cm-1. This study will help to improve HNO3 measurements by satellites. This will be indeed the case for the "Infrared Atmospheric Sounding Interferometer" (IASI) experiment. {	extcopyright} 2013 American Chemical Society.},
author = {Perrin, Agn{\`{e}}s},
doi = {10.1021/jp401979v},
issn = {10895639},
journal = {Journal of Physical Chemistry A},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {50},
pages = {13236--13248},
title = {{New analysis of the $
u$3 and $
u$4 bands of HNO 3 in the 7.6 $\mu$m region}},
volume = {117},
year = {2013}
}

@article{13Pe,
abstract = {A new line position analysis of the $
u$3 and $
u$4 bands of nitric acid (HNO3) at 1326.186 and 1303.072 cm-1 together with its associated interacting bands is presented. The 31 and 41 energy levels were obtained from an extended analysis of high-resolution Fourier transform spectra recorded at Giessen in the 7.6 $\mu$m region. The energy levels of 31 and 41 upper states of nitric acid are strongly interacting with those of the 93, 6 2, 5191, and 7181 dark states centered at 1288.899, 1289.46, 1341.05, and 1343.78 cm-1, respectively. Informations on these perturbing dark states were achieved through previous partial investigations of hot bands in high-resolution Fourier transform spectra recorded at 22 $\mu$m in Giessen (for 3$
u$9- 2$
u$9 and 3$
u$9-$
u$5), at 12 $\mu$m in Denver (for 3$
u$9-$
u$9), and at 11 $\mu$m in Orsay (for $
u$5+$
u$9-$
u$9). The energy levels calculation accounts for the various Fermi, anharmonic, A-type, B-type, and C-type Coriolis resonances, which couple together the {62,9 3,41,31,5191,7 181} interacting energy levels. For nitric acid, the $
u$9 mode (OH torsion relative to the -NO2 moiety) is a large amplitude motion. The theoretical model used in this work accounts also for large amplitude effects in the 93 dark state, which lead to a splitting of the 93 energy levels of about 0.060 cm-1. In this way, the existence of torsional splittings for several $
u$4 perturbed lines was explained by the occurrence of local A-type and B-type Coriolis resonances coupling the 41 energy levels with those of 93. Because four dark bands had to be accounted for in the model, the results of the energy level calculations are reasonable, although not perfect. However, a very significant improvement was achieved in terms of understanding the 7.6 $\mu$m absorbing bands of nitric acid as compared to the analysis of the $
u$3 and $
u$4 bands performed several years ago [Perrin, A.; Lado-Bordowski, O.; Valentin, A. Mol. Phys. 1989, 67, 249-267]. Finally, the present analysis also features, for the first time, the $
u$ 3+$
u$9-$
u$9 hot band located at 1331.09 cm-1. This study will help to improve HNO3 measurements by satellites. This will be indeed the case for the "Infrared Atmospheric Sounding Interferometer" (IASI) experiment. {	extcopyright} 2013 American Chemical Society.},

@article{91NeZa,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of the $\nu$3 vibration of the hydroperoxyl radical has been examined using a tunable lead salt diode laser. Fifty-nine transitions were observed in the wavenumber interval between 1040 and 1120 cm-1. This work extends the earlier measurements of Johns, McKellar, and Riggin to significantly higher rotational states and results in an improved set of spectroscopic constants which should predict all atmospherically relevant HO2 transition frequencies with a precision approaching a thousandth of a cm-1. The incorporation of these line positions in atmospheric transmission models using HITRAN or ATMOS data bases will be useful in remote sensing measurements of HO2. {\textcopyright} 1991.},
author = {Nelson, D. D. and Zahniser, M. S.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(91)90247-8},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {527--534},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Diode laser spectroscopy of the $\nu$3 vibration of the HO2 radical}},
volume = {150},
year = {1991}
}

@article{92BuHaHo,
abstract = {The $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 fundamental absorption bands of the HO2 radical were measured at 0.01-cm-1 resolution using a high resolution Fourier transform spectrometer. HO2 radicals were produced in a fast flow long path absorption cell using two independent sources: (1) F + H2O2 _ HF + HO2 and (2) Cl + CH3OH _ HCl + CH2OH followed by O2 + CH2OH _ CH2O + HO2. Approximately 400 and 770 transitions have been assigned and analyzed in the $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 bands, respectively, to obtain improved molecular parameters for HO2 in the $\nu$2 = 1 and $\nu$3 = 1 levels. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {Burkholder, James B. and Hammer, Philip D. and Howard, Carleton J. and Towle, Jonathan P. and Brown, John M.},

title = {{Fourier transform spectroscopy of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 bands of HO2}},
volume = {151},
year = {1992}
}

@article{86LaOl,
abstract = {The infrared spectra of the a-type transitions of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 bands of HO35Cl and HO37Cl have been obtained under high resolution. Line assignments of both bands have been made, and the spectroscopic constants have been obtained for both bands using a Watson Hamiltonian. Lines of the Ka = 5 subband of the $\nu$2 band of the HO35Cl molecule were found to be slightly shifted by an interaction with the Ka = 4 level of the 2$\nu$3 vibrational state. The b-type transitions permitted for both bands were too weak to observe. Relative intensities of selected lines of both bands have been measured, and empirical Herman-Wallis factors have been determined. {\textcopyright} 1986.},
author = {Lafferty, W. J. and Olson, W. B.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(86)90010-X},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {359--373},
title = {{The high-resolution infrared spectra of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 bands of HOCl}},
volume = {120},
year = {1986}
}

@article{75DuGrMa,
abstract = {The Raman spectra of gaseous hydrazine and hydrazine_d4 have been recorded from 40 to 3500 cm_1. For the Ôlight' molecule, strongly polarized lines at 3398, 3329 and 1076 cm_1 have been assigned to the NH antisymmetric stretch, NH symmetric stretch, and NN stretch, respectively. For the hydrazine_d4 molecule, strongly polarized lines at 2442, 2422, 1031, 930 and 749 cm_1 have been assigned to the ND antisymmetric stretch, ND symmetric stretch, NN stretch, ND2 was and ND2 rock, respectively. The Raman spectra of both solid hydrazine and hydrazine_d4 have been recorded and the splitting in the intramolecular fundamental region indicates that there are at least four molecules per primitie cell. In the lattice region of the spectra the optical translations and librations are assigned and the number of lattice modes rules out both of the space groups previously proposed for hydrazine from scattering studies. Copyright {\textcopyright} 1975 D. Reidel Publishing Company},
author = {Durig, J. R. and Griffin, M. G. and Macnamee, R. W.},
doi = {10.1002/JRS.1250030204},
issn = {1097-4555},
journal = {Journal of Raman Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {2-3},
pages = {133--141},
publisher = {John Wiley & Sons, Ltd},
title = {{Raman spectra of gases. XV: Hydrazine and hydrazine-d4}},
url = {https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/jrs.1250030204 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/jrs.1250030204 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.1250030204},
volume = {3},
year = {1975}
}

@article{07Ho,
abstract = {The lowest fundamental vibration rotation bands $\nu$2 of nitrous oxide (N2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) have been measured with a Fourier transform spectrometer at the resolution of 0.001 cm-1. The spectra have been calibrated with the high accurate peak positions of the carbonyl sulfide (OCS) $\nu$2 band, which has been recently produced as a candidate for a secondary standard by calibrating first the 2$\nu$2 band with the CO2 laser bands around 10 $\mu$m and then transferring the calibration to $\nu$2 with the internal energy levels of OCS. In the present work the OCS $\nu$2 and $\nu$1 bands were measured together with the spectra of N2O and CO2. Then the OCS $\nu$1 band was measured by calibrating it with the 2$\nu$2 band of OCS. The linearity of the wavenumber scale was checked by comparing the corresponding line positions in the OCS $\nu$1 band in these two separate measurements. The absolute accuracy of the $\nu$2 band centers of N2O and CO2 were evaluated to be 6.8 _ 10-6 and 8.4 _ 10-6 cm-1, respectively. {\textcopyright} 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Horneman, Veli Matti},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2006.10.014},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Accurate peak positions,Calibration,Infrared spectra},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {45--50},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High accurate peak positions for calibration purposes with the lowest fundamental bands $\nu$2 of N2O and CO2}},
volume = {241},
year = {2007}
}

Journal: Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy & Radiative Transfer
BibTex_Code:
@article{18AlLaGa,
abstract = {The $\nu$1 fundamental band of N2O is examined by a novel spectrometer that relies on the frequency locking of an external-cavity quantum cascade laser around 7.8 µm to a near-infrared Tm:based frequency comb at 1.9 µm. Due to the large tunability, nearly 70 lines in the 1240Ð1310 cm_1 range of the $\nu$1 band of N2O, from P(40) to R(31), are for the first time measured with an absolute frequency calibration and an uncertainty from 62 to 180 kHz, depending on the line. Accurate values of the spectroscopic constants of the upper state are derived from a fit of the line centers (rms Å 4.8 _ 10_6 cm_1 or 144 kHz). The $\nu$1 transitions presently measured in a Doppler regime validate high accuracy predictions based on sub-Doppler measurements of the $\nu$3 and $\nu$3-$\nu$1 transitions.},
author = {AlSaif, Bidoor and Lamperti, Marco and Gatti, Davide and Laporta, Paolo and Fermann, Martin and Farooq, Aamir and Lyulin, Oleg and Campargue, Alain and Marangoni, Marco},
doi = {10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.03.005},
issn = {00224073},
journal = {Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer},
keywords = {Frequency comb,Line position,Microwave,Mid-infrared,Nitrous oxide,Quantum cascade laser},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
pages = {172--178},
publisher = {Pergamon},
title = {{High accuracy line positions of the $\nu$ 1 fundamental band of 14 N 2 16 O}},
url = {https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S002240731830058X},
volume = {211},
year = {2018}
}

Journal: Journal of the Optical Society of America B
BibTex_Code:
@article{14TiChCh,
abstract = {Frequency measurements are given for the 10¡0_00¡0 band of N2O near 4.5 $\mu$m and for pure rotational transitions beyond 151.5 $\mu$m. The infrared measurements utilize a periodically poled lithium niobate (PPLN) based difference frequency generation (DFG) source locked to the saturated absorption center of an N2O absorption line. The DFG frequency is calibrated by an optical frequency comb and an iodine hyperfine transition. We report 44 transitions ranging from J = 1 . 100 for both the P and R branches and the accuracy is better than 10 kHz for most transitions. In addition, 175 pure rotational transitions have been measured including 33 measurements with sub-Doppler precision (.3 kHz), and 142 Doppler limited measurements. These are combined with other precision rotational and vibrational measurements to provide improved quantum mechanical parameters, as well as frequency calibration tables for the N2O bands near 4.5 $\mu$m. {\textcopyright} 2014 Optical Society of America.},
author = {Ting, Wei-Jo and Chang, Chun-Hung and Chen, Shih-En and Chen, Hsuan-Chen and Shy, Jow-Tsong and Drouin, Brian J. and Daly, Adam M.},

issn = {0740-3224},
journal = {Journal of the Optical Society of America B},
keywords = {Absorption spectroscopy,Frequency combs,Frequency measurement,Frequency modulated lasers,Molecular spectroscopy,Periodically poled lithium niobate},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {8},
pages = {1954},
publisher = {Optical Society of America},
title = {{Precision frequency measurement of N_2O transitions near 45 $\mu$m and above 150 $\mu$m}},

volume = {31},

@article{15Na,
abstract = {Several accurate experimental values of the rovibrational interaction constants $\alpha$C and $\alpha$B, the harmonic wave-number parameters $\omega$ij, and the anharmonicity xij and gij constants have been extracted from the most recent high-resolution Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), centimeter-wave (CMW) and millimeter-wave (MMW) measurements in the spectra of the oblate symmetric top molecule 14NF3. The data used are those of the four fundamental, the overtone, the combination and the hot bands identified and analyzed in the range between 400 cm-1 and 2000 cm-1. Combining the recent experimental values of the constants $\alpha$C and $\alpha$B, with the accurate experimental ground state rotational constants C0 and B0, new equilibrium rotational constants have been evaluated: Ce = 0.1968006 (26) cm-1 and Be = 0.358981442 (43) cm-1 for the pyramidal molecule NF3, from which the following equilibrium structure is obtained: re(F-N) = 1.36757 (58) {\AA}; $\theta$e(FNF) = 101.8513 (10)¡. This experimental equilibrium geometry is in excellent agreement with the recent structure determined by ab initio calculations at the CCSD(T)/aug-cc-pVQZ level of theory.},
author = {Najib, Hamid},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.02.002},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Anharmonic constants,Equilibrium structure,Harmonic wavenumbers,Nitrogen trifluoride,Rovibrational constants},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {1--5},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{Experimental values of the rotational and vibrational constants and equilibrium structure of nitrogen trifluoride}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2015.02.002},
volume = {312},
year = {2015}
}

Except in the far-infrared with instrument limited resolution ($\Delta$$
u__FWHM = 0.0008 cm-1) many of the spectra are nearly Doppler limited. Rovibrational transitions were assigned to 13 different vibrational bands and were used then in the fitting procedure. We re-investigated the bands 2$

@article{99RaBeHi,
abstract = {The high-resolution emission spectrum of NH has been observed in the near infrared using a Fourier transform spectrometer (FTS) and a cryogenic echelle spectrograph (called Phoenix) at the National Solar Observatory at Kitt Peak. By using a large format InSb array detector, the newly constructed Phoenix is calculated to offer a large increase in sensitivity over a Fourier transform spectrometer for measurements near 5 $\mu$m (2000 cm-1). In order to test the performance of Phoenix, we recorded vibration-rotation emission spectra of the free-radical NH. The infrared bands of NH were produced in a microwave discharge of a mixture of NH3 and He. The rotational structure of five bands, 1-0, 2-1, 3-2, 4-3, and 5-4 in the 2200-3500 cm-1 region has also been measured using two FTS spectra. An analysis of these bands combined with the previous electronic, vibration-rotation, and pure rotation measurements provides improved molecular constants for the ground electronic state. In particular, we have extended the range of measured J values so that the new constants are suitable for predicting line positions in high-temperature sources such as stellar atmospheres and flames. A comparison of the Phoenix spectra with the FTS spectra confirms the higher sensitivity of the Phoenix spectrometer. The relative advantages and disadvantages of instruments like Phoenix are discussed. Although designed for astronomical work, cryogenic echelle spectrographs have applications in the ultrasensitive detection of molecules in chemical physics. {\textcopyright} 1999 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Ram, R. S. and Bernath, P. F. and Hinkle, K. H.},
doi = {10.1063/1.478453},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {Fourier transform spectra,free radicals,ground states,infrared spectra,nitrogen compounds,rotational-vibrational states},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {12},
pages = {5557--5563},
publisher = {American Institute of Physics Inc.},
title = {{Infrared emission spectroscopy of NH: Comparison of a cryogenic echelle spectrograph with a Fourier transform spectrometer}},
url = {http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.478453},
volume = {110},
year = {1999}
}

@article{81UrSpPa,
abstract = {Fourier transform infrared spectra of the inversion-rotation transitions have been measured with 0.010-cm-1 resolution between 40 and 300 cm-1 in the ground state and $\nu$2 excited states of 14NH3. Submillimeterwave spectra of the inversion and inversion-rotation transitions in the $\nu$2 state of 14NH3, including a few $\Delta$k = ±3 "perturbation-allowed" transitions, have been measured with microwave accuracy between 540 and 770 GHz. A simultaneous least-squares analysis of these data, the microwave ground-state transition frequencies, and the $\nu$2 infrared-microwave two-photon transition frequencies has been carried out. A theory of the $\Delta$k = ±3n interactions in the ground and $\nu$2 excited states of ammonia (S. P. Belov, L. I. Gershtein, A. F. Krupnov, A. V. Maslovskij, {\v{S}}. Urban, V. {\v{S}}pirko, and D. Papou{\v{s}}ek, J. Mol. Spectrosc.84, 288-304 (1980)) has been used in the analysis. A set of the ground- and $\nu$2-state molecular parameters has been obtained which describes the experimental data within the precision of the experiment. The "smoothed" values of transition frequencies can be used for calibration purposes with a precision better than 3 _ 10-5 cm-1 in the submillimeterwave region, better than 10-3 cm-1 in the far-infrared region, and better than 1.5 _ 10-3 cm-1 in the region 700 - 1200 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 1981.},
author = {Urban, {\v{S}} and {\v{S}}pirko, V. and Papou{\v{s}}ek, D. and Kauppinen, J. and Belov, S. P. and Gershtein, L. I. and Krupnov, A. F.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(81)90179-X},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {274--292},
title = {{A simultaneous analysis of the microwave, submillimeterwave, far infrared, and infrared-microwave two-photon transitions between the ground and $\nu$2 inversion-rotation levels of 14NH3}},
volume = {88},
year = {1981}
}

@article{00CoKlTa,
abstract = {Line positions and intensities belonging to the vibrational system 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 of ammonia 14NH3 are measured and analyzed between 1200 and 2200 cm-1 in order to improve the molecular database. For this, laboratory spectra are obtained at 0.006 and 0.011 cm-1 unapodized resolution and with 4% precisions for the intensities using Fourier transform spectrometers located at the Kitt Peak National Observatory and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The observed data contain transitions of the $\nu$4 fundamental band near 1626.276(1) and 1627.375(2) cm-1 (for s and a inversion upper states, respectively) and the 2$\nu$2 overtone band near 1597.470(3) and 1882.179(5) cm-1 (for s and a inversion states, respectively). A total of 2345 lines with J_²15 is assigned from which 2114 line positions with J_²15 are fitted using an effective rotation-inversion-rotation Hamiltonian to achieve an rms of 0.003 cm-1 with 57 molecular parameters. Over 1200 intensity measurements are modeled to ±4.7% using 16 terms of the dipole moment expansion. A dyad model is used in order to model all the interactions expected within the 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 system. The bandstrengths of 2$\nu$2 (s_a), 2$\nu$2 (a_s), and $\nu$4 (s_s and a_a) are estimated to be 6.68(24), 0.201(5), and 116(3) cm-2 atm-1, respectively, at 296 K. The prediction generated by this study is available for planetary studies.},
author = {Cottaz, C. and Kleiner, I. and Tarrago, G. and Brown, L. R. and Margolis, J. S. and Poynter, R. L. and Pickett, H. M. and Fouchet, T. and Drossart, P. and Lellouch, E.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2000.8182},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {285--309},
title = {{Line positions and intensities in the 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 vibrational system of 14NH3 near 5-7 $\mu$m}},
volume = {203},
year = {2000}
}

@article{00CoKlTa,
abstract = {Line positions and intensities belonging to the vibrational system 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 of ammonia 14NH3 are measured and analyzed between 1200 and 2200 cm-1 in order to improve the molecular database. For this, laboratory spectra are obtained at 0.006 and 0.011 cm-1 unapodized resolution and with 4% precisions for the intensities using Fourier transform spectrometers located at the Kitt Peak National Observatory and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The observed data contain transitions of the $\nu$4 fundamental band near 1626.276(1) and 1627.375(2) cm-1 (for s and a inversion upper states, respectively) and the 2$\nu$2 overtone band near 1597.470(3) and 1882.179(5) cm-1 (for s and a inversion states, respectively). A total of 2345 lines with J_²15 is assigned from which 2114 line positions with J_²15 are fitted using an effective rotation-inversion-rotation Hamiltonian to achieve an rms of 0.003 cm-1 with 57 molecular parameters. Over 1200 intensity measurements are modeled to ±4.7% using 16 terms of the dipole moment expansion. A dyad model is used in order to model all the interactions expected within the 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 system. The bandstrengths of 2$\nu$2 (s_a), 2$\nu$2 (a_s), and $\nu$4 (s_s and a_a) are estimated to be 6.68(24), 0.201(5), and 116(3) cm-2 atm-1, respectively, at 296 K. The prediction generated by this study is available for planetary studies.},
author = {Cottaz, C. and Kleiner, I. and Tarrago, G. and Brown, L. R. and Margolis, J. S. and Poynter, R. L. and Pickett, H. M. and Fouchet, T. and Drossart, P. and Lellouch, E.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2000.8182},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {2},
pages = {285--309},
title = {{Line positions and intensities in the 2$\nu$2/$\nu$4 vibrational system of 14NH3 near 5-7 $\mu$m}},
volume = {203},
year = {2000}
}

@article{99KlBrTa,
abstract = {Line positions and line intensities of the $\nu$1, $\nu$3, and 2$\nu$4 bands of 14NH3 were analyzed using line positions from 0.0054 cm-1 apodized resolution FT spectra recorded at Orsay and using line intensities from 0.011 cm-1 unapodized resolution FT spectra recorded at Kitt Peak National Observatory. About 2110 lines with J_ ² 10 were assigned from which 1832 line positions were fitted using an effective rotation-inversion Hamiltonian to achieve an rms of 0.085 cm-1. Nearly 1000 line intensities were measured with an accuracy of 6% or better and modeled to 11 terms of dipole moment expansion to ±9.4%. The bandstrengths of the $\nu$1, $\nu$3, and 2$\nu$4 bands (determined for the first time in the case of the 2$\nu$4 band) are, respectively, 23.6(2), 11.8(1), and 2.82(4) cm-2/atm at 296 K. A prediction of the line positions and intensities was generated for some _2700 lines with intensities calculated greater than 1 _ 10-4 cm-2 atm-1 at 296 K, suitable for planetological purposes. Tentative assignments involving 22 upper state levels of 4$\nu$2s were identified, but these were not included in the modeling at the present stage. The theoretical model and the set of programs developed for treating the infrared system $\nu$1/$\nu$3/2$\nu$4 of ammonia are briefly discussed. {\textcopyright} 1999 Academic Press.},
author = {Kleiner, I. and Brown, L. R. and Tarrago, G. and Kou, Q. L. and Picqu{\'{e}}, N. and Guelachvili, G. and Dana, V. and Mandin, J. Y.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1998.7728},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {46--71},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{Positions and intensities in the 2$\nu$4/$\nu$1/$\nu$3 vibrational system of 14NH3 near 3 $\mu$m}},
volume = {193},
year = {1999}
}

@article{63CoMaSc,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of gaseous difluoramine, NF2{\"{U}}, has been investigated over the range 250-4000 cm"1. Four bands of NF2D have also been observed. The fundamental frequencies (in cm-1) and their species are as follows: NF2H: v1(a') :3193; v 2(a') :1307; v3(a') :972; v4(a') :500; v 5,(a") :1424; v6,(a") :888. NF2D: v1(a') :[2333]; v2(a') :1008; v3 (a') :972; v4(a') :[500]; v5(a") :1042; v6(a") :888. The bracketed values were not observed directly. The fine structure resolved in several of the bands led to a value for A -(B+C)/2 in agreement with the microwave result. No inversion splitting was detected.},
author = {Comeford, J. J. and Mann, D. E. and Schoen, L. J. and Lide, David R.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1733681},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {2},
pages = {461--463},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Infrared spectrum of difluoramine}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.173368138,461},
volume = {38},
year = {1963}
}

abstract = {The purpose of the present paper is to describe recent progress in the study of two molecules of atmospheric interest, namely nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and sulfur dioxide (SO2). This progress has led to updates in the 1996 version of the HITRAN database. Also some recommendations for the future will be given. {\textcopyright} 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.},
author = {Perrin, A. and Flaud, J. M. and Goldman, A. and Camy-Peyret, C. and Lafferty, W. J. and Arcas, Ph and Rinsland, C. P.},

number = {5},
pages = {839--850},
publisher = {Elsevier Ltd},
title = {{NO2 and SO2 line parameters: 1996 HITRAN update and new results}},
volume = {60},
year = {1998}
}

@article{76MuMoCy,
abstract = {The complete infrared spectrum of gaseous NSCl, including the hitherto unobserved $\nu$3, is reported. A set of force constants for gaseous NSCl consistent with a number of pieces of independent data such as the isotopic shifts (14N32S35Cl, 15N32S35Cl, 14N32S37Cl, 15N32S37Cl, 14N34S35Cl and 15N34S35Cl), centrifugal distortion constants (14N32S35Cl), and the inertia defect (14N32S35Cl) has been computed. Also, the force field of NSF has been redetermined using the vibrational frequencies and the centrifugal distortion constants. {\textcopyright} 1976.},
author = {M{\"{u}}ller, A. and Mohan, N. and Cyvin, S. J. and Weinstock, N. and Glemser, O.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(76)90288-5},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {feb},
number = {2},
pages = {161--170},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Molecular constants for NSCl and NSF}},
volume = {59},
year = {1976}
}

@article{06RoMc,
abstract = {The $\nu$1 band of thiazyl chloride (NSCl) has been measured by high resolution FTIR spectroscopy, and studied using the spectral analysis by subtraction of simulated intensities (SASSI)-technique. This involves assignment and fitting of a component, creating a global simulation of the entire component to be subtracted from the experimental spectrum, and subsequent analysis of the resultant spectrum. Through this iterative procedure it has been possible to assign rovibrational transitions for seven components, with populations in the lower vibrational state as low as 2% of the total. The components are the 101 fundamental and 101 311, 101 322, and 101 211 hotbands of 14N32S35Cl, the 101 fundamental and 101 311 hotband of 14N32S37Cl, and the 101 fundamental of 14N34S35Cl. Rotational and centrifugal distortion constants beyond the quartic level have been obtained by fitting to Watson's A-reduced Hamiltonian in upper and lower states. {\textcopyright} 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {Robertson, Evan G. and McNaughton, Don},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2006.04.009},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {High resolution IR spectroscopy,Rovibrational analysis,Spectral analysis by subtraction of simulated inte,Thiazyl chloride},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {1},
pages = {56--63},
title = {{Maximising rovibrational assignments in the $\nu$1 band of NSCl by spectral analysis by subtraction of simulated intensities (SASSI)}},
volume = {238},
year = {2006}
}

@article{02WaBiSc,
abstract = {[1] High-resolution Fourier transform infrared measurements of the three ozone fundamentals have been performed. A total of 16 spectra have been recorded, including pure as well as oxygen- and nitrogen-broadened ozone at room temperature and 200 K. Focus was set on quality assurance for sample preparation and on prevention of instrumental and retrieval errors. Line positions, line strengths and pressure-broadened half widths have been determined. A quantum mechanical analysis of line positions and line strengths was performed, and improved molecular constants were obtained. Individual pressure-broadening parameters and temperature exponents were calculated and represented as polynomials in the in quantum number for differently binmed sets of subbands. Accuracies of better than 2% were achieved for both line strengths and pressure broadening of many strong transitions. The new data are suited for update of line-by-line spectroscopic databases. Copyright 2002 by the American Geophysical Union.},
author = {Wagner, G. and Birk, M. and Schreier, F. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1029/2001JD000818},
issn = {0148-0227},
journal = {Journal of Geophysical Research},
keywords = {Infrared,Line strengths,Ozone,Pressure-broadening parameters,Remote sensing,Spectroscopic database},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {D22},
pages = {4626},
publisher = {Blackwell Publishing Ltd},
title = {{Spectroscopic database for ozone in the fundamental spectral regions}},
url = {http://doi.wiley.com/10.1029/2001JD000818},
volume = {107},
year = {2002}
}

@article{02WaBiSc,
abstract = {[1] High-resolution Fourier transform infrared measurements of the three ozone fundamentals have been performed. A total of 16 spectra have been recorded, including pure as well as oxygen- and nitrogen-broadened ozone at room temperature and 200 K. Focus was set on quality assurance for sample preparation and on prevention of instrumental and retrieval errors. Line positions, line strengths and pressure-broadened half widths have been determined. A quantum mechanical analysis of line positions and line strengths was performed, and improved molecular constants were obtained. Individual pressure-broadening parameters and temperature exponents were calculated and represented as polynomials in the in quantum number for differently binmed sets of subbands. Accuracies of better than 2% were achieved for both line strengths and pressure broadening of many strong transitions. The new data are suited for update of line-by-line spectroscopic databases. Copyright 2002 by the American Geophysical Union.},
author = {Wagner, G. and Birk, M. and Schreier, F. and Flaud, J. M.},
doi = {10.1029/2001JD000818},
issn = {0148-0227},
journal = {Journal of Geophysical Research},
keywords = {Infrared,Line strengths,Ozone,Pressure-broadening parameters,Remote sensing,Spectroscopic database},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {D22},
pages = {4626},
publisher = {Blackwell Publishing Ltd},
title = {{Spectroscopic database for ozone in the fundamental spectral regions}},
url = {http://doi.wiley.com/10.1029/2001JD000818},
volume = {107},
year = {2002}
}

@article{06VaFa,
abstract = {Using a total of 18 unapodized high-resolution (MOPD=300 and 450 cm) Fourier transform absorption spectra of carbonyl sulfide (P__=14.3-60, 600 Pa_cm, T=296.0 K), we measured 1340 absolute line intensities in 8 bands ($\nu$1+$\nu$21-$\nu$21,2$\nu$20,2$\nu$1,$\nu$1+2$\nu$20,4$\nu$20,$\nu$3, $\nu$21+$\nu$3-$\nu$21,$\nu$1+$\nu$3) of the main isotopologue, located between 827 and 2939 cm-1. In addition, we measured 307 absolute line intensities in the $\nu$3 fundamental band of 16O12C 34S and 16O13C32S, observed near 2061.45 and 2009.23 cm-1, respectively. The observed Herman-Wallis dependences are in most cases reproduced by the global model of OCS [E. Rbaihi, A. Belafhal, J. Vander Auwera, S. Na{\"{i}}m, and A. Fayt, J. Mol. Spectrosc., 191:32-44, 1998]. The pressure self-broadening parameter was also measured up to J=83. {\textcopyright} 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.},
author = {{Vander Auwera}, J. and Fayt, A.},
doi = {10.1016/j.molstruc.2005.04.052},
file = {::},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
keywords = {Absolute intensities,Carbonyl sulfide,Infrared,Self-broadening,Transition dipole moments},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {SPEC. ISS.},
pages = {134--141},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Absolute line intensities for carbonyl sulfide from 827 to 2939 cm -1}},
volume = {780-781},
year = {2006}
}

@article{84FoJo,
abstract = {The $\nu$2 and $\nu$3 fundamentals of FNO have been recorded with a Fourier transform spectrophotometer at an apodized resolution of approximately 0.004 cm-1. The Fourier infrared data have been analyzed together with previous microwave data to yield improved molecular parameters for the (000) and (010) vibrational states and the first set of constants for the (001) state. The main results (in cm-1) are {A table is presented}. {\textcopyright} 1984.},

@article{93Ed,
abstract = {From the most precise experimental measurements available from the gas phase for the three vibrational wavenumbers of P4, the primary stretching force constant fr = 2.06 mdyn {\AA}-1 and two stretch-stretch interaction constants have been evaluated using a simple valence force field. The positive value of frr1 and negative value of frr are confirmed and the value of fr is found to be significantly smaller (15% and 7% respectively) than the corresponding values calculated from the infrared spectra of solutions of phosphorus in carbon disulphide reported in the literature. {\textcopyright} 1993.},
author = {Edwards, H. G.M.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2860(93)85009-J},
issn = {0022-2860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {C},
pages = {95--100},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Vibrational raman spectrum and force constants of phosphorus, P4}},
volume = {295},
year = {1993}
}

@article{65MiScFa,
abstract = {First order centrifugal distortion constants of PCl3 and PF3 have been obtained from millimeter rotational spectra. Their values in KHz are: DJ = 1{\textperiodcentered}17 ± 0.01; DJK = -1,879 ± 0.008 for PCl3 DJ = 7{\textperiodcentered}845 ± 0.045; DJK = -11{\textperiodcentered}77 ± 0{\textperiodcentered}04 for PF3. Using DJ and DJK in addition to the four vibration frequencies, all the constants of the general force field have been determined for both molecules. {\textcopyright} 1965.},
author = {Mirri, Anna M. and Scappini, Flavio and Favero, Paolo G.},
doi = {10.1016/0371-1951(65)80164-3},
issn = {0371-1951},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {may},
number = {5},
pages = {965--971},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Millimeter wave spectrum of PF3 and PCl3 and force constants determination}},
volume = {21},
year = {1965}
}

@article{14Na,
abstract = {Thanks to recent high-resolution Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and pure rotational (RF/CM/MMW) measurements, several experimental values of the rotation-vibration parameters of the oblate molecule PF3 have been extracted, contributing thus to the knowledge of the molecular potential of phosphorus trifluoride. The data used are those of the fundamental, overtone and combination bands studied in the 300-1500 cm-1 range. The new values are in good agreement with ones determined at low resolution, but significantly more accurate. The agreement is excellent with the available values determined by ab initio HF-SCF calculations employing the TZP/TZ2P triple-zeta basis. From the recent experimental rovibrational interaction constants $\alpha$C and $\alpha$B, new accurate equilibrium rotational constants Ce and Be have been derived for the symmetric top molecule PF3, which were used to derive the equilibrium geometry of this molecule: re(F-P) = 1.560986 (43) {\AA}; $\theta$e(FPF) = 97.566657 (64)¡.},
author = {Najib, Hamid},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.008},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Anharmonic constants,Equilibrium structure,Harmonic wavenumbers,Phosphorus trifluoride,Rovibrational constants},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
pages = {17--21},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Experimental rovibrational constants and equilibrium structure of phosphorus trifluoride}},
volume = {305},
year = {2014}
}

@article{14Na,
abstract = {Thanks to recent high-resolution Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and pure rotational (RF/CM/MMW) measurements, several experimental values of the rotation-vibration parameters of the oblate molecule PF3 have been extracted, contributing thus to the knowledge of the molecular potential of phosphorus trifluoride. The data used are those of the fundamental, overtone and combination bands studied in the 300-1500 cm-1 range. The new values are in good agreement with ones determined at low resolution, but significantly more accurate. The agreement is excellent with the available values determined by ab initio HF-SCF calculations employing the TZP/TZ2P triple-zeta basis. From the recent experimental rovibrational interaction constants $\alpha$C and $\alpha$B, new accurate equilibrium rotational constants Ce and Be have been derived for the symmetric top molecule PF3, which were used to derive the equilibrium geometry of this molecule: re(F-P) = 1.560986 (43) {\AA}; $\theta$e(FPF) = 97.566657 (64)¡.},
author = {Najib, Hamid},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2014.09.008},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Anharmonic constants,Equilibrium structure,Harmonic wavenumbers,Phosphorus trifluoride,Rovibrational constants},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
pages = {17--21},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Experimental rovibrational constants and equilibrium structure of phosphorus trifluoride}},
volume = {305},
year = {2014}
}
