@article{96RaBe,
abstract = {The infrared vibration - rotation bands of ND in the _3$\Sigma$- state were recorded using a Fourier transform spectrometer. The bands were observed in a microwave discharge of a mixture of N2 and D2 in the presence of He. The rotational structure of six bands, 1-0, 2-1, 3-2, 4-3, 5-4, and 6-5, has been observed in the 1800-2600 cm-1 region. The analysis of these bands provides an independent determination of the ground state vibrational constants in addition to an improved set of rotational constants. The principal molecular constants for the ground state are we = 2399.1255(299) cm-1, wexe = 42.1064(212) cm-1, weye, = 0.1203(54) cm-1 Be, = 8.908665(146) cm-1, $\alpha$e, = 0.254570(192) cm-1, re = 1.036651(9) {\AA}. The molecular constants for PH have also been refined by combining the previous infrared [J. Mol. Spectrosc. 122, 275-281 (1987)] and the recent submillimeter-wave [Chem. Phys. Lett. 211, 443-448 (1993)] measurements. {\textcopyright} 1996 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Ram, R. S. and Bernath, P. F.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1996.0094},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {2},
pages = {329--336},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{Fourier transform infrared emission spectroscopy of ND and PH}},
volume = {176},
year = {1996}
}

@article{00FuLo,
abstract = {The IR absorption spectrum of phosphine (PH3) has been recorded at a resolution of 0.004 cm-1 in the region between 750 and 1400 cm-1. About 2500 rovibrational transitions have been measured and assigned to the V2 (A1) and v4 (E) bending fundamentals, including 501 'perturbation allowed' transitions with selection rules $\Delta$(k - l) = ± 3, ± 6, and ± 9. Splittings of the K' = 3, 6, and 9 lines were observed. Rotational transitions in the vibrationally excited states have also been identified in the far-IR spectra recorded in the past at 0.002 cm-1 resolution between 30 and 200 cm-1 [L. Fusina and M. Carlotti, J. Mol. Spectrosc., 130 (1988) 371]. The rotational structure in the v2 = 1 and v4 = 1 vibrational states up to J = K = 24 was reproduced by fitting simultaneously our experimental data, together with the very accurate transitions previously reported in the literature. The adopted rovibrational Hamiltonian explicitly took into account the Coriolis interaction between the v2 = 1 and v4 = 1 states, and included also several essential resonances within them. The 46 parameters obtained from the fit reproduced 2736 IR and far-IR transitions retained in the final cycle within the uncertainty of the experimental measurements and 37 microwave and mm-wave transitions with an rms value of 0.9 MHz. The ground state parameters have also been improved by means of ground state combination differences. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science B.V.},
author = {Fusina, L. and {Di Lonardo}, G.},
doi = {10.1016/S0022-2860(99)00239-2},
issn = {00222860},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Structure},
keywords = {High resolution,Infrared spectra,PH3,Phosphine},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {67--78},
title = {{The v2 and v4 bending fundamentals of phosphine (PH3)}},
volume = {517-518},
year = {2000}
}

@article{92TaLaLe,
abstract = {The five absorption bands of PH3 at 4-5 $\mu$m, i.e., 2$
u$2, $
u$2 + $
u$4, 2$
u$4, $
u$1, $
u$3, were simultaneously analyzed from FT spectra recorded with an apodized resolution of 0.0054 cm-1. A theoretical model suited to the strong vibro-rotational couplings among the five bands was used. More than 4400 transitions (J ² 16) pertaining to the five bands were assigned in the range 1885-2445 cm-1, but only 3766 relatively unblended transitions were finally retained for the adjustment of the upper state energy parameters. A set of 57 energy parameters was required to reproduce the experimental wavenumbers with an overall standard deviation of 0.009 cm-1, consistent with the estimated upper limit of uncertainty when taking into account all factors of experimental errors. Absolute intensities of about 1600 lines were also measured, mainly in 2$
u$2, $
u$2 + $
u$4, and 2$
u$4 bands. The fitting of these data was achieved by using a restricted set of 53 energy parameters which yields the best compromise for both spectral position and intensity analyses. An estimate was then obtained for the four dipole moment derivatives involved in 2$
u$2, $
u$2 + $
u$4, and 2$
u$4, allowing us to reproduce the intensity measurements with an overall standard deviation of 10.9%, consistent with the experimental uncertainties. Absolute bandstrengths relative to 2$
u$2, $
u$2 + $
u$4, and 2$
u$4 were thus derived for the first time. Last, a line-by-line simulation of the five bands (J ² 16) was carried out in a form suitable for planetary applications. PH3, which is observed in Jupiter and Saturn, is an important molecule for studies of their atmospheric structures. The 5-$\mu$m bands are of special importance because the atmospheres are sounded deep at these wavelengths. {	extcopyright} 1992.},
author = {Tarrago, G. and Lacome, N. and L{'{e}}vy, A. and Guelachvili, G. and B{'{e}}zard, B. and Drossart, P.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(92)90026-K},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {1},
pages = {30--42},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Phosphine spectrum at 4-5 $\mu$m: Analysis and line-by-line simulation of 2$
u$2, $
u$2 + $
u$4, 2$
u$4, $
u$1, and $
u$3 bands}},
volume = {154},
year = {1992}
}

@article{95AhHa,
abstract = {The infrared absorption spectrum of the PN molecule has been recorded for the first time using an FTIR spectrometer. A flowing discharge of PCl3 and N2 was used to produce short-lived PN molecules at room temperature in a long-path cell. Spectra of the fundamental transition were recorded at a nominal resolution of 0.02 cm-1 and calibrated against accurately known water vapor lines present in the background to give an absolute and relative accuracy on the order of 0.0004 cm-1. The line positions measured in this work were analyzed in terms of effective band constants and combined with previous high-temperature microwave and infrared data to produce accurate spectroscopic parameters for the ground state X1$\Sigma$+. {\textcopyright} 1995 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Ahmad, Imtiaz K. and Hamilton, Peter A.},
doi = {10.1006/JMSP.1995.1022},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {286--291},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrum of PN}},
volume = {169},
year = {1995}
}

@article{94LiNiTi,
abstract = {S2 was generated by photodissociation of S2Cl2 and the B3$\Sigma$-u state was investigated for upsilon_ = 0.8 by laser excitation spectroscopy from the ground state. Bands were detected and assigned up to rotational levels N_ = 50. For both states accurate parameters were determined, which allow the description of the B-X spectrum for N ² 20 within the errors of measurements. For higher quantum numbers deviations from perturbations become severe. A new set of molecular parameters for the X3$\Sigma$-g ground state is given from a simultaneous fit of optical and millimeter spectra. {\textcopyright} 1994 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Lindner, J. and Niemann, R. and Tiemann, E.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1994.1139},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {2},
pages = {358--367},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Laser spectroscopy of the b3$\Sigma$-u-x3$\Sigma$-g spectrum of S2 produced by photodissociation}},
volume = {165},
year = {1994}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{70BrPe,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of difluoro disulphane, FSSF, and the Raman spectra of difluoro disulphane and thio-thionyl fluoride, SSF2 have been recorded. Six fundamentals of FSSP (point group C2) were observed and have been assigned as follows: Species A: $\nu$1(SF) 717.0 ± 0.5 cm-1, $\nu$2(SS) 614.6 ± 0.4 cm- $\nu$3(FSS) 319.8 ± 0.3 cm-1, $\nu$4(FSS) 182.5 ± 1.5 cm-1 Species B: $\nu$5(SF) 680.8 ± 0.3 cm-1, $\nu$6(FSS) 301 ± 2 cm-1. A normal co-ordinate vibrational analysis was performed using a modified Urey-Bradley potential function. Calculated values for the S-F and S-S force constants are 3.2 and 3.7 mdyn A respectively; the latter constant is surprisingly small for the S-S bond length of 1.888 ± 0.01 {\AA} in FSSF. The fundamentals in our reported infrared spectrum of SSF2 (point group C3) have been re-assigned on the basis of the present Raman data: Species A': $\nu$1 760.5 ± 0.2 cm-1, $\nu$2 718.5 ± 0.2 cm-1 $\nu$3 411.2 ± 0.4 cm-1, $\nu$4 330 ±1.5 cm-1 Species A_: $\nu$5 692.3 ± 0.8 cm-1, $\nu$6 274 ± 1.5 cm-1. Thermodynamic functions have been calculated for FSSF and SSF2 using the harmonic oscillator ideal gas approximation. {\textcopyright} 1970.},
author = {Brown, R. D. and Pez, G. P.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(70)80199-4},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {7},
pages = {1375--1386},
title = {{Vibrational spectra of thio-thionyl fluoride and difluoro disulphane}},
volume = {26},
year = {1970}
}

@article{70BrPe,
abstract = {The infrared spectrum of difluoro disulphane, FSSF, and the Raman spectra of difluoro disulphane and thio-thionyl fluoride, SSF2 have been recorded. Six fundamentals of FSSP (point group C2) were observed and have been assigned as follows: Species A: $\nu$1(SF) 717.0 ± 0.5 cm-1, $\nu$2(SS) 614.6 ± 0.4 cm- $\nu$3(FSS) 319.8 ± 0.3 cm-1, $\nu$4(FSS) 182.5 ± 1.5 cm-1 Species B: $\nu$5(SF) 680.8 ± 0.3 cm-1, $\nu$6(FSS) 301 ± 2 cm-1. A normal co-ordinate vibrational analysis was performed using a modified Urey-Bradley potential function. Calculated values for the S-F and S-S force constants are 3.2 and 3.7 mdyn A respectively; the latter constant is surprisingly small for the S-S bond length of 1.888 ± 0.01 {\AA} in FSSF. The fundamentals in our reported infrared spectrum of SSF2 (point group C3) have been re-assigned on the basis of the present Raman data: Species A': $\nu$1 760.5 ± 0.2 cm-1, $\nu$2 718.5 ± 0.2 cm-1 $\nu$3 411.2 ± 0.4 cm-1, $\nu$4 330 ±1.5 cm-1 Species A_: $\nu$5 692.3 ± 0.8 cm-1, $\nu$6 274 ± 1.5 cm-1. Thermodynamic functions have been calculated for FSSF and SSF2 using the harmonic oscillator ideal gas approximation. {\textcopyright} 1970.},
author = {Brown, R. D. and Pez, G. P.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(70)80199-4},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
number = {7},

title = {{Vibrational spectra of thio-thionyl fluoride and difluoro disulphane}},

@article{15MaEnZi,
abstract = {Abstract The fundamental vibrational bending mode $\nu$2 of disulfur monoxide, S2O, and the associated hot band 2$\nu$2-$\nu$2 have been observed at high spectral resolution for the first time at the SOLEIL synchrotron facility using Fourier-transform far-infrared spectroscopy. This transient species has been produced in a radio-frequency discharge by flowing SO2 over elemental sulfur. The spectroscopic analysis has been performed using the newly developed Automated Spectral Assignment Procedure (ASAP) which has enabled the accurate determination of more than 3500 energy levels of the v2=1and2 vibrational states. The procedure provides a fast and convenient way to analyze large data sets in a straightforward manner, if one of the two vibrational states involved in the transition is accurately known from prior work. In addition to the high-resolution synchrotron study, pure rotational spectra of S2O in the v2=1 and 2 vibrational states were observed in the frequency range 250-500 GHz by absorption spectroscopy in a long-path absorption cell. From these combined measurements, extensive molecular parameter sets have been determined, including full sets of sextic and two octic centrifugal distortion terms. Highly accurate band centers (to better than 10-5 cm-1) have been derived for both vibrational bands.},
author = {Martin-Drumel, M. A. and Endres, C. P. and Zingsheim, O. and Salomon, T. and {Van Wijngaarden}, J. and Pirali, O. and Gruet, S. and Lewen, F. and Schlemmer, S. and McCarthy, M. C. and Thorwirth, S.},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2015.02.014},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Disulfur monoxide,Far-infrared,Fourier-transform spectroscopy,Millimeter-wave spectroscopy,Radio-frequency discharge,S2O,Synchrotron radiation},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
pages = {72--79},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The SOLEIL view on sulfur rich oxides: The S2O bending mode $\nu$2 at 380 cm_1 and its analysis using an Automated Spectral Assignment Procedure (ASAP)}},
volume = {315},
year = {2015}
}

@article{16ThMaEn,
abstract = {The fundamental S-S stretching mode $\nu$3 of disulfur monoxide, S2O, located at 679 cm-1, has been investigated using Fourier-transform far-infrared spectroscopy at the SOLEIL synchrotron facility. A spectroscopic analysis has been performed using an Automated Spectral Assignment Procedure (ASAP) which permits accurate determination of more than 2000 energy levels from $\nu$3. In addition, the $\nu$3 + $\nu$2 - $\nu$2 hot band was observed for the first time and some 500 corresponding energy levels were assigned. The high-resolution synchrotron study was complemented with pure rotational spectra of S2O in the (v1, v2, v3) = (0, 0, 1) vibrational state observed in the frequency range from 250 to 280 GHz using a long-path absorption cell. From these combined measurements, extensive molecular parameter sets have been determined and precise band centers have been derived for both vibrational bands.},
author = {Thorwirth, S. and Martin-Drumel, M. A. and Endres, C. P. and Salomon, T. and Zingsheim, O. and {Van Wijngaarden}, J. and Pirali, O. and Gruet, S. and Lewen, F. and Schlemmer, S. and McCarthy, M. C.},
doi = {10.1016/J.JMS.2015.12.009},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Disulfur monoxide,Far-infrared,Fourier-transform spectroscopy,Millimeter-wave spectroscopy,Radio-frequency discharge,S2O,Synchrotron radiation},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jan},
pages = {47--49},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{An ASAP treatment of vibrationally excited S2O: The $\nu$3 mode and the $\nu$3 + $\nu$2 _ $\nu$2 hot band}},
volume = {319},
year = {2016}
}

@article{86LiRuJo,
abstract = {Diode laser spectroscopy of $\nu$1 and $\nu$3 of 32S218O and $\nu$3 of 32S216O has been carried out and several hundred transition frequencies were measured with a nominal accuracy of ±0.001 cm-1. These data have been combined with earlier microwave and diode laser measurements to produce accurate rotational and distortion constants for the (0, 0, 0), (1, 0, 0), and (0, 0, 1) vibrational states of both isotopic species. These results were combined with microwave data from (0, 1, 0) of both isotopes to allow and equilibrium structure for S2O to be calculated. {\textcopyright} 1986.},
author = {Lindenmayer, Josef and Rudolph, Heinz Dieter and Jones, Harold},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(86)90201-8},
issn = {0022-2852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {1},
pages = {56--67},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The equilibrium structure of disulfur monoxide: Diode laser spectroscopy of $\nu$1 and $\nu$3 of S218O and $\nu$3 of S216O}},
volume = {119},
year = {1986}
}

@article{00BiClDe,
abstract = {The rotational spectra of 32S35Cl2, 32S35Cl37Cl, 32S37Cl2, and 34S35Cl2 in their ground vibrational states, as well as those of 32S35Cl2 and 32S35Cl37Cl in their v2 and 2v2 excited states, have been studied in selected frequency regions between 100 and 370 GHz. Transitions involving a large range of quantum numbers have been observed, so that precise rotational and quartic centrifugal distortion constants could be determined for each of the spectra investigated. The complete set of sextic distortion constants was also obtained for the most abundant isotopomer in its ground vibrational state. The newly determined rotational constants of 34S35Cl2 and 32S37Cl2 allowed us to calculate the complete rsstructure of sulfur dichloride using both single- and double-isotopic substitution methods. The quadratic force field has been refined using a larger set of quartic distortion constants and inertial defects. {\textcopyright} 2000 Academic Press.},
author = {Bizzocchi, L. and Cludi, L. and {Degli Esposti}, C. and Giorgi, A.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2000.8223},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Excited states,Harmonic force field,Isotopic species,Microwave spectroscopy,Molecular structure,Sulfur dichloride},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {275--280},
publisher = {Academic Press Inc.},
title = {{Millimeter-wave spectroscopy of sulfur dichloride}},
volume = {204},
year = {2000}
}

@article{95RaBeEn,
abstract = {The infrared emission spectrum of SH has been observed in the 1850-2800 cm-1 spectral region using a Fourier transform spectrometer. The molecules were excited in a microwave discharge source and the spectra have been recorded at a resolution of 0.005 cm-1. The observed spectra consist of 1-0, 2-1, and 3-2 vibration-rotation bands of the X2 $\Pi$1/2 spin component and 1-0, 2-1, 3-2, and 4-3 bands of the X2 $\Pi$3/2 spin component. The present data were combined with the previous vibration-rotation, pure rotation, and $\Lambda$-doubling measurements in the ground state to yield an improved set of molecular constants. The principal equilibrium constants obtained from this work are: $\omega$e = 2696.2475(58) cm-1, $\omega$exe = 48.7420(28) cm-1, Be = 9.600247(51) cm-1, $\alpha$e = 0.27990(10) cm-1, and re = 1.340614(4) {\AA}. {\textcopyright} 1995 Academic Press, Inc.},
author = {Ram, R. S. and Bernath, P. F. and Engleman, R. and Brault, J. W.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1995.1153},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jul},
number = {1},
pages = {34--42},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Fourier Transform Infrared Emission Spectroscopy of SH}},
volume = {172},
year = {1995}
}

@article{05LaDiHo,
abstract = {The ($
u$4 + $
u$6) - $
u$4, ($
u$4 + $
u$8) - $
u$4 and ($
u$4 + $
u$9) - $
u$4 hot infrared systems of disilane (Si 2H6) have been analysed at high resolution, and the values of the relative vibration-rotation-torsion parameters have been determined. The torsional splitting is about 0.500 cm-1 in the $
u$4 and $
u$4 + $
u$6 states, and decreases strongly in the vibrationally degenerate upper states $
u$4 + $
u$8 (about 0.0272 cm-1 on average) and $
u$4 + $
u$9 (about 0.3019 cm-1), consistent with theoretical predictions. Comparison between the vibrational wavenumbers of cold transitions and hot transitions originating in the excited torsional state v4 = 1 allows one to determine the change of the fundamental torsional frequency $
u$4 caused by the excitation of small amplitude vibrations. A remarkable increase in $
u$4 of about 8.599 cm-1 is found in the v4 = 1 state (E1d SiH3d-rocking mode, asymmetric to inversion in the staggered geometry), and this corresponds to an increase in the torsional barrier height in this excited fundamental vibrational state by about 48.77 cm-1. The mechanism responsible for the decrease of the torsional splittings in the degenerate vibrational states is briefly outlined by means of second-order perturbation theory, using torsion-hindered vibrational basis functions of E1d and E 2d symmetries for the degenerate modes. {	extcopyright} 2005 Taylor & Francis Group Ltd.},
author = {Lattanzi, F and {Di Lauro}, C and Horneman, V. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970500168670},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {19},
pages = {2655--2663},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{Torsional tunneling splittings in the V4 = 1 excited torsional state of Si2H6: Analysis of hot bands accompanying fundamental transitions in the high resolution infrared spectrum}},
url = {https://www-tandfonline-com.wwwproxy1.library.unsw.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970500168670},
volume = {103},
year = {2005}
}

@article{04LaDiHo_2,
abstract = {The lowest infrared active perpendicular fundamental v9 of disilane has been analysed on a Fourier transform spectrum between 320 and 430cm-1, at the spectral resolution of 0.0012cm-1. The rotation-torsion structure of this band is affected by x,y Coriolis interactions with excited torsional levels of the vibrational ground state, correlating with components of 3v4 and 4v4 in the high barrier limit. The interaction of v9 and 4v4, forbidden in the D3d symmetry limit, is allowed between components of E torsional symmetry under the G36(EM) extended molecular group, because of the large amplitude of the internal rotation motion. We could determine the values of the main vibration-rotation-torsion parameters of v9, interaction parameters, and the vibrational wavenumbers of the four torsional components of 3v 4 and of the E3d component of 4v4. The intrinsic torsional splitting of v9 is found to be smaller than in the ground vibrational state by 0.0066 cm-1, in good agreement with our theoretical predictions. The possibility of observing the effects of D 3d-forbidden interactions in the spectra of ethane-like molecules is also discussed.},
author = {Lattanzi, F. and {Di Lauro}, C. and Horneman, V. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970410001672746},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {5},
pages = {507--512},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{Rotation-torsion analysis of the Si2H6 infrared fundamental v9, perturbed by excited torsional levels of the vibrational ground state}},
url = {https://www-tandfonline-com.wwwproxy1.library.unsw.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970410001672746},
volume = {102},
year = {2004}
}

The rotation-torsion structure of this band is affected by x,y Coriolis interactions with excited torsional levels of the vibrational ground state, correlating with components of 3v4 and 4v4 in the high barrier limit. The interaction of v9 and 4v4, forbidden in the D3d symmetry limit, is allowed between components of E torsional symmetry under the G36(EM) extended molecular group, because of the large amplitude of the internal rotation motion. Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{92Mc_2,
abstract = {Assignments of $\nu$(SiH) and $\nu$(SiD) modes in SiHX3, SiH2X2 and SiH3X compounds are surveyed. With a few exceptions, $\nu$(SiH)/$\nu$(SiD) ratios are found to be those expected on the basis of harmonic local mode calculations, if $\nu$(SiD) values are first divided by a factor R which normally lies in the range 1.010-1.011. Major deviations from this range indicate misassignments or Fermi resonances. Stretch-stretch interaction constants f_a are tabulated, and agree excellently with ab initio values, where these are available. Where $\nu$is (SiH) values are known, the frequency sum rule is found to be obeyed closely. The $\nu$7 bands of Si2H6 and Si2D6 are reanalysed to yield an R value of 1.010. The $\nu$(SiH) data for disilanes then yield, in a "6 _ 6" refinement, values of the three interaction force constants f_a, f_g and f_g, together with predictions of hitherto unlocated stretching fundamentals. Constancy of the R factor for different types of XH bonds is shown to be a consequence of Dennison's rules, and similar anharmonicity factors. {\textcopyright} 1992.},
author = {McKean, D. C.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(92)80139-N},
issn = {0584-8539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {oct},
number = {10},
pages = {1335--1345},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{On the assignment of SiH and SiD stretching frequencies: A reanalysis of the $\nu$7 bands of Si2H6 and Si2D6 and a harmonic local mode force field for disilane}},
volume = {48},
year = {1992}
}

@article{04LaDiHo,
abstract = {The infrared active v7 and v5 fundamentals of disilane, coupled by an x,y Coriolis interaction, have been analysed on a Fourier transform spectrum between 2120 and 2225 cm-1, at the Doppler limited spectral resolution. A Fermi resonance with 2v2 + v 9 affects the $\Delta$K = 1 side of v7, and both v 7 and v5 show the effects of several additional localized perturbations. Line splittings in the v5 transitions are not observed, showing that the torsional splitting in the v5 excited state and in the vibrational ground state are almost equal. The intrinsic torsional splitting of v7 is found to be smaller than in the ground vibrational state by 0.0085 cm-1. This splitting value and those found for the other two infrared active degenerate fundamentals, v8 and v9, follow the trend expected from our theoretical predictions. Exploratory numerical calculations show that the decrease of the torsional splittings, observed in the fundamental degenerate vibrational states of disilane, can actually be accounted for by the head-tail and torsional Coriolis coupling of all the degenerate vibrational fundamentals, in several torsional states.},
author = {Lattanzi, F. and {Di Lauro}, C. and Horneman, V. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268970410001719771/SUPPL_FILE/TMPH_A_10063463_SUP_0001.PDF},
issn = {00268976},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {apr},
number = {8},
pages = {757--764},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{The high-resolution infrared spectrum of Si2H6: Rotation-torsion analysis of the v5 and v7 fundamentals, and torsional splittings in the degenerate vibrational states}},
url = {https://www-tandfonline-com.wwwproxy1.library.unsw.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1080/00268970410001719771},
volume = {102},
year = {2004}
}

@article{84BaCa,
abstract = {The millimeter-wave spectra of six isotopic species of SiH3Cl in the ground vibrational states, and of 28SiH335Cl in the $\nu$3 state, have been measured; Bv, DJ, DJK, and eQq values were obtained. The $\nu$6 states of 28SiH335Cl and 28SiH337Cl have also been measured, and B6, DJ, DJK, $\eta$J, and |q6+| determined. The l-resonance in this state is very small and A(1 - $\zeta$) could not be determined. The constants obtained compare well with the less-precise values from high-resolution infrared spectra; the complementary nature of the information from mm-wave and infrared spectroscopy is discussed. {\textcopyright} 1984.},
author = {Barrett, David and Carpenter, John H.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(84)90274-1},issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {1},
pages = {153--159},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The millimeter-wave spectrum of chlorosilane}},
volume = {107},
year = {1984}
}

@article{71RoCaHop,
abstract = {Infra-red spectra have been recorded for silyl fluoride and silyl fluoride-da at a resolution of circa 0-3 cm-1. Rotational structure has been observed for parallel fundamentals in both molecules, and for all perpendicular fundamentals. In both SiD3F and SiD3F the A1 and E species deformation modes interact strongly via a Coriolis perturbation; this has been analysed, and the band origin of v5 for SiH3F is reassigned. A hybrid-orbital force field based on the experimental data is also reported. {\textcopyright} 1971 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Robiette, A. G. and Cartwright, G. J. and Hoy, A. R. and Mills, I. M.},
doi = {10.1080/00268977100100501},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {3},
pages = {541--553},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{The infra-red spectra of silyl fluoride and silyl fluoride-d3}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268977100100501},
volume = {20},
year = {1971}
}

@article{82EsGaBu,
abstract = {Infrared spectra of silyl fluoride were recorded at a resolution of 0.06 cm-1 using a Nicolet Fourier transform interferometer. Analyses of the $\nu$3 and $\nu$4 bands are presented for 28SiH3F, together with work on 29SiH3F, 30SiH3F, and various hot bands. {\textcopyright} 1982.},
author = {Escribano, R. and {Garcia Hernandez}, M. and Butcher, R. J.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(82)90133-3},

pages = {334--349},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{The infrared spectra of SiH3F: $\nu$3 and $\nu$4 bands}},
volume = {95},
year = {1982}
}

@article{76JoKrSu,
abstract = {The $\nu$4 band of silane has been recorded with a resolution of about 0.06 cm-1 in the region from 850 to 950 cm-1. Assignments of all allowed transitions in this range with J_ ² 12 have been made on the basis of frequency and relative intensity. Qualitative agreement with theory is good but quantitative agreement begins to break down above J_ = 8. The breakdown is attributed to the effects of the strong Coriolis interaction with nearby $\nu$2. Lines of 29SiH4 and 30SiH4 have been observed in the R branch with constant isotope shifts of -1.334 cm-1 and -2.600 cm-1. {\textcopyright} 1976.},
author = {Johns, J. W.C. and Kreiner, W. A. and Susskind, J.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(76)90143-0},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {1-3},
pages = {400--411},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Measurement and analysis of the $\nu$4 band of silane}},
volume = {60},
year = {1976}
}

@article{78CaGrRo,
abstract = {The high-resolution infra-red spectrum of SiH4 in the region 2101 cmÐ1 to 2265 cmÐ1 has been analysed. Most of the lines observed have been assigned to transitions of the $\nu$3 and $\nu$1 bands of the abundant isotopic species28SiH4. The $\nu$1 band is formally forbidden in the infra-red, but a vibrationrotation interaction between $\nu$1 and $\nu$3 lends intensity to the $\nu$1 transitions. The spectrum has been fitted by diagonalizing the v3 = 1 and v1 = 1 hamiltonians coupled by the vibration-rotation interaction term. 500 transitions have been fitted with an overall standard deviation of 0_007 cmÐ1, using only 15 adjustable parameters (ten in the v3 = 1 hamiltonian, four in the v1 = 1 hamiltonian, and one interaction coefficient). The calculated intensities are also in good agreement with experiment. Transitions of the other isotopic species29SiH4 and30SiH4 have also been observed, but these spectra have not been analysed in detail. {\textcopyright} 1978 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.},
author = {Cabana, A. and Gray, D. L. and Robiette, A. G. and Pierre, G.},
doi = {10.1080/00268977800102531},
issn = {13623028},
journal = {Molecular Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {5},
pages = {1503--1516},
publisher = {Taylor & Francis Group},
title = {{Analysis of the $\nu$3 and $\nu$1 infra-red bands of SiH4}},
url = {https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00268977800102531 https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00268977800102531},
volume = {36},
year = {1978}
}

@article{00GnMaCo,
abstract = {The present paper deals with the analysis of the microwave, millimeter-wave, and infrared spectra of 28SiHF3 in its ground, $\nu$6 = 1 and $\nu$4 = 1 excited states. The former was observed up to 1055 GHz leading to the determination of one octic centrifugal distortion constant, LJ = -0.0749(55) $\mu$Hz. Furthermore the _k|H|k ± 6_ interaction term |h3,GS| = 1.1032(70) mHz has been fitted from splittings of six K = 3 lines. The excited states have been regarded as isolated ones. This enabled fits according the Q-, D-, and QD-reduction schemes proposed by E. I. Lobodenko, O. N. Sulakshina, V. I. Perevalov, and Vl. G. Tyuterev, (J. Mol. Spectrosc. 126, 159-170 (1987)) and further developed by J. K. G. Watson, C. Gerke, H. Harder, and K. Sarka, (J. Mol. Spectrosc. 187, 131-141 (1997)) and Harder (J. Mol. Spectrosc. 194, 145 (1999)). A multiple fit analysis was performed confirming the assumption that the excited states are not affected by intervibrational resonances. Finally the millimeter spectrum of 29SiHF3 and 30SiHF3 in their ground state was also measured up to 460 GHz and accurate rotational and centrifugal distortion parameters were derived. {\textcopyright} 2000 Academic Press.},
author = {Gnida, M. and Margul{\`{e}}s, L. and Cosl{\'{e}}ou, J. and Bocquet, R. and Demaison, J. and Mkadmi, E. B. and B{\"{u}}rger, H. and Harder, H. and M{\"{a}}der, H.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.1999.8026},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {mar},
number = {1},
pages = {40--54},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Radiofrequency, Centimeter-Wave, Millimeter-Wave, and Infrared Spectra of SiHF3: Investigation of the Ground, $\nu$4 = 1, and $\nu$6 = 1 Vibrational States}},
volume = {200},
year = {2000}
}

Journal: Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy
BibTex_Code:
@article{71BuBiRu,
abstract = {The infrared spectra of gaseous HSiF3 and DSiF3 were recorded with a resolution between 0.2 and 1.0 cm-1. The contours of the fundamentals were analyzed, wherever possible, by classical methods and by a computer program for contour simulation. Table 10 lists the values obtained for $\nu$o, $\alpha$iA, $\alpha$iB, $\zeta$i and some xij. {\textcopyright} 1971.},
author = {B{\"{u}}rger, H. and Biedermann, S. and Ruoff, A.},
doi = {10.1016/0584-8539(71)80224-6},
issn = {05848539},
journal = {Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {9},
pages = {1687--1702},
publisher = {Elsevier},
title = {{Schwingungsspektren und Kraftkonstanten symmetrischer Kreisel-V1 1 IV. Mitteilung s. Ref. [1]. Die IR-Spektren von HSiF3 und DSiF3}},
volume = {27},
year = {1971}
}

@article{92HaAkMi,
abstract = {The $\nu$4 (SiF3 degenerate stretch) fundamental band of SiHF3 has been investigated by the CO2 laser Stark spectroscopy. The vibrationally induced dipole moment was found to give remarkable perturbations of the type ($\Delta$l,$\Delta$K) = (2, - 1) in the $\nu$4 vibrational state under intense electric field. Several perturbation-induced rovibrational transitions obeying the $\Delta$(K - l) = ±3 selection rules were observed in the Stark spectrum. The C0 rotational constant, which is otherwise hard to obtain for a symmetric top molecule, was determined to be 4134.73(71) MHz. The vibrationally induced dipole moment $\mu$, in the $\nu$4 state was derived as ±0.034 38(17) D, the sign being experimentally indeterminable. The band origin, the Coriolis constant C$\zeta$4, and the vibration-rotation constant $\alpha$4care 999.581 076(30) cm-1, 2445.59(71) MHz, and 9.243(22) MHz, respectively. The dipole moment is 1.359 20(22) D in the ground state, and increases by 0.026 73(10) D on excitation of the $\nu$4 vibration. The uncertainties given in the parentheses correspond to three standard deviations. The present results are compared with our previous results of a similar analysis for the deuterated species. The dipole moment in the ground vibrational state decreases by 0.002 01(28) D on deuteration. The vibrationally induced dipole moments $\mu$, and the vibrational changes $\delta$$\mu$4 of the dipole moment for both isotropic species are discussed theoretically. We introduce the coefficient of the mean square amplitude dependence for the bond moment, which is useful in the discussion. {\textcopyright} 1991 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Harada, Kensuke and Akao, Syuji and Miyachi, Kazumi and Tanaka, Keiichi and Tanaka, Takehiko},
doi = {10.1063/1.462444},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {CARBON DIOXIDE LASERS,DEGENERATION,DIPOLE MOMENTS,ELECTRIC FIELDS,HYDROFLUORIC ACID,LASER SPECTROSCOPY,SILICON FLUORIDES,STARK EFFECT,VIBRATIONAL STATES},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {1},
pages = {5--12},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{CO2 laser Stark spectroscopy of the $\nu$4 band of SiHF3: The C0 rotational constant and vibrationally induced dipole moment}},
url = {https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.462444},
volume = {96},
year = {1992}
}

@article{92HaAkMi,
abstract = {The $\nu$4 (SiF3 degenerate stretch) fundamental band of SiHF3 has been investigated by the CO2 laser Stark spectroscopy. The vibrationally induced dipole moment was found to give remarkable perturbations of the type ($\Delta$l,$\Delta$K) = (2, - 1) in the $\nu$4 vibrational state under intense electric field. Several perturbation-induced rovibrational transitions obeying the $\Delta$(K - l) = ±3 selection rules were observed in the Stark spectrum. The C0 rotational constant, which is otherwise hard to obtain for a symmetric top molecule, was determined to be 4134.73(71) MHz. The vibrationally induced dipole moment $\mu$, in the $\nu$4 state was derived as ±0.034 38(17) D, the sign being experimentally indeterminable. The band origin, the Coriolis constant C$\zeta$4, and the vibration-rotation constant $\alpha$4care 999.581 076(30) cm-1, 2445.59(71) MHz, and 9.243(22) MHz, respectively. The dipole moment is 1.359 20(22) D in the ground state, and increases by 0.026 73(10) D on excitation of the $\nu$4 vibration. The uncertainties given in the parentheses correspond to three standard deviations. The present results are compared with our previous results of a similar analysis for the deuterated species. The dipole moment in the ground vibrational state decreases by 0.002 01(28) D on deuteration. The vibrationally induced dipole moments $\mu$, and the vibrational changes $\delta$$\mu$4 of the dipole moment for both isotropic species are discussed theoretically. We introduce the coefficient of the mean square amplitude dependence for the bond moment, which is useful in the discussion. {\textcopyright} 1991 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Harada, Kensuke and Akao, Syuji and Miyachi, Kazumi and Tanaka, Keiichi and Tanaka, Takehiko},

volume = {96},

@article{87PeNeBr,
abstract = {In methylene, the rotational levels of the {\~{a}} 1A 1 (0,0,0) and (0,1,0) vibronic states are so heavily perturbed by nearby rovibrational levels of the ground triplet state (__ 3B1) that standard rotation-vibration Hamiltonians do not provide a satisfactory fit or any indication as to which levels are strongly perturbed and which are less perturbed. Recent spectroscopic and theoretical work gives triplet state term values and the singlet-triplet energy difference with an accuracy of a few tens of wave numbers. Using these term values and ab initio spin-orbit matrix lements it is shown that all Ka=1, 3, and 4 levels of 1A1 (0,0,0) and all Ka=1 levels of 1A1 (0,1,0) are strongly perturbed by 3B 1 (0,$\upsilon$2,0) levels with 2²$\upsilon$2²4. Individual levels in the other Ka stacks are also perturbed but most can be fit satisfactorily with a Watson Hamiltonian. The shifts between the observed term values and those calculated from the Watson Hamiltonian are reproduced in each Ka stack by a spin-orbit matrix element value only 5%-30% larger than the ab initio value. Over 60% of the measured term values show shifts greater than 0.2 cm-1. Shifts of the 322 and 000 levels can only be explained by interaction with levels in either (1,0,0) or (0,0,1) states; possible values for the vibrational frequencies of $\nu$1 and $\nu$3 of 3B1 are given. Molecular constants for 1A1 (0,0,0) and (0,1,0) are derived and quantitative estimates of spin-orbit mixing for individual levels of 1A1 (0,0,0) and (0,1,0) are given. From a chemical point of view singlet methylene is never in a pure spin state and always has some triplet character in its wave function. These data provide a basis for proper modeling of the kinetics of chemical reactions of "singlet" and "triplet" methylene species and their interconversion by "intersystem crossing." {\textcopyright} 1987 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Petek, Hrvoje and Nesbitt, David J. and {Bradley Moore}, C. and Birss, F. W. and Ramsay, D. A.},
doi = {10.1063/1.452264},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {ABSORPTION SPECTRA,L_S COUPLING,METHYLENE RADICALS,ROTATIONAL STATES,SPECTRAL FUNCTIONS,VIBRATIONAL STATES,VISIBLE SPECTRA,ZEEMAN EFFECT},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {3},
pages = {1189--1205},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Visible absorption and magnetic-rotation spectroscopy of 1CH2: Analysis of the 1A1 state and the 1A1-3B1 coupling}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.452264},
volume = {86},
year = {1987}
}

@article{89PeNeDa,
abstract = {The symmetric and antisymmetric stretch spectra of {\~{a}} 1A1 CH2 are measured with Doppler-limited resolution by infrared flash-kinetic spectroscopy between 2600 and 3050 cm -1. The spectra are significantly perturbed by spin-orbit interactions between near-resonant levels of __ 3B1 in both lower and upper levels of the transitions, and by Coriolis interaction between symmetric and antisymmetric stretch states. The triplet character of the perturbed levels is detected by observing broadening of MJ structure in a magnetic field of about 1 kG. The levels that are likely to be perturbed by triplet methylene are identified using the experimentally observed and theoretically calculated 3B1 energy level structure. The term values of the remaining symmetric and antisymmetric stretch levels are simultaneously fit to Watson's Hamiltonian including Coriolis coupling. This analysis provides the remaining information needed to determine the equilibrium rotational constants [Ae = 19.8054(206), Be = 11.2489(45), and Ce = 7.2386(36) cm-1], and, therefore, the equilibrium structure (re = 1.107 {\AA}, and $\theta$e = 102.4¡) of this fundamentally important carbene. The experimental and theoretical structures are in good agreement. {\textcopyright} 1989 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Petek, Hrvoje and Nesbitt, David J. and Darwin, David C. and Ogilby, Peter R. and Moore, C. Bradley and Ramsay, D. A.},
doi = {10.1063/1.457375},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {BOND LENGTHS,CARBENES,CORIOLIS FORCE,ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE,INFRARED SPECTRA,LASER SPECTROSCOPY,L_S COUPLING,METHYLENE RADICALS,MOLECULAR STRUCTURE,POTENTIAL ENERGY SURFACES,VIBRATIONAL STATES},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {11},
pages = {6566--6578},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{Analysis of CH2 {\~{a}} 1A1 (1,0,0) and (0,0,1) Coriolis-coupled states, {\~{a}} 1A1-__ 3B1 spin-orbit coupling, and the equilibrium structure of CH2 {\~{a}} 1A1 state}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.457375},
volume = {91},
year = {1989}
}

@article{83PeNeOg,
abstract = {The transient infrared spectrum of singlet methylene (1CH2) produced by pulsed 308-nm laser photolysis of CH2CO has been observed by time-resolved absorption spectroscopy using a difference frequency infrared laser source. Single rotation-vibration transitions are observed in the 2740-2940-cm-1 region with 0.0013-cm-1 instrumental resolution. Preliminary analysis of the 265 observed transitions yields vibrational frequencies v1 = 2805.9 ± 0.1 cm-1 and v3 = 2864.5 ± 0.3 cm-1, and upper-state rotational constants A_ = 19.8 ± 0.2 cm-1, B_ = 11.0 ± 0.2, C_ = 6.95 ± 0.1, and A_ = 19.3 ± 0.6 cm-1, B_ = 11.16 ± 0.02 cm-1, and C_ = 6.94 ± 0.06 cm-1, for the symmetric and asymmetric stretch, respectively. This marks the first observation of 1CH2 in the infrared, and serves as an excellent test of this general technique for high-resolution infrared spectroscopy of even extremely reactive species. {\textcopyright} 1983 American Chemical Society.},
author = {Petek, Hrvoje and Nesbitt, David J. and Ogilby, Peter R. and Moore, C. Bradley},

publisher = {American Chemical Society},
title = {{Infrared flash kinetic spectroscopy: The v1 and v3 spectra of singlet methylene}},
url = {https://pubs.acs.org/sharingguidelines},

year = {1983}
}

@article{05MuBr,
abstract = {Approximately 150 pure rotational transitions each have been recorded for SO2, v2 = 0 and 1, in selected frequency regions up to 2 THz. The J and Ka quantum numbers reach very high values: 92 and 23, respectively, for the ground vibrational state and 81 and 21, respectively, for the first excited bending state. The highest levels accessed are almost 3000 cm-1 above ground. The relative experimental uncertainties $\Delta$$\nu$/$\nu$ are about 10-8 for several medium to strong, isolated lines, and generally better than 2.5 _ 10-7. Improved spectroscopic parameters have been obtained for both states, particularly for the excited bending state. In fact, the accuracies with which the energy levels of the v2 = 1 state are known depend essentially only on the accuracy with which the vibrational spacing is known from infrared spectroscopy. {\textcopyright} 2005 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.},
author = {M{\"{u}}ller, Holger S.P. and Br{\"{u}}nken, Sandra},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2005.04.010},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Interstellar molecule,Rotational spectroscopy,Secondary standard,Submillimeter wave spectroscopy,Sulfur dioxide,Terahertz spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {2},
pages = {213--222},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Accurate rotational spectroscopy of sulfur dioxide, SO2, in its ground vibrational and first excited bending states, v2 = 0, 1, up to 2 THz}},
volume = {232},
year = {2005}
}

@article{87GuNaUl,
abstract = {High-resolution spectra of sulfur dioxide have been recorded between 1055 and 2550 cm-1 using infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy. More than 18 000 recorded lines have been assigned to nine cold and four hot vibration-rotation bands of SO2. Precise values of the band centers, rotational and centrifugal parameters, and anharmonic constants have been determined that allow one to reproduce and to predict the energy spectrum of SO2 and its isotopic species with high accuracy. {\textcopyright} 1987.},
author = {Guelachvili, G. and Naumenko, O. V. and Ulenikov, O. N.},
doi = {10.1016/0022-2852(87)90199-8},
issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {sep},
number = {1},
pages = {128--139},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Analysis of the SO2 absorption Fourier spectrum in regions 1055 to 2000 and 2200 to 2550 cm-1}},
volume = {125},
year = {1987}
}

@article{02BaChMa,
abstract = {Further analysis of the high-resolution (0.0015 cm_1) infrared spectrum of 32S16O3 has led to the assignment of more than 3100 hot band transitions from the v2 and v4 (levels to the states 2v2 (l = 0), v2 + v4 (l = ±1), and 2v4 (l = 0, ±2). These levels are strongly coupled via Fermi resonance and indirect Coriolis interactions to the v1 levels, which are IR-inaccessible from the ground state. The unraveling of these interactions has allowed the solution of the unusual and complicated structure of the v1 CARS spectrum. This has been accomplished by locating over 400 hot-band transitions to levels that contain at least 10% v1 character. The complex CARS spectrum results from a large number of avoided energy-level crossings between these states. Accurate rovibrational constants are deduced for all the mixed states for the first time, leading to deperturbed values of 1064.924(11), 0.000 840 93(64), and 0.000 418 19(58) cm_1 for v1, $\alpha$1B, and $\alpha$1C, respectively. The uncertainties in the last digits are shown in parentheses and represent two standard deviations. In addition, new values for some of the anharmonicity constants have been obtained. Highly accurate values for the equilibrium rotational constants Be and Ce are deduced, yielding independent, nearly identical values for the SO re bond length of 141.734 03(13) and 141.732 54(18) pm, respectively. {\textcopyright} 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).},
author = {Barber, Jeffrey and Chrysostom, Engelene T.H. and Masiello, Tony and Nibler, Joseph W. and Maki, Arthur and Weber, Alfons and Blake, Thomas A. and Sams, Robert L.},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2002.8646},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {CARS,Infrared,Raman,Spectrum,Sulfur trioxide},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {nov},
number = {1},
pages = {105--112},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{Analysis of v2, v4 infrared hot bands of 32S16O3: Resolution of the puzzle of the v1 CARS spectrum}},
volume = {216},
year = {2002}
}

@article{01MaBlSa,
abstract = {New measurements are reported for the infrared spectrum of sulfur trioxide, 32S16O3, with resolutions ranging from 0.0015 cm_1 to 0.0025 cm_1. Rovibrational constants have been measured for the fundamentals v2, v3, and v4 and the overtone band 2v3. Comparisons are made with the earlier high-resolution measurements on SO3, and the high correlation among some of the constants related to the Coriolis coupling of the v2 and v4 levels is discussed in order to understand the areas of disagreement with the earlier work. Splittings of some of the levels are observed and the splitting constant for K = 3 of the ground state is determined for the first time. Other observed splittings include the K = 1 levels of 2v3 (l = 2), the K = 2 levels of v3 and v4, and the K = 3 levels of v2. The analysis shows that there are level crossings between the l = 0 and l = 2 states of 2v3 that allow one to determine the separation of the subband centers for these two states even though access to the l = 0 state from the ground state is electric-dipole forbidden. This is a generalized phenomenon that should be found for many other molecules with the same symmetry. The l-type resonance constant, q3, that causes the splitting of the l3 = ±1, k = ±1 levels of v3 also couples the l3 = 0 and 2 states of 2v3. {\textcopyright} 2001 Elsevier Science.},
author = {Maki, Arthur and Blake, Thomas A. and Sams, Robert L. and Vulpanovici, Nicolae and Barber, Jeffrey and Chrysostom, Engelene T.H. and Masiello, Tony and Nibler, Joseph W. and Weber, Alfons},
doi = {10.1006/jmsp.2001.8454},
issn = {00222852},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Infrared,Spectrum,Sulfur trioxide},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
month = {dec},
number = {2},
pages = {240--249},
publisher = {Academic Press},
title = {{High-resolution infrared spectra of the v2, v3, v4, and 2v3 bands of 32s16O3}},
volume = {210},
year = {2001}
}

Splittings of some of the levels are observed and the splitting constant for K = 3 of the ground state is determined for the first time. @article{54MaLa,
abstract = {The infrared spectra of thionyl chloride and sulfuryl chloride have been investigated from 400 cm-1 to to 5000 cm-1 with a prism spectrometer. Three of the fundamentals of SOCl2 have been found and four for SO2Cl2. They and the various additional bands have been assigned to their appropriate symmetry species assuming SOCl 2 has C3 symmetry and SO2Cl2 has C2v symmetry.},
author = {Martz, Dowell E. and Lagemann, Robert T.},
doi = {10.1063/1.1740330},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
mendeley-groups = {PhD/5_HarmBenchmark,PhD/5_HarmBenchmark/Freqs_refs},
number = {7},
pages = {1193--1195},
title = {{Infrared spectra of thionyl chloride and sulfuryl chloride}},
volume = {22},
year = {1954}
}

@article{15MaMoPi,
abstract = {Abstract Thionyl chloride (SOCl2) is a volatile inorganic compounds used extensively in industry. Its monitoring in gas phase is critical both for environmental and defense concerns. Previous high-resolution gas phase spectroscopic studies were focused on the microwave region (below 40 GHz) and no rotationally-resolved study of the IR spectrum has been reported to date. We present in this article a rovibrational analysis of the two lowest frequency infrared active bending modes $\nu$3 and $\nu$6 of SOCl2. By means of synchrotron based Fourier-Transform far-infrared spectroscopy on the AILES beamline of the SOLEIL facility, the spectra of the symmetric $\nu$3 (346 cm-1) and asymmetric $\nu$6 (283 cm-1) fundamental bands have been rotationally resolved and analyzed.},
author = {Martin-Drumel, Marie Aline and Mouret, Ga{\"{e}}l and Pirali, Olivier and Cuisset, Arnaud},
doi = {10.1016/j.jms.2015.02.001},issn = {1096083X},
journal = {Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy},
keywords = {Far-IR synchrotron radiation,Low-frequency modes,Rovibrational spectroscopy,SOCl2,Thionyl chloride},
mendeley-groups = {Refs_frequencies,FREQ_refs},
pages = {30--36},
publisher = {Elsevier Inc.},
title = {{High-resolution synchrotron far infrared spectroscopy of thionyl chloride: Analysis of the $\nu$3 and $\nu$6 fundamental bands}},
url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jms.2015.02.001},
volume = {315},
year = {2015}
}

@article{17RoDhCu,
abstract = {The $\nu$2 and $\nu$5 fundamental bands of thionyl chloride (SOCl2) were measured in the 420 cm-1-550 cm-1 region using the FT-far-IR spectrometer exploiting synchrotron radiation on the AILES beamline at SOLEIL. A straightforward line-by-line analysis is complicated by the high congestion of the spectrum due to both the high density of SOCl2 rovibrational bands and the presence of the $\nu$2 fundamental band of sulfur dioxide produced by hydrolysis of SOCl2 with residual water. To overcome this difficulty, our assignment procedure for the main isotopologues 32S16O35Cl2 and 32S16O35Cl37Cl alternates between a direct fit of the spectrum, via a global optimization technique, and a traditional line-by-line analysis. The global optimization, based on an evolutionary algorithm, produces rotational constants and band centers that serve as useful starting values for the subsequent spectroscopic analysis. This work helped to identify the pure rotational submillimeter spectrum of 32S16O35Cl2 in the v2=1 and v5=1 vibrational states of Martin-Drumel et al. [J. Chem. Phys. 144, 084305 (2016)]. As a by-product, the rotational transitions of the v4=1 far-IR inactive state were identified in the submillimeter spectrum. A global fit gathering all the microwave, submillimeter, and far-IR data of thionyl chloride has been performed, showing that no major perturbation of rovibrational energy levels occurs for the main isotopologue of the molecule.},
author = {Roucou, Anthony and Dhont, Guillaume and Cuisset, Arnaud and Martin-Drumel, Marie Aline and Thorwirth, Sven and Fontanari, Daniele and Meerts, W. Leo},
doi = {10.1063/1.4996655},
file = {::},
issn = {10897690},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {evolutionary computation,isomerism,isotope effects,rotational states,rotational-vibrational states,submillimetre wave spectra,sulphur compounds,vibrational states},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {5},
pages = {054303},
pmid = {28789547},
publisher = {NLM (Medline)},
title = {{High resolution study of the $\nu$2 and $\nu$5 rovibrational fundamental bands of thionyl chloride: Interplay of an evolutionary algorithm and a line-by-line analysis}},
url = {http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.4996655},
volume = {147},
year = {2017}
}

@article{75MiShHa,
abstract = {The infrared and Raman spectra of 1,2-dichloroethane and its deuterium compound in the gaseous, liquid, and solid states have been remeasured in the wide range of wavelength by the experimental techniques developed recently. Normal coordinate treatments have been made for crystals as well as for free molecules by use of computer programs made by us, and all the vibrational frequencies observed for free molecules and crystals have been assigned satisfactorily. Our previous conclusions of the existence of the trans and gauche forms have been confirmed spectroscopically and, furthermore, supported theoretically by the quantum mechanical treatment of the internal rotation.},
author = {Mizushima, S. and Shimanouchi, T. and Harada, I. and Abe, Y. and Takeuchi, H.},
doi = {10.1139/p75-259},
issn = {0008-4204},
journal = {Canadian Journal of Physics},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
number = {19},
pages = {2085--2094},

@article{75MiShHa,
abstract = {The infrared and Raman spectra of 1,2-dichloroethane and its deuterium compound in the gaseous, liquid, and solid states have been remeasured in the wide range of wavelength by the experimental techniques developed recently. Normal coordinate treatments have been made for crystals as well as for free molecules by use of computer programs made by us, and all the vibrational frequencies observed for free molecules and crystals have been assigned satisfactorily. Our previous conclusions of the existence of the trans and gauche forms have been confirmed spectroscopically and, furthermore, supported theoretically by the quantum mechanical treatment of the internal rotation.},
author = {Mizushima, S. and Shimanouchi, T. and Harada, I. and Abe, Y. and Takeuchi, H.},
doi = {10.1139/p75-259},

@article{86MaMc,
abstract = {The $\nu$2 (bending) fundamental band of CH2 in its __ 3B1 ground electronic state has been studied using tunable diode laser spectroscopy and also the LMR (laser magnetic resonance) technique in the 800-911 cm-1 and 1030-1173 cm-1 regions. For the diode laser study, a multiple-traversal absorption cell was used with Zeeman modulation, and the CH2 radicals were produced by a mild discharge in a flowing mixture of ketene (_0.3 Torr) and helium (_2 Torr). Under these conditions, the apparent lifetime of CH2 following cutoff of the discharge was about 1 ms. A total of 53 new transitions with rotational quantum numbers up to N=10, K_a=3, and K_a=2 were observed to add to the 11 transitions previously measured in this band. A combined analysis of the present data and all the previous pure rotational and $\nu$2 band results on CH2 has yielded an improved set of molecular parameters, including the first determination of centrifugal distortion effects for the dominant spin-spin interaction parameter, D. The present data have also been used in a comprehensive new analysis of triplet methylene rotation-vibration energies using the nonrigid bender Hamiltonian by Bunker et al. in an accompanying paper. {\textcopyright} 1986 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Marshall, Mark D. and McKellar, A. R.W.},
doi = {10.1063/1.450943},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {ENERGY_LEVEL TRANSITIONS,INFRARED SPECTRA,MAGNETIC RESONANCE,METHYLENE RADICALS,MOLECULAR STRUCTURE,ROTATIONAL STATES,SPECTRAL RESOLUTION,ZEEMAN EFFECT},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {aug},
number = {7},
pages = {3716--3723},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{The $\nu$2 fundamental band of triplet CH2}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.450943},
volume = {85},
year = {1986}
}

@article{88JeBu,
abstract = {The Morse oscillator-rigid bender internal dynamics (MORBID) Hamiltonian [P. Jensen, J. Mol. Spectrosc. 128, 478 (1988) ] has been used in a fitting to all extant rotation-vibration data for __3B1 methylene CH2. This fitting leads to an improved determination of the potential energy surface, and in particular to reliable predictions for the stretching frequencies. We predict v1 = 2992 cm-1 and v3 = 3213 cm-1 for 12CH2, and we hope that the new predictions will encourage the experimental search for these weak fundamentals. In the MORBID approach the rotation-vibration energies are obtained from the potential energy surface in a purely variational calculation, and consequently the present work is an improvement over previous determinations of the CH2 potential energy surface from experiment that used the nonrigid bender formalism [see P. R. Bunker et al., J. Chem. Phys. 85, 3724 (1986), and references therein]; this latter approach treats the stretching vibrations by second order perturbation theory. A fitting to the J = 0 vibrational energy data for {\~{a}}1A1 methylene has also been made here using the MORBID Hamiltonian. Combining the results of these MORBID fittings to experimental data for the (X_) and ({\~{a}}) states of CH2 we obtain the singlet-triplet splittings T0({\~{a}} 1A1) = 3147 cm-1 (8.998 kcal/mol) and T e ({\~{a}} 1A1) = 3223 cm-1 (9.215 kcal/ mol). {\textcopyright} 1988 American Institute of Physics.},
author = {Jensen, Per and Bunker, P. R.},
doi = {10.1063/1.455184},
issn = {00219606},
journal = {The Journal of Chemical Physics},
keywords = {HAMILTONIAN FUNCTION,METHYLENE RADICALS,MORSE POTENTIAL,POTENTIAL ENERGY SURFACES,ROTATIONAL STATES,VIBRATIONAL STATES},
mendeley-groups = {FREQ_refs},
month = {jun},
number = {3},
pages = {1327--1332},
publisher = {American Institute of PhysicsAIP},
title = {{The potential surface and stretching frequencies __3B 1 methylene (CH2) determined from experiment using the Morse oscillator-rigid bender internal dynamics Hamiltonian}},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1063/1.455184},
volume = {89},
year = {1988}
}
